headline: Excellent colleagues and work and lots of change
pros:
The people you work with are fantastic, there is a great work culture and you get to work on exciting projects.

There is real optimism around the work and the impact the company is having, and there are really good development opportunities and ways to partake in different projects across the business. Internal networking is brilliant, and the ERGs have a really good following and calendar of events.

Benefits and perks are very good and are focused around financial wellbeing in particular.
cons:
There is a lot of change, which can be said about many businesses, especially in the FinTech space.

Working with US colleagues can mean working some unsociable hours. You do have to manage expectations about your availability, but generally the business is accomodating of the difference in timezones.

headline: Inept Executive Leadership

I don't even understand how Amex ever functioned working with the people who came from there.

headline: Great company but lacking in long-term strategic vision
pros:
Great environment to work in. The people are caring and there is support to make your working day as great as it can be. The company is flexible in its work ethos and there is a really collegial atmosphere with your workmates.

People work well together and there is surprisingly little egos and politics when compared to some other large companies. 

When it wants to get something done, the business can be focused and deliver quickly and well, but it takes a lot of effort to get there.
cons: Constant re-orgs and job changes means it's hard to focus on your role for long. Feels like there's a very short-term view of strategy, always looking to deliver on what Wall St requirements are for the next quarter rather than take a long-term view of the business. This means your priorities shift regularly and it can feel like you're chasing your tail constantly.

headline: An old dog trying to learn new tricks but chases it’s own tail.

cons:
The highest management for the org seems tone deaf. We do virtual trash pick ups on earth day. There are constant reorgs.
They love the major corporate feeling. They’re really good at stripping amazing benefits from the companies they acquire including: gym memberships, free food, free health insurance, competitive pay.

headline: Great benefits, wonderful teammates, mixed bag of leadership.
pros: Hands down the main reason to keep working here was the best medical/dental/vision benefits available.
cons:
Your experience will greatly vary based on your supervisor all the way up. I had some of the worst and the best supervisors during my time there.
Terrible work/life balance. Only in recent years did they give sick leave or close on Christmas. If you are in an operations team expect to work most holidays. Expect to get an attendance occurrence if you are a minute late for work. Emergency in late or out early? Depends on your supervisor if they will work with you or not.

headline: chaotic execution
pros: the Pay is OK, although the RSUs have gone down for many that have been hired in the past year. I have a neutral to positive outlook personally on the stock. there will be some short term challenges for the company coming up but nothing insurmountable.
cons:
operationaly speaking, it's chaotic and sometimes down right absurd. there are organizational divisions that simply do not make sense. it causes execution problems and software/product quality issues.  I have never worked for a company (and I have worked for other large companies) where most of the people in meetings have no idea what is going on. i believe it has been caused by years of nepotistic hiring bringing in people that are not qualified. 

I think finally there are a lot of execs that need to go. Especially in the Omni org.

headline: Proceed with Caution

cons: They tell you you will be able to earn great commissions or bonuses. Not true. They put you on the worst deals to start with. Also, you HAVE to put up with verbally abusive customers, you are NOT allowed to disconnect them, even with a warning! NO ONE should have to put up with that at any job!

headline: Good job to start
pros: Benefits are great. We had the possibility to work from home in 2021.
cons:
- The teams are managed by leaders without experience. If your leader does not like you, you are done, it is very difficult to get a promotion.
-Your job is answering calls for 10 hours, with the stress of reaching impossible targets. It does not matter how good you are or try in the calls, if the customer give you a zero, that is what defines your job.
-It is supposed to be a rotation job.it is not. The same people are always in calls and only the chosen ones are in chat not doing much.
- Work here 1, 2 years and then leave.

headline: Toxic Workplace
pros: No pros come to mind
cons: Leaving this sales organization was the best decision I have made, both financially and emotionally. Sales reps are underpaid, taken advantage of, and gaslit by management into working unreasonable hours for a salary equivalent to minimum wage. The managers are all white men, with no representation from women or other backgrounds. Employees have also been told that only those who come into the office full time will be considered for promotions moving forward. HR from PayPal would be wise to look into how the sales organization is being run, if only due to the massive turnover it has seen in the last 9 months.

headline: A Sinking Ship
pros: Benefits, stock options, currently remote.
cons:
Constant pay cuts, micro managers, toxic work place, leaders are not fit for their role to lead, unfair treatments & opportunities, and no upward mobility. 
If you are in sales, you are money motivated. News flash, paypal no longer takes care of their reps. They would rather hire people right out of college and tell them they can make 100K. We were making 180K-200K. PayPal just use their globally known name to hire/keep their reps instead of actually compensating them well. I would rather work for a company who takes care of me and compensates me well than work for a company for their name. People who get promoted are ones that management likes to take golfing and to happy hour. If you are a female you are only being promoted because they have to even out male to female ratio.
Would not recommend this job to my worst enemy. If you are about to start this job: Welcome to the sinking ship and make sure you have a life vest.

headline: Not the best company to work for…
pros:
Really good healthcare and insurance
Your individual manager always tries their best with whatever information or tools they have (they are just as limited for most things).
cons:
Working on Venmo’s side of the corporation, we don’t get all the benefits that ‘actual’ PayPal employees get. Venmo customer service employees are treated very poorly with little to no communication about changes or updates about the company. When you need information, the supervisors don’t know what’s going either so they send you in circles. We don’t have the same time off benefits or shifts as ‘actual’ PayPal employees. They used to preach about opportunities but since being here (4 years) the company has had less and less and now hire outside for more roles.
Now, since working from home, there is a false sense of community and team- what is, is limited and it’s only out there so that the company can check that box.
The turnover is so high that some teammates have gone through 5-8 managers in a single year.

headline: Good culture, no advancement
pros: Good culture, decent pay. A variety of positions available.
cons:
I have worked for PayPal for eight years and the first several before we went public were some of the best. We were constantly paid more every year, we got large bonuses and advancement came when you wanted. 

Since going public in 2016 things have been going down hill. Responsibility has skyrocketed and the amount of information you are expected to retain is endless. You need to be a psychologist, a sociologist. You need to be public relations and a product expert in 8 queues. 

PayPal has moved away from specialization in an attempt to break down silos but instead what has happened is PayPal expects more and more work and continues to hand out 2% raises for "Meets Expectations" and rarely hands out "Exceeds" especially if you are on a specialist team. 

In 2019 my pay increased from 35k to 40k which was amazing but every year there after and for a few years leading up to that we were given 2% raises which are consistently below inflation. Which means PayPal would tell me how great I am and then effectively pay me less every year despite increased responsibility. 

I have moved from frontline, to specialists in various roles to senior agent and in that time my pay has moved by a total of 3%. 

This is not acceptable.

headline: You will be happy
pros: There are several Pros that PayPal has to offer. They're global and can provide a lot of experience in the Fintech industry especially since PayPal offers crypto now. PayPal offers a fantastic work-life balance. PayPal also cares about your mental and physical wellness. This is a priority to them and they let you know they care. Advancement opportunities are readily available. Sometimes you will have to move laterally before you move vertically, but as long as you know what you want, and are preparing yourself for it, doors will open. PayPal offers stock options and allows you to purchase stock at a 15% discount per each paycheck. They also give you stock options at the end of the year as a bonus based on performance. PayPal keeps growing and has no intention to stop. Its variety in offering payment solutions for the underbanked is truly amazing and limitless. Lastly, but not least, after 5 years of service, PayPal will give you a 30-day paid sabbatical for you to enjoy and will do this every 5 years you work there.
cons: Cons ... as long as you have a growth mindset, there are no cons. You will get feedback about your performance and if you do not like it, it may bother you. But of course, as long as you are staying responsible and accountable for your work, then it should all be good. A con for me is that at the end of the day, its a job. I have to constantly remind myself that I should be thankful for all of the amazing things this job offers. For many, it has turned into a career.

headline: Started off great, but slowly turned into a nightmare
pros:
When I first started with this company, I worked in operations as a phone agent, so I’ll list pros that apply to operations.
The operations team had some really wonderful leadership: folks who were constantly optimistic, inspired, and overjoyed to help their teammates grow in the company. There were a ton of opportunities to learn about other departments, partner with other teams to tackle problems, and even help our training teams manage their workload. We got to volunteer with our teams once a year, which was lovely. One year, my leader took our team on a paid “team retreat” where we learned more about diversity and inclusion in a relaxed environment. Our group leader had hundreds of people under her at one point, but was still able to focus on every individual and call out their strengths. Absolutely amazing experience. Until I moved to a support role.
cons:
Towards the end of my PayPal journey, I spent a year interning in a support role. During this internship, I was basically given busy work by my “managers” to keep me quiet, and completely ignored by them otherwise. I hoped that if I stuck around long enough, maybe I would get some actual training. Little did I know, the nightmare had just begun.

I was given the support role, and immediately discovered the pay for this “promotion to salary pay” was 2000.00 less annually than I had earned the year prior as operational leadership. But my health insurance cost nearly doubled as a result of switching to salary. So I lost money for this “amazing” new role.

Then, after a year of no training by leadership while interning, I was suddenly plunged into a hellscape of:
-still no actual training
- having huge projects flung at me without warning, usually two- three months later than I should have known about them, causing major issues for the company and my sanity
- oh by the way, these projects you don’t get notified about until they are three months in? They’re all going to be labeled “high visibility high priority moonshots” so I better not mess up, right? Ha!
- Id would be doing that moonshot high visibility top priority project that I have zero training for and require PD support for (and tell my boss this) then my own boss would go and tell PD to prioritize something else completely so it won’t get done on time and then I would get yelled at by my boss even though my boss knowingly sabotaged it for me and still expected me to complete the project according to near impossible timeframes
-I remember successfully creating a gigantic presentation I was told about last minute and presenting it to upper management to rave reviews- only for my own manager to pull me aside and say I did “fine” but would never succeed as a manager unless I dropped 1500.00 on a Carnegie Mellon public speaking course
-did I mentioned no training for this role?!
-I had my senior manager state he wanted to meet with me to discuss a list of issues I had identified and shared on yet another high priority moonshot. He insisted I set up the meeting at a very specific time, and proceeded to simply not show up. I sat in a teams meeting for 30 minutes while he refused to respond to my messages asking him to join. When I rescheduled the meeting later in the week, he showed up hostile and cranky, and when I asked him to please let me know if he wouldn’t be able to make it to a meeting, he yelled at me that he had apologized to one of my peers about that “the other day” so I needed to get over it. This manager then never spoke to me directly ever again- for a year.
-the white male management just loves talking about how they’ve recently hired “so many women and are so diverse”- meanwhile this group is less diverse than they have ever been, with all the female senior management leaving, one after the other. More on that….
-every Black, Mexican and Asian manager and their teams were abruptly moved to other departments with no warning in one fell swoop towards the end of my time with the company. Whether this was intentional or not, it looked incredibly bad on my department.
-eleven hour shifts. Probably with no lunch. Get on early enough to meet with someone in the UK(5am) stay on late enough to meet with someone in Australia (5pm) and probably have to do some extra work with India (10pm) from your phone while laying in bed. It never stops. And while all this is happening, your managers are going on vacations back to back. It’s a nightmare!
-being gaslit by management. They refuse to respond to requests for help, then find a way to blame you if things don’t go as they should. These people should not manage the department they do as they have no certifications or degrees of any kind and no knowledge on the subject. They BS their way through work and throw the “hard” stuff onto new hires and other support positions. 
- Finally, I ended up having to go on leave due to major depression prior to leaving the company. Two months in, my leave was approved with less than a week of leave time left, and I got the correspondence via email. Then, I put in a resignation three days later, and the leave was suddenly denied via paper letter because I “dressed appropriately” to go to my doctor and therefore couldn’t have been ill. Seems awfully retaliatory and illegal to me, but whatever. :) ok PayPal 

Anyway, long story short. PayPal was a wonderful place to be for nearly eight years. I loved my job and never wanted to leave. Once I started with this support role, I started hating it and had to get out for the sake of my own sanity. No job is worth crying at your desk every day over, and once it gets to that point it will likely never go back.

headline: Good company but a lot of churn at upper levels
pros: The work is interesting, the people are great, the salary and benefits are great. A+ on diversity, inclusion, and company values.
cons: However, there has been a great deal of churn at the upper levels which leads to instability and uncertainty for those of us swimming down below.

headline: Started off well....
pros: Wellness days - health insurance plan
cons: You really are just a number - started off well, felt like we were really appreciated then out of nowhere we were told our shifts may change, I was currently working on Wednesday-Saturday. We were given 5 different types of shifts to choose from and asked to rate them for our preferences - I sent my preferences back to management to then be told a week later I will be given my 5th Preference..... Yes that's right, my least preferred shift! Why bother giving us an option to rate our preferences if they would be completely disregarded anyway. Tried to take this up with my team lead in which they responded in other words "it's in your contract so there's nothing you can do (though)" This happened to most of my co-workers too in which I have heard are all activly seeking employment elsewhere (including myself). Also found out PayPal have just given all the new hires their first preference shift (which was my first preference) left me feeling VERY underappreciated, over worked as I am skilled in many departments. Loved the company at first, now applying to other companies, actively scheduling interviews and can't see myself working for PayPal for much longer.

headline: Amazing culture and mission
pros: PayPal describes its culture as 'people centric' and I've found it to be absolutely true. Employees are passionate about the company's mission to democratize payments and are committed to one another (and the company's) success. Unlike many companies, colleagues at PayPal consistently seek ways to support and help one another, even if it means taking on more work themselves.
cons: During COVID, the desire to collaborate has led to too many meetings

headline: The Marie Antionette Moment
pros:
I realized the extent of my burnout when there was an email hyping third quarter, lots to launch, we’re in a marathon but start sprinting. 4 weeks later, another email came about management's refreshing 2-week vacations, the realization of how important it was to recharge and how good it was to step away for time with their families, yet it's still 3rd quarter, so keep sprinting. 

For the majority who can’t take time off due to an overload of varying production deadlines and escalations and who start their workday earlier and end them later just to keep up, this came across as exceptionally tone deaf. Making it worse was an all hands discussing how to ensure a better work life balance—here, read some slide decks. 

What finally convinced me to write this review was when a dev colleague told me after he’d been diagnosed with a serious illness, his manager asked if he could take on an additional product launch to the ones he's currently handling. In short, it’s your own damn fault if you can’t manage self-care, regardless of the work load. 

Pros:
•	Good health benefits 
•	401k match 
•	ESPP program
•	RSUs
•	Commuting reimbursements
•	Roth 401k
•	Track free vacation - no need to put in a request for time off weeks in advance
cons:
Cons: 
•	2020 Covid moonshot attitude focus, aka “all hands on deck/sprint to you drop, people!”, is now the workstyle norm 
•	Reports overload. Multiple, often duplicate reports must be done each week. Even if there was no movement, something must get added (punctuation change, word deletion) otherwise it’s a mark against you.
•	Rampant Yes Man culture in meetings where people race to add their “wow, fantastic insight!” comments in the meeting chat just to get noticed for promotion
•	Quarterly team re-orgs that are just constant churn / chaos
•	Layoffs in January/early Feb (avoids bonus payout) 
•	Promotions are difficult to achieve. The process is pretty much where the manager who shouts the loudest in the ranking meeting, gets the promotions 
•	Fewer RSU awards 
•	Track free vacation almost impossible to use due to the workload. Most people end up only taking 2 weeks at the end of the year

headline: Exhausted
pros:
-The nature of my role is that I interface with scores of engineering teams, analysts etc. across PayPal on products that get released all the time. It’s an exciting space to be in
-Visibility is very good, at least in my org
-Unlimited PTO (if you can use it)
-The investopia slack channel
-Focus on gender diversity
cons:
-Reorgs (and rearchitectures depending on the domain) happen nonstop
-Heavy politics. You can tell if you’ve done a project well if three other teams try to take credit for it
-My WLB is dismal. I work 12+ hrs daily. One time I had an ongoing personal emergency (which I notified my team about) and could only work a 40 hour week and I got publicly berated; I was told I needed to “grow up” and work more than 60 hours per week
-Low Pay. We already make less than industry standard, and I recently found out that I’m getting paid 20% less than the rest of my team. Upper management responded by raising my salary 3% 😐
-I have a technical background and I’m in a technical role. However a significant part of my job comes from my boss volunteering to do PowerPoints for their bosses and then farming it out to me
-Be careful who you tell your ideas to. If you show interest in something or if you think something could be more optimized, they will make you do it and own/run it addition to your day job.

headline: It was great... UNTIL
pros: The sales department used to be a great place to work. The goals were managable and the people had a TON of fun, energy and excitment. The pay was really good as well.
cons: i wored as a sales rep for 9 years and loved about 7 of it, the last 2 years went down hill quickly. Telesales turned into a nightmare once the new managment of the sales department came in and cleaned house. They let go of ALOT really great people and just let them go out of nowhere. Then came the goals... oh wow! Goals went up to an astronomical amount, they were raised by 65% , let me repeat that... 65% without ANY better leads or way of "achieving your goal", they jsut raised them and said well.. it is what it is. Over 10 of the most serniored sales people (including myself) had been in sales over 7 years EACH and we all left becasue the pay was horrible for the amount of work they wanted us to do. there is NO life/work balance. the goals do not match up to the pay they are giving. when going on an interview, make sure to ask "how many seniored sales rep have left in the last 6 months", because its been more than 10 at this date.

headline: People of color, go elsewhere.
pros: Literally the only good thing here is their benefits, everything else sucks. Please beware of their lies.
cons: Literally everything, they lied about how they treat employees. If you get covid once you're good but if it happens to someone you need to take care of after you are out of luck. Their pay increase is base on performance but every year they make it harder and harder to get a pay increase. Oh and the bonus, you used to get quarterly bonuses now it's yearly, literally anything to make sure they save money. They are firing those that have high hourly to hire people for less pay. I had no idea about Glassdoor until another person of color that's was let go for the same lie of a reason let me know. I definitely will be tell every other person I know that is dealing with this about know about this.

headline: After COVID avoid working here.
pros: Good benefits and work from home for those looking for that but that is about it.
cons:
The moment their stocks went from about $95 a stock to over $300 a stock they no longer care about the employee but about the stock holder. They talk about about caring about your health and financial wellness but this is simply no true. They have changed stats to make it where the only thing that matters is how many customers you help, more of quantity over quality. 

They release products that are not completed and leave front line employees to deal with the issues and the angry customer. We are not allowed to hang up on abusive customers but only report them after the call. You can literally have every number great but if your handle time is bad you will get fired. They do not care if you have the best knowledge of any customer service agent in your team or how happy you keep customers, if your handle time is high you will get fired.

They will also blame you for technical issue with the equipment provided to you. If the laptop given to you is so slow that your calls keep dropping or it add to your handle time with a customer, guess what? It is your fault. When you contact IT to solve any issues, it never gets solved but because of this you are not able to work, guess what? It's your fault. 

When it comes to moving up in the company, hiring is about how much you are liked by the hiring manager vs how much you qualify for the position. I have 6 years of sales experience however the people that got the sales jobs have none yet were cool with the managers, same as supervisor positions. PayPal no longer cares about their employee or truly assisting customer, I no longer even use PayPal for my own business. They talk about inclusion yet it seems odd that a lot of the people being let go seem to be people of color, maybe Mr. Schulman should take a look at that before yelling out that his company embodies inclusion.

If you care about your sanity and your mental health please avoid this place like COVID. I became suicidal because everything was our fault and never GCS upper management that I am pretty certain they have never ever worked front line a day in their life.

headline: Going the Way of the Dodo
pros: Excellent team dynamics, competitive health benefits and some of the best team leads in the business.
cons:
Poor treatment by VP's, layoffs, antiquated systems with horrible, outsourced global service desk that is incapable of fixing issues and complete tickets without resolution. 
This was the best year in PP history and across the board and annual raises of 2% or less do not come close to covering the cost of living increases and/or inflation. 
Plans to employ a geographical wage which means any remote employees that move to another state with lower cost of living will see their wages decreased to match the cost of living in the new state.

headline: Wonderful people, but absolutely exhausting
pros: PayPal's benefits and compensation attracts top talent. Many of my colleagues have been wonderful - collaborative, communicative, innovative. Collectively, we've been able to drive meaningful change and deliver innovative internal products.
cons: I've observed the organization to be highly political. Career advancement is near impossible. Most "promotions" for individual contributors come in the form of role name changes or added responsibilities. PayPal has many perks, but some have withered as the company has continued to mature. Our department is very much focused on farming out work, reducing the number of FTEs in favor of contractors and consultants. The hours can be incredibly long, and work-life balance almost non-existent. Myself and others consistently work 50-60 hour weeks in an attempt to stay ahead (or simply afloat).

headline: Great vision
pros:
Company has a great vision - democratizing financial services for everyone. A lot of social justice and diversity programs within and outside the company. Company policies and communication demonstrate caring for employee well being and doing good work in the community and the world.

Competitive compensation with stock as long as the stock keeps rising like it has. Flexible time off as long as you have a good manager.
cons:
Burnout from putting out fires all the time. Everything is top priority. There's a constant drive to start new projects before the old one was fully completed.

Positions don't get backfilled when people leave as long as the work continues around the same pace, which people stretch to do. Not enough time and resources invested in quality improvements - devOps, architecture design, individual learning, etc. There's not enough senior tech leadership / oversight, so a lot of garbage code gets written that ends up causing a lot of time-wasting issues later on.

headline: Negative Culture, Almost No Opportunities For Growth
pros: Job security, and great speeches from the CEO
cons:
I unfortunately experienced many critical issues working at PayPal.

The biggest issue I faced was around promotions and raises. They give each department so few allocated promotions, that most teams aren’t given even a single promotion for years. This creates a serious problem, because so many people are under leveled and under compensated, that most just decide to leave as soon as their stocks vest after the first or second year, causing a huge drain of knowledge and experience, and a never ending cycle of recruiting. 

Then, our yearly budget for raises is incredibly small. As a manager, it was disheartening to tell my direct reports that I couldn’t give them a raise more than approx. 2%, even though they deserved it, because of PayPal’s allocated budget. It really felt like mixed signals when they keep bragging about their highest profit levels ever in their earnings calls, but then tell us their isn’t enough budget for raises to keep up with inflation.

Additionally, compensation packages for new hires is reasonable, but lower than most of their competitors, which made it extremely difficult to get candidates to accept offers.

I also unfortunately experienced an issue with diversity and inclusion. When I was affected by something that at most companies would be considered a serious offense, where private personal information was leaked without my consent, I was basically told that “this is the way it is and there’s nothing we can do about it.” I felt so alone, and cried for days, and felt like all of PayPal’s messaging about diversity and inclusion and caring about minorities was all talk and no action.

All of this made it very difficult as a manager to keep our talented engineers at the company, and to have optimism when telling new candidates about the role.

headline: A great company ruined by lower level management
pros:
- Health benefits, insurance is very comprehensive
-Company cares for you, in the midst of the pandemic no firings reported for saving on costs
-Good place for a fresher
-Great initiatives such as RSUs for employees across levels
cons:
-Management in Risk Operations looks at you like a machine that is expected to churn out case items at a fixed rate every hour, i.e., you can finish double your daily case count in half the time but will still be expected to be at your desk. 
- Entire department was asked to take toilet breaks using a break code on the system at one point. They clearly don't see you as human.
- Nepotism quite evident, a manager was asked to resign instead of being fired even after being found out by HR.
-Promotions process is convoluted and opaque.

- Decisions are pretty top-down.

headline: Great Company for Growth
pros:
- Own projects and provide creative input. Able to have direct impact on company's key initiatives
- Friendly team members. Always ready to share advice. Very helpful for an entry level employee with no payments background
- Manager and I set up clear long and short term goals for success in my role. Transparent conversations on improvement and direction
- Leadership advice readily available. Exponential growth on my soft skills (communication, decision-making) from their mentorship 
- Clear communication on company COVID-19 response. Very generous benefits during pandemic (office equipment, stock options, bonuses). Employees well-being is a priority
cons: - Multiple re-organizations. Sometimes unclear on reasoning

headline: Working at PayPal
pros:
It would not be surprising to say PayPal is my second home. I have been working here for 10 months in San Jose and I would not have thought of a better workplace than here.
I have been put into challenges at times and I have been able to overcome it with the help of my team mates. 
So, overall it’s been a real pleasure working for PayPal and cheers to many more years to come!!

#PayPal #PayPalUniversity

headline: manipulative, pretentious, arrogant leadership, cutthroat environment
pros:
Looks like the leadership is trying to pay more attention to innovation, although there are some growing pains of transition from traditional banking culture to tech culture.

Before COVID-19 period, the work life balance was decent, like an old school place good for retirement/family oriented employee.

If you are in a team don’t need to support business clients/operations directly, but just do research/develop products or model in production, you could experience more flexibilities and less politics than in my team. 

The new hire orientation was considerate and warm, I enjoyed a short honeymoon period after I joined.
cons:
My department has very high turn over rate, to guarantee their own positions, senior director/director/manager level were in a hurry to cover up issues to higher level leadership: 

(1)	Due to lack of necessary technical skills to handle tech team appropriately, insecure junior manager with banking background assigned challenging tasks to incompetent candidates and assign low-profile/labor tasks to competent candidates as a way to balance the power and keep control.

(2)	Due to frequent re-org, senior director/director/manager were afraid of themselves putting on the chopping board, they all secretly allocated some resources on seemingly fancy but not so practical prototype research/machine learning project to showcase to their leaders, and shifted low profile, repetitive job such as data cleaning to people under them. 

(3)	It’s like on a wobbling crashing plane while managers preparing parachutes for themselves because they have access to upper management’s vision change but try to keep you in the dark with nice words. 

(4)	Everyone was trying to avoid the hard work of diving deep into data. Many built their models by taking shortcut borrowing the data extracted & put in production by some poor superman(usually new hires who is in dark). Some senior staff told me, business clients and senior management only care about “you tell a good story(of model) in front of them”. Rewarding system was broken so people took advantage of it. 

(5)	Senior director treat engineers just as ”numbers” without enough respect, this mentality made the situation worse during COVID-19 period because most my teammates with engineering background belong to one ethnic group 

(6)	Play mind games with gas-lighting ability, skills, personality…or create an event/circle and leave you out to subtly hint you don’t belong, or spreading rumours among teammates or business clients to shift blames to scapegoat. 

(7)	Some manager was both pretentious and insecure, putting on the mask of innocent hard working, outgoing, knowledgeable in front of leaders/clients but turned into a type-A tyranny manner in front of subordinates. If you dare to voice opposition, she would assert authority by 
- play mind games in (6) to intimidate & shut you down
- block your model from passing legal review and enter production
- throw a bus of new unnecessary tasks at you all of a sudden 
- let other teammate take over your project ownership

(8)	Preventively give written performance warnings to employees who they suspect would leave, so that if the employee does resign it wouldn’t contribute to team turnover rate.

headline: Productive, Fun and Flexible work place.
pros:
PayPal takes great care of employees and mainly listens to the need and adapt accordingly. Always open to change, and feedback. Work-life balance is good. It provides competitive pay and good benefits. It has great perks in respect to discounted stock plan(ESPP), 401K, and unlimited paid holidays. Opportunity for advancement is available and everyone is encouraged with ways to map out and mentored along the way. There are ample learning resources available like LinkedIn Learning, Udemy, O’Reilly, and internal tools. 

It feels like one team working at PayPal. People have a vision and passion for their work. Management is very supportive and it's a good place to grow in a career.

It has one of the best Internship Programs for Undergrads and Grads. Interns get to work on exciting and challenging projects all along with the fun and productive activities planned by University Team.
cons:
- No free Lunch
- Long blackout periods for trading company stocks

headline: What it’s like to be a PayPal employee?
pros:
Balanced Work and life, although depends on the team but the overall culture is really, they do care about you, giving you the freedom to take of yourself and your society together. The PP gives initiative is really great where PayPal matches the amount you donate to a noble cause of your choice.
The tech stack and quality of work is up to date with the industry standards and you do get the freedom of trying new things and suggest better solutions.
People are really helping here be it new hire training or any support regarding any internal product. You will definitely find a help slack channel for it. 
Overall as a professional you will grow well here.
The leadership is also very supportive they host Ask Me Anything sessions also encourage questions during the All hands session to hear your voice and concerns and the best part is you can go anonymous.
cons: As with everything there are cons as well. This is a part of our industry it seems, layoffs happen here as well, as the atmosphere is competitive, one has to keep learning and growing to be of value for the organization. However, it does help the person itself in overall growth and development.

headline: Best Company to Start Your Career!!! #PayPalUniversity #PayPal
pros:
I joined as a recent college graduate in pandemic, PayPal's values and mission have always inspired the work we do and the impact we create is beyond amazing. As a new joinee, I feel learning curve has been big for me and PayPal has been super supportive to help maintain WFH life balance. Why should you be here ? 
1. If you care that your work positively impacts the world and you want to be in a place that cares about you. 
2. Benefits are amazing ! Wellness days - FTW 
3. Challenging problems to solve; great work domain 
4. No late night staying at work 5. Happy friday hours are for real !
cons: Re-orgs might happen often; but looking at a positive side - this gives you a chance to network across other teams

headline: *** DO NOT RECOMMEND WORKING HERE ***
pros: The only positive coming into work each day was seeing my coworkers and knowing we were going to endure the same hell every day. Yes they offer some good benefits but it's because it is a horrible place to work where you're just a number
cons: I have worked many years of inbound phone customer service jobs and I have NEVER EVER had customers treat the people the way me and my coworkers were treated on a daily basis. I am a Very positive and upbeat person and always try to find the little bit of positive in even the worst of situations but the constant verbal abuse that we had to put up with was unreal. The crazy thing is that PayPal could do something about it ---if someone can't get into their acct or give any of the personal info they should be able to provide we were not able to help them. I think as a company who claims to "care about their employees" they could stop the abuse. You give someone a warning if they do it again then they can only self service via the internet and if they continue being abusive you tell them they are no longer able to have a PP account. I literally had people calling me not only cussing me out but telling me to die and that my family should die and some other horrible terrible things I can not imagine EVER saying to someone I don't know who is trying to help you. I got to the point were I was suffering from severe depression because of the job and decided my mental health and well being was worth more than the money I was making there (which was just ok btw) I definitely would NEVER work for them again in any position. What they expect their employees to put up with and endure is SO unbelievable. There are WAY better corporate jobs out there with upper management that actually care about you and you're treating as a human not just another number.

headline: Run away from this employer
pros: Above average total compensation packages
cons:
Constant reorgs. I experienced 4 org changes and 6 different leaders in less than 2 years. Each one demanding a new plan and new strategy to be developed in the first weeks they took over. 

Everything is a priority and there is no resourcing to match. You take a job here, it's your 24hr a day 7 day a week commitment because "it's a rocket ship". 7am calls with EMEA, 9pm calls with Asia - it's normal to have 14hour days three or four days a week. 

It's a rocket ship for those with millions in stock, not the lower level employees who do the work. it's just a grind with no end in sight. You get one big project done, and there are three more you are behind on that you get called on the carpet for because that leader is upset his/her project wasn't the first one you did. 

Management runs from one fire to the next. It's all about greasing the squeaky wheels. And the politics are sooooo deep here it's crazy.

There is very little thought to longevity of employees, outwardly the CEO talks about the importance of employees, but internally he is driving programs and demanding outcomes that can't be met by the organization staffing levels. So he is stressing out every department, bursting capacity limits, and demanding more and more every week to satisfy the thirst of investors and drive the stock price up.

headline: Not a company for gays or over 40
pros: Great training, nice coworkers and challenging work
cons: If you are over 40, do not expect to go anywhere at PayPal. There is a huge conscious/unconscious bias issue as even if you spent your whole career in a position, they will not even consider you if you are in a protected class. Before applying, they will make comments like "we're just starting the interview process but you can throw your name in the hat if you want". I waited six weeks and finally reached out to the recruiter and she stated "Oh, I'm sorry, we filled the position with someone with more experience". My advice, stay way if you are older or gay.

If you are part of their herd , then you will be blessed by extremely well RSUs and awards.

- too much too-down leadership. For instance, senior leaders define large initiatives with deadlines that just aren’t realistic. Senior leaders also seem to have a lot of turf wars around ownership
 - too many reorganization’s (and layoffs). Many teams have been through three or more reorganization’s over the past 12 months. The head reorganization’s result in a job reductions and cause a significant amount of instability for employee’s jobs
 - too many teams in San Jose are non-diverse. We have huge blocks of the organization that are only Indians. Why aren’t there more minorities and non-Asians on these teams?

headline: Forward-thinking, leadership is listening and wellness responsive

cons:
Clarity in prioritization at 1st/2nd level management is a WIP. Recent re-orgs at the highest levels are still trickling down. This leads to ambiguity and uncertainty in some areas.
Workforce reduction is preferring employees in lower-cost areas (including off-shore).
Preference for "co-location" despite support for remote work during COVID. Great opportunity for those living close to an office...not-so-much for those living elsewhere.
Career development is supported with resources, but not much support to pursue growth unless you know the right resources internally. (i.e. hiring managers)

headline: Such a bummer. The business is doing very well, but I'd rather have fun on a sinking ship than be unhappy on a yacht.
pros:
- The opportunity to learn about the fintech industry as well as practical system design and architecture.
- The opportunity to work on widely used products and services.
- There are loads of interesting Slack channels and groups to join around crypto, blockchain, quantum computing, cooking, you name it.
cons:
Background: I have been here < 6 months and joined remotely during the pandemic when offices are not a thing. I'm so unhappy and disappointed.

I've never started a job and have it not go well—this is new to me. Moreover, the ways that this job is not going well is surprising. My work/life balance is fine, the pay is fine, and the benefits are fine. It's literally everything else that's awful.

Onboarding and my team are the two biggest negative experiences. 

I feel like I'm burdening all of my teammates and especially my manager. I repeatedly cannot get the support I need and this has discouraged me from seeking help. The help I do get is a "oh, you have to use this tool." So I get referred to this tool like it's something I should know how to use when, in reality, it is a tool that was built internally at PayPal and I, as a new hire, have a 0% chance of knowing how to use. 

In general I'm drowning in a pool of abbreviations, foreign terms, and a lack of context. Documentation is scattered in confluence and mostly outdated. Reading source code is a good way to learn, but it's unfortunately the only way to learn at PayPal. When I ask for more help I'm either ignored or I another suggestion made without enough context.

Communication in general is poor. My team is mind-blind when it comes to onboarding a new hire. They seem to not understand that I don't yet know how things are done at PayPal and they can't remember how to set up a new developer for success. Finally, there is 0 enthusiasm on my team. Nobody loves what they do and that is tragic. This is also a byproduct of lackluster management. I've tried to cultivate team spirit, but I feel stupid for doing so when it is met with nothing.

Working at PayPal feels like eating by myself in a massive food court. I think there are teams out there that are fun and productive, but my team is the opposite. I'm just a newbie floating around waiting to be terminated. PayPal feels like a corporate blob and I have zero personal connections with my team. I feel as if I am burdening them and as well as my manager. I feel bad that I'm not instantaneously up-to-speed. 

Finally, a re-org eliminated a team member out of the blue and it gives me no security as I feel like my team doesn't like me because I'm new and stupid.

The business is doing well, but I'd rather have fun on a sinking ship than be unhappy on a yacht.

headline: Great Work-Life Balance
pros: Great work life balance so far! I'm not rushed to finish what i'm working on. My team seems to be more focused on quality and building with the idea that this is going to be scaled or expanded upon in the future, versus just pushing out new features or new products.
cons:
Pay is lower than FAANG. 

To put it into perspective a bit, in my opinion the only thing you might have trouble with is, if you are in the bay area, Seattle or somewhere with comparable cost of living and want to buy a house. If you are renting or live somewhere else I think you should be fine. I still think you could buy a house in these areas but it will take a decent amount of saving. I would guesstimate for myself 3 - 5 years for a down payment of between 10% and 20%, on a house in the $1 million range. Living decently comfortable. 

Take this with a huge grain of salt though this is at the software engineer 2 pay range and is a rough estimate for myself.

headline: Good work, Poor pay, Very political
pros:
1. You get to work on good problem statements. PayPal has high amount of data that makes things interesting.
2. They have a great internship program.
cons:
1. There is a huge pay disparity between the orgs. You can be paid 40% more outside of PayPal for the same work. 
2. The organization is very political. 
3. Too many acquisitions, lead to too many issues at Sr. Drirector and above level which can trickle down and impact entire org structure. 
4. Year end appraisals are unfair (This could be very subjective hence my last point)

headline: Good place to hone skills, but not a long term place to be.
pros:
Many opportunities to learn new technologies via classes/presentation.
Provides company wide events for majour holidays.

Flexible PTO (in USA)

Good benefits
cons:
Projects are too political, with groups more concerned about keeping/expanding their team than making the company a better place.

Racism occurs in small batches within the minority groups.
e.g. Indians hiring only Indians (even at the level of their own state/neighborhood).

Managers blatantly steal ideas to boost themselves or their favorites.

Work/Life balance is a hit or miss.

No sense of working on anything that contributes to the well being of society.

Teams don't really provide career growth after a few years, forcing you to move around.

headline: Get in the clique
pros: The pay was pretty great for a starting developer. Also stock options.
cons:
Everything else was absolutely terrible. Cliques form and if your not in the clique then come "calibration" month, expect to be dinged for the most asinine things. Watched 2 people get fired because they were in the longue room and were 5 minutes late to a meeting... A meeting even the manager came in late to... cause he was in the lounge...and that's how he knew those two people were there. Yeah. The entire establishment is "rules for thee, not for me".

Got out as soon as I saw what was going on to my coworkers and never looked back. Read up on stacked ranking and calibrations. PayPal VERY AGGRESSIVELY pits their own employees against each other and the managers sit back and joke about it. They think its funny and game.

headline: PayPal is one of the best product companies to work in India
pros:
- Excellent compensation (especially when compared to a servcied company)
- Opportunity to move internally between departments after a minimal serving period in one department (2-3 years depending on the department)
- (Apart from Covid times) Absolutely free office bus (Air Conditioned + WiFi enabled) from different parts of Chennai + free cab services from Alandur (spefiic timing) to/fro
- Mandatory year end gifts (sometimes includes gadgets)+ sweets
- Hard work is always appreciated (sometimes cash benefits included)
cons: - Usual politics that exists in every other organization. But that's manageable if one finds a way

headline: PayPal Account Manager
pros: Dan Shulman was the best hire in company history. A good place to work if you are comfortable with rapid change and 180 change. Invaluable experience in the Payments world.
cons: If you get a manager that does not understand what you are doing or why, your job will be hell. Virtually all of the frustration at the job has to do with internal factors, not external. Rapid changing of departmental goals (every month for 9 months in one department...no joke). Process for a process. completely over-processed and not cohesive with other divisions and countries. Many people were forced to seek mental health professionals due to the level of stress. A total change from client support to straight sales and the quotas that went along with it. Who will actually solve the client's problems? And there are many problems with the various product lines with functionality.

headline: All fluff but no love for dedicated workers...
pros:
(This is a review for PayPal after acquiring Hyperwallet)

Pros (a few of which are partially thanks to Hyperwallet pre-acquisition):
- An existent workplace social life with various events happening throughout the year, for those who are into that.
- Stocked kitchen with snacks and beverages, occasionally getting treated to catered meals for special events or meetings.
- Happy Hour on Fridays (free beer and wine).
- Nice, modern office space.
- Lots of great people to work with, learn from, and socialize with, locally and abroad.
- Lots of fantastic management that do whatever they can to help you develop, but unfortunately don’t have much power in the administrative side of things.
cons:
Cons (largely appearing after PayPal’s acquisition and somewhat pertaining to a certain department):

- Certain departments had varied benefits and were structured differently upon acquisition (such as some going hourly, not receiving stocks, while others were on salary and stocks were granted). It produced a feeling of unfairness as the departments in question were very, VERY small and quite cohesive prior to the acquisition, even with salary and task differences. Understandable that PayPal had to align the positions to their own departments, but it felt like the local departments just split off and became almost foreign to each other, in a very negative way, not only compensation-wise, but even socially. 
- Employees in certain pay grades (not necessarily C-level but just employees in different departments) appeared to be treated quite well, while employees at lower-level pay grades were always given the short-end of the stick (less benefits, minuscule bonuses, etc.), even with years of loyalty and hard work. Never seen such a disparity in treating coworkers at any other company in terms of benefits.
- Competitive culture with what felt like a lot of elitism between certain individuals and teams once the acquisition happened. The acquisition seemed to put a lot of people up on a “high horse” which was laughable to see. Lots of petty drama too. 
- PayPal likes fluffing themselves up on all the good they do and the record profits they make, and though they may do good, they don’t necessarily translate this to their employees in terms of wages and job security. They could do much, much more for their employees, particularly at the lower levels.
- Further on the outsourcing: after acquisition, teams overseas were trained on local work and although job security was reassured, that promise was not held up... you can see where that leads to. Plenty of false promises that your job will be secure which turned out to be a lie. 
- Salaries and hourly wages were laughable in some departments compared to similar positions at other companies. It was easy to understand why people left one-by-one after the acquisition.
- Raises were meagre and non-negotiable despite record profits and despite you working yourself to the bone... so there’s really no incentive to work hard as you’ll get compensated in peanuts anyways.
- Higher-ups abroad have an eat-breathe-work attitude, with little to no work-life balance that felt like it was pushed onto lower-level employees at certain points.
- Quantity over quality was key and encouraged... which led to an enormous amount of time wasted fixing stupid mistakes made when rushing the work. 
- Little opportunity to move around or up in Vancouver unless you move to the US or overseas. Was a lot different with Hyperwallet where there were opportunities to learn new skills and take on new positions with no prior experience. 
- Just another giant tech corporation. Free snacks and t-shirts are nice, but I’d rather skip that and get compensated and treated fairly.
- Dan Schulman seems to have good interests at heart but it feels like it gets severely bumbled somewhere down the corporate ladder.

headline: Toxic culture in some teams that demotivates new employees to excel in their jobs
cons:
Following data points are specific to my experience and doesn't necessarily mean all teams suffer from the same. This feedback is specifically for Data Infrastructure team.
(1) People who have worked in the company for many many years don't share any knowledge or information to new staff. Extremely political. They feel their jobs at risk if they share any knowledge / subject matter which makes the environment highly toxic. I had to go run around people for permissions/ approvals, information shared is highly cryptic and misleading.
(2) Managers here lack leadership skills. They don't have a vision and are never sure of their roadmaps. They prefer to be people managers for HR purposes. I had to go to skip level to get help but even they were of no help.
(3) Chennai mafia - Yes, the office in Southern India is full of highly toxic personalities, scheming, misleading, extremely manipulating. They have subject knowledge but they are absolutely difficult people to work with. It's a shame that most of the Engineering resources are situated there.
(4) Insane and inhuman scheduling of meetings in late nights for visionless, directionless endeavors. Following Agile for a meaningless projects, blame games make your life stressful. I had to attend at least 10 meetings a day from 8 am to 11 pm. What a culture!

headline: Among the best companies to work for in Chennai
pros: In some teams, the work-life balance is great. People are usually nice, company takes care of you so well, gives you all the facilities you need to do your work. Their breakout rooms are great. I used to love playing foosball after work is done. There are people of all languages from all regions of India, with over 800 people working in the Futura office. Depending on the team, the pros may or may not be there.
cons:
Salary isn't on par with industry (startups and top tier tech firms). 
More of a business process driven firm than a technology firm. So your learning as a software developer is limited. 
Very slow in moving towards the future. 
It's the company you decide to settle at, not the company you grow yourself at. 
People around you are mostly settled 30 somethings who prioritize personal lives over professional growth. So keeping your drive would be difficult. 
Some teams are great, but getting into these teams may not be straight forward.
Huge disparity in pay between university hires of Tier-1 and Tier-2 colleges.

headline: Omaha PayPal
pros: Stock, Work from Home freedom, future thinking technology, part of a global reaching company
cons: Omaha long term employees are toxic. If a manager is hiring for new position, unless you have a history with that manager forget getting the position even if you are more qualified. Long term employees stick together because anyone new to the company is a threat. Once PayPal became publicly traded, revenue is important.

headline: An amazing period in my career but slowly losing it’s fin tech culture and vibe
pros:
I worked in the UK office for 6 years and look back at my time very fondly. The company enjoyed massive growth and the leadership, culture and vibe in the UK office was second to none over the first 4 years of my time.

-A great core product and many other good services added through Acquisition
-Analysts and many people in the market continue to predict PayPal’s downfall at the hands of competitors, which appears wrong consistently. The company continues to produce amazing performance 
-The share and bonus scheme is the most generous I’ve seen. Staff who do well over a few year a rewarded very well via slow maturing PayPal stock. 
-Company does strive to put customers first in most areas
cons:
-almost nothing negative to say for the first few years
-the company has been constantly re-structuring and centralising more and more decision making out of California. The aim of doing so is sound but it’s simply not worked and made the regional offices in Europe far less effective. Ultimately PayPal has become like any other big US corporate, obsessed by KPIs, sales pipelines and maintaining control. most of the long serving European leadership has left and the brain drain is still continuing now.
-some senior leaders in Europe were dispatched from the business in quite a nasty way in cases.
-Some leadership in US often have limited understanding of the payment landscape in Europe, leading to flawed commercial and product strategies- which staff on the ground are more powerless to influence than before
-limited technical roles in Europe leading to eventual career plateau unless you’re happy to move to the US.

headline: Good company for mid-late career
pros:
Excellent WLB for most, Wellbeing is actually one of our core values.
Opportunity to collaborate across multiple teams but everyone belongs to a relatively small team.
Teams have been trying to be more agile and forming hybrid teams.
Recently upgraded several collaboration tools (Teams, Slack, Jira since 2019)
Excellent benefits overall.
Great company for parents with small children, as the company culture is very flexible with time.
SJ campus have nice common areas to hangout, and 2 awesome cafes, my favorite is Indian food in Cafe 17, they have a proper clay oven!
cons:
Culture is still heavily based on face to face interaction, and often its difficult to work done remotely. (Though the Covid19 situation is forcing people to adapt.
Engineering teams gets things done, but processes are somewhat sloppy.
Some engineers who have been here a while are grumpy, stubborn, resistant to change.
Performance review and feedback execution is not good, though there is good process and programs (Step Up) are in place.
Managers in my org are too involved in project management rather than developing their teams. Some have too many direct reports (10+).
Frequent reorgs have created some level on panic in workers, especially those with work visas in US.
Communication with overseas teams can be challenging sometimes because of timezone difference.

headline: Corporate environment has really gone downhill.
pros: Pay for Tech positions is good. There are some great people scattered in various groups.
cons: The Information Security group is very cut-throat and not a fun environment to work in. It is full of unnecessary fire drills and inconsistent, temperamental leadership. Roughly half of the 2nd line InfoSec group, from CISO on down, do not care about their employees in the least. Managers will smile and lie to your face then do the opposite. Very unprofessional managers will openly mock former employees and expect you to laugh along at their horrible jokes lest ye be next. Last year they shrunk cubes and banned personal items on desks. Personal items must be kept in a bank of lockers so that it is easier to walk people out as they are terminated. InfoSec has constant "reorgs" to get rid of employees(Often more than once a year). Management complains that they can't find good employees, but the reality is, they probably should be taking a long look at their own management styles instead.

The leadership team really cares about the employees, they care about the customers. They truly value their people.
cons: Promotions were difficult. Consistently rated in the top 2 tiers (when there were 5) and in or near the top tier (when it was reduced to 3). Just could never get that promotion. Was pacified with huge raises and bonuses, however.

headline: If you're not part of PayPal proper forget it
pros:
Vast Resources
Excellent Pay / Benefits
cons:
If you're not part of the core operation you're likely in for a rough ride. While their onboarding for acquired companies seemed streamline and the rhetoric talks about how they embrace you as part of the "family" you're really not. You'll be held at arms length, eyed suspiciously and if anything at all goes sideways you're jettisoned as a dead weight.
0/10 - would not be acquired again.

headline: Hire and Fire Company, prospective employees stay away
pros: Only good thing is compensation (Salary and Stock options)
cons:
I don't know where to start because I have a huge list, but let me put up something.
1. No innovation takes place in our company. We only copy what competitors are doing.
2. There is an org re-structure every two months. We don't allow out employees to settle down and focus on work. We want them to be worried about their jobs, so their productivity is low
3. We don't have work-life balance. We slog, slog, slog and then get laid off.
4. Our leaders lack transparency,  leadership and compassion. They are robots who think the employees are emotionless machines.
5. If your tongue can do the talking, you can survive here. Knowledge, hardwork, attitude does not count.
6. Managers here are the worst species. Most have come from services companies and run this company as a service company. They treat us like slaves. I know of a director who used to prepare charts and paste them all over to walls when her bosses would visit Chennai to please them. 
7. Managers are not bothered about our career progression.  They are like leeches who suck our blood. And once they have sucked all the blood out, they leave us to fend off for our self or be laid off.
8. We do not get time or the opportunity to sharpen our skills. We need to do the work equivalent to two employees in the US.
To summarize, PayPal is one of the worst companies to work for. Its not worth the compensation, at the cost of your health and well-being and wellness.

headline: From bad to worst
pros:
Globally recognised company, good company values and strong value prop in market, the company holds fun social events from time to time. 
Great sabbatical program to loyal employees who can stick around for 5 years.
Discounted gym membership and great health cover with on site massage available, flexible working conditions (but this can be very dependent on your direct manager and which team you are in.)
cons:
Free Wednesday lunch is no more, broken processes with no clear guidance for employees to follow, moving towards more of a corporate banking culture with above average incentive program. (Could do with a revamp)
Lack of support and training has lead to employee turnover and team mates feeling overstretched mentally due to a lot of changes recently.

headline: Gross mismanagement in the India office
pros:
1) Strong brand name
2) Decent Salary
cons: Despite claims to the contrary, the India office is seen (within the company) and run like a pure back-office bodyshop with little focus on innovation or differentiation. This reflects in the sub-standard quality of most leaders hired in India as they openly engage in sycophancy, favoritism in comparison to creating real value.  One would be better off joining an Infosys, TCS, Cognizant as they are atleast very open with their process/back-office orientation. People interested in working in an innovative product-based company should avoid avoid this one or you are setting yourself up for disappointment and career disruption.

headline: Great perks, amazing people, changing times
pros: PayPal salaries tend to be higher compared other companies coupled with many perks: discounted lunches, many socializing/team building events, flexible schedules, very supportive of work-life balance including options to work from home a day or two a week (or more depending on role). Aside from the perks, the people really made the day-to-day the joy of coming to the office.  Work was always challenging and made you think out of the box. The company as a whole is very conscious of its role and its influence and sees itself as a leader when it comes to social/community/environmental issues/events.  There's a lot to like once you get your foot in door.
cons:
- periodic layoffs
- depending on which dept you end up in there may be a discrepancy in quality of leadership and transparency.

In Bangalore, you will lot of manager will go to US and book nice hotels and stay over there and visit to multiple cities by company budget and don't allow developer to go to San Jose or even any training or event.Whenever you approach for these thing then they will say "We have budget constraint".
Don't trust if they show We are in  Top Best Place to Work in India.If you looks stats on Glassdoor or Forbes it don't stand in top 100 also.So please don't trust if they show you or tell you that we are Top Best Place to Work in India.

headline: Your Team Matters !!
pros:
* You get a lot of Extra activities to participate.
* Good employee benefits like Stocks
* Some really good techies
cons:
* Your team matters. I'm a full-stack developer with java background. But I was made to work in C++ code and they allocated QE Task and automation for a few months.
* I really hate the way AWF's(Alternative WorkForce) are treated here. I'm an FTE ( Full Time Employee) and any team outings including company-sponsored team lunch AWF was avoided. Director will behave like as if they don't exist
* PayPal should get rid of this Hire and Fire culture. You will get to see a developer with some technology stack getting fired and they will recruit a new guy with the same technology stack
* People don't get noted for the work they do. They get noted only for the marketing they do.
* You can see many people who blame others for the failures.
* Again the team matters, in the team I work there is no proper road map, senior architects fight among themselves to decide things.No one works for one good product here. Everyone wants to do something to keep them alive

headline: Great Benefits, Horrible Execution
pros:
Company culture is very accepting and open. As long as you try to achieve success (and aren't lazy), your supervisors will be accepting of any struggles you come across.

Benefits package is by far the best in the industry, and very likely the entire state. With additional perks like quarterly performance cash bonuses and yearly stock bonuses the compensation issued is quite good.
cons: For a customer service role you'll be forced to either become apathetic towards the customers or become a customer advocate and try to fight byzantine bureaucracy. Too much of my day is spent getting yelled at for not fixing an easy problem because "that's how the system works."

headline: Good potential, spoilt by poor engagement and no career development path or appraisal process
pros: Culture allows flexible working hours, people are overall nice and individually, valuable
cons: There is absolutely neither career development path nor appraisal process in place! You start your year and you don’t know what your KPIs / goals are, or what will justify your performance review outcome. People who underperform keep staying in the company, together with those who over perform but in the long run become unsatisfied and unmotivated because there is no reward or chance to grow.

headline: Better than most; choose the right team
pros:
- Some areas have interesting problems

- Few companies have larger scale

- Nice campus -- ongoing renovations will make it even better

- Interesting 33% RSU vesting schedule/year

- Very good 401k match of 4%
cons:
- Food is atrocious and expensive. Run by Sodexo. Coffee bar runs out of drinks often.

- Comp can be quite a bit lower than other tech companies

- Financial roots make development work slow

- Facilities team not up to par - broken TVs in conference rooms, nonfunctional phones, unpainted patches on the walls, elevators are way too slow, etc.

- Benefits are falling behind comparable companies. Not enough EV chargers (and you have to pay for them), not enough parking, some health plans are 2x the price of other companies, RSU vesting is still yearly

headline: The company is fabulous and provide lot of facility to the employee.
pros: If you are under a good boss then you will be able to enjoy a lot of flexibility such as work from home and other stuffs. They have a medical policy for spouse and family and free transport.
cons: The management specially in the Risk and Control Department in Bangalore believes in too much of micro management which is completely unnecessary,If they do not like any employee they have the complete power to throw people out of the company.The managment believes in hire and fire policy. There is no job security if you are working in those department. Even in the past few months lot of employees are fired which is really sad and unfortunate.The probation period specially for the employee above grade 22 is 6 months and they presurrize you on a daily basis  and remind you everyday that you are on Probation. There is always a sense of fear while working here.

headline: Job in security
pros: 27 days paid leaves, no dress code, cab facility and free packaged fruit juice and banana in a day n also some nuts.
cons:
One will always have a pressure to perform, as quality 80%, AHT  and Action rate has to be maintained throughout. And the initial mistakes done while learning might impact your YTD performance and if you take any unplanned leave , a mail with all the points will be in your inbox... You will be kept in PIP for 30 days and if still u don't perform till 80% then u r out.
Every company needs benchmark to measure performance and to set a target..But this company sets unrealistic targets and keeps employees under pressure. Although we get 1.5 hr break each day, but for rest 7.5 hours ,cases keep on coming back to back with AHT in seconds and one needs to think even before going to wash room... I will never recommend anyone here.

headline: In a midst of a Reorganization & Business transformation - Growing Pangs
pros:
- Good culture on diversity inclusion  and living company values and demonstrated by CEO
- Strong focus on Risk, Security and Compliance. About 30% of staff is hired to perform such roles.
- Work/Life Balance : PayPal gives a 1 month sabbatical for every 5 years of service
- Nice office environment and depending on location free lunch and ample stock of a variety of drinks and beverages
- PayPal brand well recognized in core markets like USA, Europe and Cross border commerce markets in APAC. 
- Cash rick company that invests in fintech startups and acquisitions over the last decade. Acquisitions include: iZettle, Simility, Hyperwallet and Braintree.
cons:
- Business reorganization in process. Workforce reduction due to redundancies or change in org structure led to people leaving the company due to attrition or redundancy.
- Marketing teams from various products were merged with the new CMO joining PayPal. 
- This followed with Worldwide Sales team reorg where PayPal sales team have been merged with Braintree sales team for Mid and Large enterprise business. This started in USA last year and have been expanded this year to the International markets. This has caused lots of uncertainty to employees
- Product strategy is to have a single PayPal platform with other services like Braintree, iZettle, Hyperwallet, Simility as part of the platform. The various product team have been merged back to the PayPal product team group. Integration is still in progress and question is whether products like Braintree  will still exist post integration.
- Investment by the company is on the top clients in the USA, less focus on growing the international markets. The competition like Adyen and Stripe are heavily investing in other international markets via increase local acquiring and local/regional payment methods. This will make PayPal less competitive in meeting merchant needs internationally and drive merchants to other providers.
- Underwriting and Pricing teams sits in the USA and have no local context of the business to work with Sales to price deals to win the merchant.
- Management is telling employees that the strategy is clear and the right thing to do but have no definite details to share on the execution  especially on the people front. People are concerned where they will be any impact in their roles with this transformation.

headline: Great benefits
pros: Great benefits (401k Match, dental, vision, health, on-site free mental wellness, $5,250 tuition reimbursement which is matched by Bellevue university for a total of +$10,000 per year), everyone is insanely nice at work including management, game room, onsite free gym, onsite great cafeteria, PTO and paid sick, affinity groups for just about everything you can imagine, employee and family events, fast track to train you for other roles... at least for me. I get to dress casual within reason... yay, flip flops! And quarterly bonuses driven by metrics such as transfer rate, average handle time, recontact rate, and customer satisfaction pulled from surveys.  Started in April and got a +$700 bonus my first quarter.
cons: Honestly the only downfall is the customers sometimes. When dealing with money, people get upset. The beginning segment (SSP, or “settings, security and payments”) is rough just because you’re having to explain what an echeck is and why it takes so long to process, or that a transaction will not go through due to the security system blocking it. People can get angry, but that’s to be expected I guess. Just can be emotionally taxing.  Gotta do well on your metrics or you can get in trouble. Never happened to me and it seems pretty easy to keep metrics up. Those who don’t are coached on how to get them up and the coaching is very helpful and not like being scolded etc. so I guess maybe that’s not a con after all lol.

headline: Below Average company
pros:
1. Free cabs.
Nothing else. nothing else. 5 words complete.
cons:
1. Bangalore facility & management team is the worst. The cafeteria vendor is completely waste & corrupt. Bangalore management does not take employee feedback seriously.
2. Food is bad & comparatively costly. I saw them reducing the quantity every day.
3. Work was ok.
4. Bangalore management is not aligned with 'Wellness' value of PayPal, people talk about it but no one cares about it. Food is the biggest proof of it. Unhealthy food served with pride.
5. Secluded office location.
6. Politics in team.
7. No free snacks, even they put only very limited quantity( around 20 pieces for 200 people ) banana, butter milk everyday, once finished, you can't get more.
8. Extreme level of cost cutting, cheapness around in the Bangalore office.
9. Overall, it's not a great company, just works like a bigger start up with extremely low quality engineering & management. Hiring bar is very low in almost all teams.

cons: Too much into political correctness. Recently had inclusion training which devolved into an unpleasant/intimidating group discussion about white privilege - very harsh comments about older white men - encouraged by moderator. Inclusion is really defined as "we include all those that agree with us" (conservative positions and politics are openly and routinely mocked by teammates.) Bonuses changed from quarterly to yearly reducing incentive. Quickly becoming like any other call center.

headline: Review
pros: Only salary. Nothing else.
cons:
PayPal goes big on their values, one which is "Wellness". Once you join PayPal(especially if they force the graveyard shift on you) your life will go haywire. People working in the graveyard shifts do not have proper food in the canteen and decent facilities. Due to "business requirements" there are no activities conducted. Managers are being recruited from small vendor companies, who are trying to bring in the BPO culture. The only answer management has to everything is "Business requirements".  Sudden change in shift? Business requirement. Cannot take a break? Business requirement. Cannot take a scheduled team meeting? Business requirement. 

The only way to get through is by butter the Team Leader and the Group Leader.
