headline: Laid back with no standards
pros:
- Good work/life balance
- Ability to work with new technologies (i.e. React and GraphQL)
- San Jose campus is beautiful, a very pleasant place to walk around and show up to on a daily basis
- Expectations are reasonable (although almost TOO reasonable to the point of being lax)
cons:
- Depending on team, people aren’t always the friendliest
- Lots and lots of bureaucracy and layers of middle management that make it extremely tough to navigate
- Code and engineering standards are essentially non existent. No one cares about the quality of code you write as long as you ship the feature. Yearly reviews have nothing to do with your engineering ability, promotions are often given out to those who have stuck around long enough to make it their “turn”. 
- Internal tools often break and don’t work, staging and development environments are incredibly unstable, and a lot of productivity is lost just waiting for things to work properly.

headline: My work experience in PayPal
pros: People, all the things going on here, all the possibilities.  I met people from around the world. People who share not only PayPal related interests but people who shares really their talents. Every day I learn new things. We have so many options here...like  I love yoga and I can attend mediation classes for free, I have painting classes...you name it. As long as you have time you can just pick another thing and have joy.
cons: I dont really see bad things, I would recommend this work place to anybody.

headline: Truly the best job I have ever had
pros: Honestly, every day that I come into work I am grateful for the opportunity to work for this company. They do so many small and large things for their employees to show how much they care and they truly to want to make sure their employees stick with them for a long time. The benefits are AMAZING (great medical, Stock, 401K AND they even have PET health insurance), the workplace is both fun and sophisticated with great areas to take breaks and a full cafeteria that has AMAZING prices. Large facility next to a lake that you can stroll around on your breaks, plenty of space inside as well in the common areas to spend some time by yourself or with coworkers. Free donuts/bagels every Tuesday, cake once a month for communal birthday celebration. The environment is both diverse and inviting, promoting both consistently. Couldn't ask for better management, they are trained to be understanding while being fair as well.
cons: Better onboarding from HR would have been nice. I didn't even know how to set up my insurance until I asked someone. (It took me a while to come up with any "cons" as there are none that came to mind right away.)

headline: Worst company of my career
pros:
Being a developer I do not see any reason to work with this company ( Bangalore location, Risk domain  ). Bangalore Risk is not a team, it is a political platform which will make you perfect politician. Like Big Boss, game starts the day you join this team. Reason of this I have analysed so far is (1) very less technical work which has worth in Industry (2) Psycho managers ( this is closed group who play to save themselves at any cost). Once you join this team you will realise IIM should stop Executive course for sending incompetent managers to Industry. ** if you are a recruiter please double check IIM Executive courses profiles. Most of managers ( even of some top management ) are fake. They hardly care about PayPal. All they want to see their RSU grow. 

If you really care about your career please don't join Risk Bangalore else like me you will certainly repent one day.
cons:
politics, old technologies, fake managers.

PayPal is in Industry till next max 5 years. Because of change in Payment industry survival of this company  wouldn't be easy.

headline: Pathetic health care partner
pros:
World class tech facilities 
Friendly co-workers
cons:
I was brought in to PayPal as a security consultant in their San Jose office in March 2013. A month later my wife received the news of her pregnancy and I started making all the arrangements for it. Obviously I wanted the best for my wife so I got in touch Human Resources (I do not recollect any names) at PayPal to cover the medical expenses. They informed me about United Healthcare who was responsible for providing medical insurance to the employees. However, when I approached them with an exorbitant bill for non-invasive pre-natal test, they refused straight away by saying my wife was 
underage. The required age was 35. I was appalled by this reason as it made no sense at all. I am not sure who really fooled me, PayPal or United Healthcare.

headline: Tread with caution
pros: Plenty of interesting projects. Company doing well so equity is great investment. Company Mission of democratizing financial services is a priority and customer is put first which is great. Very inclusive culture. Many smart people at the company and every 5 years you earn a month off on sabbatical!
cons: Work life balance is terrible because of my manager signing the team up for way too much. Other teams are better so be careful with what team you accept a job from at PayPal. Despite being a startup cannot move up quickly despite what HR tells you when interviewing. Matrixed and political promotions like at a bigger Fortune 500 company so plan for that and do not accept a level less than your experience level as you will regret it. Do NOT allow HR / recruiters to underhire you because 2-3 years for promotion regardless of work. 1% yearly salary increase is the norm so be prepared to be paid in equity vesting over 3 year periods at 1/3 per year.

headline: great place to work

headline: If you want to screw your life and career.
pros:
High pay (associated with high risk)
Healthy snacks, cool drinks (you can buy them on your own)
Brand image
Some technically sound colleagues
Politics is not too much. But it's there. People tend to take away your work if you are not careful enough.
Many KT sessions, seminars would happen, but you won't get time to participate it.
cons:
Regular Lay-Offs. I joined PayPal by reading all good reviews here. But they laid me off within one year saying silly things. You are likely to be thrown away after project gets over.  HRs spoke to me so nice, made many promises, called me often to get me on board. In the end they escaped. I suspect most reviews are posted by marketing HR themselves.
If you are already settled in a good company, don't join here. You will be screwed.
You will be always loaded heavily. No breathing-time in between projects.
I had worked even on weekends for months. No work life balance. Still your work won't be appreciated.
Pay will be good in papers only. (-) all taxes, it's almost like old salary only.
I don't know how they top 25 as best company to work with. It's false.
If you are joining as a lateral with good experience, it is difficult to survive competing with guys sitting rubbing bench here for years. Since most of the things here are internal. Also if you caught for long term, difficult for next jump.
CEO talks so soft & nice in videos; but in actual, management is very rude, never care for employees.
I overheard two very top management people talking in the library "it's boring to see old face daily - lets fire some, and get fresh faces in". Understand their mentality.
So you can be fired anytime. Severance pay won't be that good if you haven't spent many years in PayPal.
I know the pay will hide your eyes, but based on my experience I am saying, you will regret joining here. Better take some more time and prepare well, and join a better product company. Remember PayPal even fired Elon Musk.

headline: Good Company, Bad Politics
pros:
- Good company. Very open, very collaborative.
- Gives flexibility on thoughts as long as they like it.
cons:
- VERY BAD politics. It's on every org. You are warned if you are going into this company, make sure you know what you are getting into.
-  They don't really care about your technical ability rather if you are good with your upper management or leadership (AKA if you kiss their #@#) then you're good.
- Managers aren't technically strong. They just have been there for a long time
- Managers don't have a say on the candidates, upper management does even though they don't directly work with the candidates.
- This is the company where you are evaluated on the basis of what your upper management thinks of your work or amount of effort you put in.

headline: Worse place to go
pros: Nice coworkers from several countries
cons:
The salary may seem high depending of your country of origin but don't get fooled it's so low. They trick you saying that every year they do a salary review, they will only add 20€ x month to your salary likely.

They live in a military crazy world, with more than 10hours shifts with only 30 minutes break, lunch time (only 30 min) is not paid and you must work for an extra half an hour.

They monitore your screen and everything you do, you must be like a office monkey basically everyday.

Stressful and poor managment, no room to grow unless you stay at your position years.

Basically a horrible place to work, don't waste your energy.

headline: Good Opportunity to learn
pros:
-I was lucky enough to have mostly kind and helpful teammates and leaders. Each leader had a different style of leading but they did their best to cater to every teammate. 
-The Risk department offers 3 types of queues, and you would learn the basics first then progress to the harder queues
-free coffee/tea/chocolate drinks and snacks
-game room with darts, pool, boards games and carrom
-weekly 1 on 1 session with your boss, which you can also use for yourself if you have no work issue
-quarterly inter-team and department competition
-depending on your teammates and leaders, you can even have weekly huddle games
-my advise is to learn as much as you can from different departments, understand the SOPs and be proactive in your career goals
cons:
-strict 30 minutes break, this includes personal and toilet breaks. Depending on your Team Leader, they may make exceptions if you are over the 30 minutes break allocation, eg diarrhea, lift not working. Sometimes felt dehydrated as did not drink water. 
-as the company progresses, higher management seems to be making changes to SOPs without any proper feedback, which can be illogical, create loss and be demotivating
-company was not transparent about decisions that would significantly affect employees, work-wise and financially

headline: Must be a politician to survive frequent restructuring and layoffs
pros:
RSUs
Growing company (via acquisitions)
Innovative product (via acquisitions)
cons:
Back-office politics is intense and political savvy is a required skill set to survive
Feedback and questions are not welcome - "yes boss" with a smile is the only right answer or you aren't considered collaborative
Leaders  talk about inclusion all the time, yet in the last few years of layoffs, they are clearly eliminating older workers, women and those with assertive communication styles
Executive leadership used to be accessible and engaged with the "workers"  but now it's an ivory tower
Top-heavy - lots of VPs with small teams and many VPs now act like directors
People are now seen as an expense rather than an investment

headline: Feels like an average company turning into a tech giant
pros: The culture at PayPal is, for the most part, really great. The people I work with care deeply about their work, especially in the diversity and inclusion sector. Groups of employees create their own initiatives and get support from the greater PayPal management. I have been impressed with the level of transparency leaders give to their different orgs, and the growing willingness to have difficult conversations.
cons:
The company feels like it's in transition. Internal reorgs happen fairly often as divisions grow and the company figures out how it will be structured moving forward. Leadership is very open to feedback, and they make changes as we move forward. The campus is going under construction constantly, and building are either using an old dated aesthetic or have been remodeled to a fresh new look and feel. 

All of these things combined can lead to a feeling of "incompleteness" or "unsteadiness." That being said, this transition is only temporary, and I am more than willing to be contributing to a growing company who's eager to improve, and excited to be a tech staple.

headline: No Work Life Balance - Lot of internal Politics - Highly not recommended for Recent Graduates
pros:
Good quality of interesting projects to work on
Only recommended to join the company at a higher position: Manager +
cons:
No career development plan for recent graduates
Swamped with ad hoc requests
Expected to work your a** off as if you are paid to lend your life
Unlimited PTOs are just a myth - you will be judged for every paid off you take
Lot of internal politics as too many people competing among each other as you are judged (annual review) Vs your peers across different group not for your own efforts. (One team culture is a myth too)
Every year they have structured layoff under the umbrella of "restructuring" - mostly affect recent college graduates (RCG) who are still trying to establish their foot in this mean corporate world, as the Managers will not want to lose their old loyal horse compared to anyone new like an RCG.

headline: SE3 at PayPal Bangalore
pros: Work from home option is available with flexible work timings
cons:
They have payments team in Bangalore and lot of their code is still in C++, they are hiring java developers in senior level and asking them to do support in c++
Lot of production issues every now and and then and every developer is asked to do support for 1 month in every 4 months
During support you have to be available 12 hours a day from 10 am to 10 pm and as there are lot of issues/bugs developers busy in looking over issues in their huge c++ code base.

Also development work is less and most of the time goes in domain and production support
People talk less on technology and more on domain
Managers promote people who are gaining more and more domain and involved more on support as Managers are also not technology people.
They shifted their Bangalore office to some place with poor road connectivity.
After shifting to new office there was not cafeteria for 8 months.
Expensive food in cafeteria which started recently and PayPal  provide just 1200 per month for food.

headline: Filthy politics, hiring and firing culture
pros: Good work life balance.  Average compensation at very low entry bar.
cons:
Focus on politics. A top heavy company where politics is key for survival.
Every director/senior director has his/her own agendas and no one worries about work. If you are on their side all is well else will you be singled out. 
Frequent reorgs due to domain grabbing and realignments.
Promotion are random. Too much focus on diversity.
Different opinions are not respected  and disagreement with your boss is looked down upon. Yes boss culture. Extreme focus on perception management vs the actual work.

Firing is too frequent and mostly based on people alignment.

headline: Unfair internal project assignment and promotions.

cons: Unfair promotions and internal project assignment. Root cause may be acquisition of an Israeli startup with culture of promoting their own people which created an unacceptable culture which later got follow by Chinese mid-level management too. Mid-level technology (not the best/first among technology/fintech companies)

headline: Good Place for Hard Workers
pros:
1. Flexibility in work, ( You can take work from home, But if u want continuous days for WFH, you should get managers approval)
2. There is no dresscode ( You can even come in shorts and round neck t-shirts)
3. Highly configured devices are given for working (laptops, if u support any application u will be given samsung s9 phone)
4. Food at the Food court is maintained well in terms of quality, Afternoon meals is not good.
5. Transport is provided for all employees even for the contractors, In fact buses are the best i have traveled so far. 
5. Compensation is above par compared to 90% of CMMI level5 companies.
6. If you work hard, you will be rewarded, if you are struggling/taking much time in doing the work, they don't even respect you.
7. Free snacks and cool drinks are available entire day mostly.
cons:
1. They don't help you, you should get the things for you. You should be ready to work in any technology. 
2. The managers expectations are huge
3. Most of the freshers they recruit from popular colleges like (Bits pilani, VIT, NITs), So managers compare you with them.

headline: One of the best brands to work for in Asia Pacific
pros: Awesome corporate culture with supportive leadership and decent work-life balance (comparatively speaking). Annual 360-degree feedback with employee satisfaction surveys being taken very seriously. In the spirit of innovation and customer champion behavior, honest well-intentioned mistakes are not just tolerated, but forgiven in the interest of keeping ideas flowing.
cons: The company tends to get "wrapped up in the details" and can occasionally miss the big picture. This isn't just the senior leadership but also effects every level of line management and operational staff as well. KPIs and goals don't seem well designed and as such each level of the organisation seems to be chasing different targets - this makes meeting or exceeding your targets more complex than it needs to be (albeit still achievable).

headline: Liked the company/mission, hard to avoid the department politics.
pros:
Decent pay 
Employee relief fund for hardship
Ability to work from home in most departments
Month sabbatical offered after every 5 years of employment
cons:
Meeting culture is a productivity killer, “let’s have meetings just to have them”. And if you decline a meeting, expect to have a follow-up meeting scheduled to discuss why. 

If you don’t care to advance your career, this is a good place for you. Even if you have a supportive manager advocating for you, unless your department has a competent HR business partner and not just a roadblock, you can bet HR will either 1) shut the promotion recommendation down immediately 2) attempt to understand the employee’s job function and promotion justification with repeated inquiries for the same information, creating churn and additional work to deter managers from pursuing this process.  Of course there are exceptions - if you’re a savvy politician, you have a chance of being promoted. It was demoralizing to work efficiently “do more with less”, see other people coasting and being rewarded for it.

headline: AMEX Customer Service Hub
pros: Above-average pay when starting out
cons:
Every Team Lead opening in Customer Service teams are typically snapped up by previous AMEX folk. Overlooking the selection process, these are unqualified, inexperienced flukes who talked their way up.

Fresh grads, this is where careers go to die. The learning curve is short, skill level minimal, and growth potential limited. No development opportunity is given to employees, as leaders seem content seeing people struggling to meet KPIs after 7 years. Shame on the HR and recruitment person.

If and only if you’d be content with an above-average starting salary (and minimal increments subsequently) should you even bother.

headline: Great company,  but not for women.
pros: You learn so much about the digital payment industry and all the innovation that the company is leading in the industry. Also, they have great benefits and all the  same environment that you can have at Google for instance, with free food and drinks.  Plus, my colleagues were incredible and it seems to be the case in most departments where people are very friendly and there are lots of social gatherings.
cons: The culture sometimes is questionable. Even though what's written/said is wonderful, it doesn't quite represent the reality. As a woman, there was a lot of sexism, especially because it only has about 30% of female employees - like most Silicon Valley companies, there's a lot of lack of support from management when you raise questions or want to learn more. In my experience, I found that to be extremely difficult, because you  have to change the way you are in order to work with men and be respected and considered in the room. That was the reason I resigned.

headline: APAC Internal Audit - hire and fire culture
pros:
Benefits and welfare good
Every Tuesday free lunch 
Dental can cover spouse using dental card
cons:
1. Hire and fire culture - 4 unfair dismissal in a short period of 2 years, resulting low morale within the team.
2. Constant change of APAC leadership - lack of stability and no clear direction
3. Promotion is not by merit - staff got promoted 3 times in less than 2 years without valid justifications and results from management.
4. High turnover due to poor hiring - APAC has been hiring auditors who doesn’t have relevant experience and competency. The mismatch of skillset has caused the misfit to the company, which results in “hire and fire” culture.

Last word - avoid to join the APAC internal audit unless you are prepare to lose your job in the near future.  The fear of “don’t know” when might be your last day is just too much risk to take.

headline: Great with the limitations of a local business unit far from decision centers
pros:
Great product and brand and getting better and accelerating on many fronts
International atmosphere in the Paris office + the chance to work with many functions across the globe
Salaries are usually very good vs the market and work-life balance is usually decent to good
Typical American tech flat organization: No dress code, no formality, no insistence on hierarchy
Super nice and clever people as a general rule
Very positive corporate culture : Lots of focus on diversity, financial inclusion, charities involvement, work-life balance etc.
Cherry on the cake: The Paris office is located in one of the best areas of the city
cons:
The Paris office is relatively small and there are almost no opportunities to relocate or move to different functions. You'll spend quite some time doing yearly and quarterly career plans and reviews that go nowhere.
The "family" atmosphere has a dark side: If the management team decides you don't belong anymore (sometimes for relatively trivial reasons), you'll be out quickly, whether you like it or not.
One trick pony: Local business units are mostly about sales/biz dev and putting a button on websites and apps. Limited chances to really acquire new skills.
Office politics and drama: All large organizations have it in some way but, especially for a company doing so well, I've always been amazed at the amount of energy that was spent on this and the churn it generated in the teams.

headline: Not as innovating as I thought it would be.
pros:
-Good people, hungry for more knowledge and innovation
-Good company mission
-Work life balance is pretty good, but it varies per team
-Good benefits
-Diverse, global team
-A large suite of classes and trainings for engineers to take to better themselves
cons:
Ho boy, where do I begin?

-Pay is below market rate, and is being squirreled away in favor of stock options which vest over many years. Example: an employee will receive their annual bonus only 3 years after the fact.
-Heavy micromanaging via Agile - tasks are reprioritized almost daily, making the previous day's work a waste of time.
-Stack-based managing style - last customer that the manager or prioritizer talks to has the first priority task, no matter the actual importance of the task
-Rewards/recognitions are purely political; I have seen people get promoted for the sole reason that they need a higher level person in that location. 
-Bad engineering practices in non-customer-facing teams - I have seen horrors like shell scripts that write to file to pass variables to subroutines. This is enterprise-level production code.

headline: Internal Consultant advisor
pros: Career improvement if lucky enough.
cons:
No indipendecy at all

headline: Compliance department is great.
pros: I've been working for PayPal for almost two years now in the compliance department. I've worked as an investigator and I am currently an interim senior investigator (pod leader). They have recently undergone a re-org, getting rid of the people who were only there to get a check. They kept all of their hard working employees and rewarded them by allowing them to be "adults". No more clocking in or out, Tracking Free Vacation (use wisely), you're not heavily monitored or micromanaged. The culture is also great and only getting better. We have a #OneTeam motto. We all work together within our own teams as well as other teams and departments. Out of all of the places I've worked, this has been the best by far.
cons: Most of the Compliance Managers are engaged and have answers. Some managers don't really know what's going on...and it's obvious. When we run into issues that need to be fixed or addressed, some compliance managers fail to follow up or prove that they care to fix problems. Or, they will escalate issues to Group Leaders and nobody will hear anything back. Communication needs some work. Several managers work from home often (especially on Friday's)  which puts a dent in the culture we are trying to create.

headline: Buyer Fraud Prevention Analyst
pros:
-Nice multicultural workforce
-Some opportunities for career growth
-Interesting to get insight into fraud detection 
-Sabbatical paid vacation of 4 weeks is given to all employees that have worked in the company for over 4 years
cons:
-They try to squeeze the most of their employees by adjusting targets every quarter to fit workers performance to a bell curve so that bonus pay out does not exceed the planned amount. As a result the targets are not just challenging, they are close to impossible to achieve unless you try to play the system by not doing your work honestly
-the amount of Big Brother policing is too much - they insist that no situation is referred to as a problem or issue, everything is "an opportunity", also whenever they have created a cult of feedback, calling it "a gift", but unfortunately it is more of a constant criticism that drains the motivation from the employees
-When it comes to promotion, once you are perceived as negative or with another unfavourable label it is impossible to progress, even if some people are really very bright, good workers and have the potential
-sometimes clearly the weaker candidates get chosen for Team Leader positions

It has great culture, with latest technology. You can attend lot of training sessions which makes you upto date. and KT sessions with buffet and beers (never seen a company do tat). It's really chill you can blindly join paypal. As you grow financially, and technically.
cons: Only few onshore team members are difficult to handle. They will think that always their more knowledge than the people are working in chennai. That's fine but not all people. Only few are like that.

headline: Highly stressful. Ridiculous expectations and demoralizing annual salty reviews
pros:
Fast paced. Great learning in a global multi national
Good salary and perks: be under no illusion tho you work for it.
Sabbatical mat leave pension ESPP all great. Perks on site of subsidized canteen and free gym
Teammates (mostly) are hard workers and very committed but are treated like children. They have to log there every move in two tools, targets are counterintuitive.
Great mix and blend of talent
Manically busy most of the time however structure is well established
cons:
Narrow career opportunity. Roles are all quite generic
Politics is deep seated. If you ain’t playing the game you’re out.
Reorg on our reorg each time with major disruption and cold hearted redundancies
Everything is over worked into a big deal causing extra waste of time work
Reports on our reports with challenging if not inaccurate information
Group leaders and above regularly stop top talent moving on to feather their own bed at all levels
No accounting of different personalities and diversity is a word not an action. Only focus is male and female
Work life balance is a joke. No tolerance at leader level to work from home, unless it’s after hours and meeting needs of the business. A good work week is 80 hours. 
Salary reviews each year decrease through “creative” new targets set up for teammates to fail, annual review for exceeding teammates get 2% and people meeting targets get 1%. 
Promotion increase very poor on a good 5% or less. Budget cuts constantly for reviews. In a >5 year period a meets has gone from avg 6% to 1%. Bonus has also been scaled back with payment in shares based on the years performance capped and not paid out or vested for 12 Months.  
Targets are ALWAYS flawed and the focus is only on budget not the people
Management change is constant, illogical and practices favoritism rather then ability
Zero focus on Team Leader development 
Bullying is something I’ve witnessed a fair amount of.

headline: Eugenics Convention
pros: They aspire to what they have read in books.  The people who wrote the books acknowledged years ago they were wrong.  Now they have to trust B2B to fix their problems.
cons: Inexperienced at the highest level.  Patronizing.  Over zealous and deeply critical of the shoulders their paychecks were created on.  Many senior managers  were let go from their prior jobs for being inept and toxic.   Everybody deserves a second chance but given the stress levels I don’t think your letting the best get action in the game. Does PayPal actually know who they hired at very senior levels.  This company tries to sponsor watered down educations to create a new age feudalism.

headline: Great company weighed down by politics
pros:
- Great pay and benefits. Probably one of the best among fintech companies.
- If you are looking for work life balance then PayPal is the company to consider. More balance in your life than work.
cons: Company was great a few years ago but has since become extremely bureaucratic. Leadership at the VP and Sr Director level is mediocre at best. Growth is not based on meritocracy. Engineering and product teams are not properly utilized and many teams have no clue what they should be working on as there is constant change in priorities. Movement between teams is impossible and training opportunities are limited. Every year there is a survey conducted to improve employee morale but nothing ever changes. Processes become even more stringent and continue to impact productivity.

headline: A certain lack of enthusiasm in the Paris office

Breakfast, fruits, all the usual perks.

cons:
There is no motivation at all in the office. 
I do not think there is a strong company culture.
People are bored and leave one after the other, even despite the good salaries.
The turnover is quite high, people look for more exciting opportunities.
And a lot of reshuffling of teams, reorgs. I've had 3 managers in my first 6 months.

headline: When pink glasses coming off...
cons:
When I started, I thought it's a job for life, but gradually I became disillusioned by my initial feelings. Company's motto/slogans are preached (drilled to you) constantly, but in reality exist only on paper. For example "being open honest and direct" is working only when your thoughts are aligned with management/company's ones, I was warned in 1 on 1 session, not to voice my opinion, as it is highlighting deficiencies in companies rules/behaviour. 
Growth available is only horizontal, as vertical promotions are done through "who you know, not what you know" basis (favouritism). One of the few "proper" adequate managers even recommended just to "smile and wave" on everything, get along so called. How can this be an option in innovative company. 
By my nature never backed down or backed off from work, but recently came across such a situation: helping out other team (full time basis) in performing their tasks with training given 1,5 hours of up-skill, while normal agents and people after me receive full blown training of 1-4 weeks, on top of that my metrics were measured as theirs!!! That's fair?!
Even though I receive constant praise from other teammates (through helping in their tasks with my expertise), my direct team leader continue to say that is just part of my duties, however other people receive awards for less significant contribution. Consequence - good specialists are staying at their current tasks and favourites got higher promotion, forcing specialist to look for another options outside this company. 
Yearly review, supposedly confidential, are backfiring on people speaking their mind as well. Vicious circle - of whoever want to make a change and company to prosper is just not listen to. Good company should praise good employees and make them as welcomed as they can, as in return employees could give extra for the company. Not for me at this stage, not here.

headline: I wouldn't recommend.
pros:
Sabbatical, and time off.
However, even though you earned PTO management still gets angry when you take time off.
cons:
You get a base pay plus bonus if you meet metrics.
No one says it, but if you don't meet the metrics of "getting results" or a meets your job is in jeopardy. 
The metrics contradict each other: you have handle time and quality. You cannot service a customer fully and have a good handle time.
Also, if a customer hates the PayPal system but LOVED you and gave you a bad survey... you could lose your job.
Everyday things change.
You come into work and every Monday they change something.
Whenever I come into work on a Monday I assume that I am getting fired.
They hire so many people also that after hearing "PayPal is the best place to work" every day after a year you become the person that seems mean and nasty because it's annoying.

The cafeteria sucks!!
Same food everyday and the employees in the cafe are JERKS!
You come in at 8 and you can't take a break within the first hour of work.
So you're not eating until lunch.
Then at lunch time the cafe is ALWAYS ALWAYS busy and the people behind the registers just seem to be joking around rather than working.
They also tear things down early or are in a switch between breakfast to lunch or lunch to close.

Management is garbage.
I sit next to my supervisor and hear conversations of crap talking EVERY SINGLE DAY.
Rather than management talking to an employee directly it turns into back talking... where the employee will never hear about it.

MANAGEMENT HATES ITS EMPLOYEES.

Oh also, every single thing you do is monitored.
Your screens are recorded 24/7 and they tell you this.
So if you have a question you can't just email your neighbors or leave your desk. 
THEY CAN FIRE YOU AT ANYTIME FOR ANYTHING.
ITS HELL ON EARTH.

headline: A great company to work for...if you put in the time
pros: PayPal is the undisputed leader in online payments and things are constantly changing. As a company that's been established for nearly twenty years, it's still operates as a start-up at heart but suffers from growing pains in various fields. This leads to new opportunities for those who are willing to step out of their comfort zones. For those that want a stable job and don't care too much for new roles, they will fit in as well. There are many lifers working for PayPal in their operation centers. The company is employee focused and is constantly updating their benefits packages to stay at the leading edge for offerings. The company has some flexibility with scheduling which allows for a healthy work/life balance.
cons: Promotional opportunities are based on your past performance ratings, so if you've had a supervisor who rated you unfairly you'll find it difficult to promote. The pay is competitive at the entry levels, but as you promote they lose some of the competitive edge.

headline: This is a call centre, pretended to be a tech company.
pros: Free coffee. Heath insurance. Sabbatical 25 days extra holidays. Free gym (poorly equipped though)
cons:
Long training. Instead of teaching their PDA tools, they engage you in unrelated learning and activities.
They tell you  that salary is 25 k per year but in fact it's paid every 4 weeks which equals  25 k per 13 months instead. The new bonus system presumes your statistics must be 100% otherwise no bonus.
Two clocking system one for your salary another for your stats. 
If you want to go to toilet you have to click on a button and the time you spend there is added to your statistics. Any mistakes made when working on a case added to your statistics. 
No opportunities for verical growth but  if your statistics are right you can go to other department. 
10 hours shifts and only 30, 15 and 15 min breaks. 30 min isn’t paid and you stuck there for 10.5 hours instead.
For PayPal you just a numeric piece of statistic.

headline: Incompetent Management Bring Down Productivity
pros: I have worked for PayPal for sometime now because I really like the company, its mission and vision.  I also like how our CEO, Dan Schulman, leads the company.
cons:
I loved and was proud working at PayPal until recently, when there was a re-org.  I have met some Senior Leaders of the company who are good leaders but others are not, unfortunately.  The ones who are less competent or less productive are creating an unhealthy workplace.
I’d like to highlight some of the negative behaviors/negative culture of the Senior Leaders in my group:

    1. They have intimidated staff members at meetings so much so that they are hesitant to speak out or voice their opinions, thus creating an atmosphere of anxiety and trepidation.
     2. An employee was told by a Sr. Leader that using the restroom during work hours was not permitted.
     3. During Kids at Work Day, a company-wide event, a manager told employees that they had to stay at their desks even workload is permitted.
     4. Sr. Leaders have been known to procrastinate and take a long time to make decisions.  There have been several instances where their indecisiveness led to urgent "fire drills".  They waver about how things should be done and as a result, project deadlines are compromised.  When mistakes are made, they don't want to be held responsible or accountable for them, so the "finger-pointing" starts. Others are blamed for the mistakes they should "own".  Furthermore, this indecisiveness and procrastination has caused a late reporting which increase regulatory risk for the company. 
      5. We recently received an email communication regarding annual performance and 360 Performance Feedback as part of our review.  However, our Sr. Leader mentioned that she will NOT incorporate it into our annual performance review, a blatant disregard for employees feedback/input.  Sr. Leaders say that they welcome our input, but they are not honest with us.  When we offer suggestions, it is not what they want to hear.  It's "their way" or "no way".

headline: Joke of a company since re org
pros: Benefits are great good teammates and some good  team leaders. Nice building short commute for me anyway. That's about it.
cons:
Re org came in this  year. Staff like myself were moved under a different director. New Segments created and staff on low grades in the new orgs suddenly got moved up to higher grades overnight. We actually provide support to these guys and troubleshoot their problem cases. And now they are 4 grades above us. Other staff getting bumped up purely on a decision made by their new director.
On the other hand, when our department asked if we would be included in the upgrade of our grade , the answer was no. Apparently other orgs can do what they like and there is nothing we can do about it.
We are a multi-skilled, highly qualified team being treated like new hires. 
Yearly survey to ask how they are doing as a company, all questions loaded to make sure we don't "unload" as one of our managers called it.
Lies lies lies from senior bosses.

headline: If I wanted you to be miserable, I'd encourage you to work at PayPal
pros: As I understand it, there are no pros left. The large window of hours to work and the days of the week in which to work them have been taken away. The only pro is there's a free gym with free group fitness classes available. Oh, and the guy who works at the deli sandwich station and the one cashier lady are super awesome. Pros are few.
cons: Horrible, demeaning, zero morale, weird feelings in the air, black cloud hanging over, several not good people, egos, hypocrisy, management does NOT have your back, as a matter of fact, several of them view your back as wide open to be stabbed. And this is for no reason. You can be just a person who shows up to work every day and minds your own business, and management will for some reason pick you out. As will certain evil people on the floor. No reason. It's just the culture there. You know how addicts and people with serious character defects and issues somehow find each other? That's PayPal and the horrible individuals that work there. The entire place and the entire experience of working there is one big con. Management encourages snitching, even when none of it is true, and pulls the innocent, unsuspecting person who was snitched on (lied about) into a meeting room and "confronts" them. But they won't say who said it, or what they said, which leaves you defenseless. And they know it. And if you, as the unsuspecting innocent one, dare to defend yourself, management only doubles down on you. It's like the Gulag Archipelago in that place. Something is really wrong there. Management and upper management retaliate against subordinates. Open door policy... non-retaliation policy... non-harrasment policy... these things means to PayPal what religious freedom means to the Pakistani constitution - the words are in the document just for show. And there is nowhere to go unless you want to just become a manager of the department you're in. There's one path, and that's it.

headline: Stingy and Corrupt
pros:
A good place for beginners whether in engineering or data science where you will learn a lot.  Brand name.
Some colleagues are good. Paypal is ideal for those who are in management or want to move to management.
cons: Managers are the worst. Stingy as hell, won't give a yearly raise. Gives promotion with a bare minimum of 6% raise. Managers tend to favor women over men at promotion (this is the current norm at PayPal as a whole). Depending on the ethnicity of the boss,  he/she will favor those who belong to the same ethnicity. Diversity is a joke.  Risk teams are fully either Chinese or Israeli. Few people from other nations who were part of these teams were made (or forced) to leave the company. Too many re-orgs and jobs getting outsourced.  High attrition. Paypal Risk has 1 manager for every 3-4 people, which translates to too much politics.

headline: Politically correct nightmare
pros:
- Benefits
- Working hours (in my field)
cons:
The atmosphere is horrible. If you are not the standard  SJW but have a brain like James Damore you will not like it, or succeed here. You get taught about the wage gap and how women are oppressed in society.... I mean I am almost 40 years old, a woman and call BS on all of that. If you don't buy into it and you voice that opinion you are basically not a fit for the culture and your career will die. I have been working for PayPal for 10 years and it was a great place when I first started but management is too afraid to say what they think and keeps pushing the SJW agenda. People are being promoted because they scream the loudest and not because they work the hardest. Soft skills and improving people's happiness (i was in a supervisory position) is not appreciated. They claim to have a coaching culture but that is there on paper and not lived.
My Advice to new employees:
- you better make sure you laugh at the jokes everyone else laughs as or you'll have an interesting 1on1 with your manager coaching you for not laughing at the appropriate moments.... yes.... this happened.... and i was required to do this to my team which I wasn't going to do. Sorry.

headline: This is a Honest Review About this company.
pros: A paycheck onsite cafeteria covered parking, gym & and a lot of attractive people.
cons:
I wouldn't recommend this company to anyone honestly. They do not keep their word on anything or practice what they preach. We were told we were in one department in training. And when we hit the floor we were basically all departments and were held accountable. PayPal is basically a Hardcore Call center expect to take 80 to 100 calls easily no filter for departments. They will let some people go for doing the same thing someone else is doing. But if they don’t like you you’re the one that’s let go or written up.  I knew people that were well over the attendance threshold but were still working. While others were terminated on the spot because of their attendance.  I had always wanted to work for this company in there Fraud Department or Compliance Department (Which are now nonexistent). They do have a lot of layoffs so you never know if you have a job or not.  I believe at some point this company was great. But in the last year so many Great people left during the time I was there while the hardcore social climbers stayed. If you want to work for a company that pays very little and works you until your mental capacity is about to break this is the company for you. Employees will try to sabotage you because they think that's how they can get ahead. I was lied to over and over the entire time I was there nothing was consistent.  But it’s done that way to brainwash you into working harder and believing that they really care when they don't.  The workload is unbearable and they do not care until they are fined or losing money. They micromanage you without doing it aggressively by 7 meetings a week. There's one team meeting per week, 5 short meetings then a one on one with your manager every week to keep up with you. I would have rather had an hour lunch incorporated every day or an extra mental break. They’re very unprofessional but that's so that you will let your guard down to instill trust them. If you are an adult and want to feel like you are trusted and given benefit of the doubt and like to work independently do not work here.  Not to mention an electronic key to log into your computer that's how much they trust you.  They have laid off two departments that were really great departments (All Back office Positions). But claiming there is still opportunity in the company. The pay is definitely under what they expect from you. We were told we would be in one department doing one job function. On a day to day bases we were taking calls from other subsidiaries , also Site support calls , email calls , dispute calls , fraud calls and collections calls (without getting paid for collections). If you like really intense and very busy hyper environments this is for you. Management walking around all day constant meetings right there on the floor. Management also standing around talking to one another about other employees. I honesty felt really uncomfortable and I had reason to feel so. They let go of all the genuine management and kept the ones that were willing to be corrupted in fear of losing their jobs. And forget about sick time with this company you will be lucky to have PTO for 5 or 6 days. Not much work balance in my opinion unless you want to take it without a check.

 There is always someone on the floor  watching. The walls are glass so there is always someone looking.  Wages are roughly about $15 an hour but there expecting $ 18 worth of work. You are not fired for your stats but you are reminded of them every day aggressively. And the way they are set up you look really bad unless you are in a very low percentage. And wage increases are very minimal not huge in any way. I suggest seriously if you are not willing to give your soul and integrity to this company think twice.  I have talked to people that had mental breakdowns and were let go.  The final act was just jaw dropping all lies no truth what so ever which in any other state they couldn’t have gotten by with lying. If you go into this company trust no one always know that you are judged every second. Everyone is scared when people are fired you ask what happen to this person. I don't know there just not here anymore?  No one should live in fear like that. The stats are basically a monthly report (but its weekly) they have everything on their except for your bathroom breaks but they are monitored separately and definitely a big deal.  They send your stats out to everyone that's so you can feel bad if you’re behind and work harder. Nothing is private it’s all designed to make you work harder for nothing. Stat wise you have 6 other things to meet including a Re-contact rate and a Transfer rate. Yes! You are held accountable if the customer calls back as well as if you have to transfer them to another segment. Plus you couldn’t really assist the client in most cases because PP systems had already implemented the decision (Which I heard that's why the compliance dept. was not needed. So in all essence you were there to take the heat and couldn’t give an answer. But at the same time you were given the negative survey for this which heavily weighed if you made bonus or not? It really was stressful and didn't make a lot of sense. If you are looking for stability I wouldn't bank on this job. If you are an adult and looking for a real job skip this place they cater to mostly the younger population now. To mold them into how they expect PayPal Soldiers to be and to be grateful for working for the company. Bonuses are a joke they are quarterly and very little money. Management do not work at all just schedule one on ones all day and  go to meetings what I said above. And it really makes the environment uncomfortable because you don’t know what’s going to happen next. Which in most cases there is always something but nothing that’s going to advance the employee’s paycheck. I wouldn’t recommend this company to anyone. They do not pay enough for the quality of work and expectations that they want from their employees.  And the micromanagement is stressful and overbearingly scripted. The company feels more like a cult than an actual place to work which made me uncomfortable especially for the money. You will have scripts to read and will sound like a android daily. This company’s reputation is surviving off the people who had integrity that are now leaving either by choice of force. As time goes on you will see that the reviews will rapidly decline. All that remains are the people with no heart no conscious and just trying to survive to keep their job.

headline: Don't drink the Kool-Aid!
pros: Cheap snacks.  Decent benefits.
cons:
Wayyy too many meetings and huddles and "this is the best company" propaganda.  They make a lot of noise to distract people from the low pay, crap hours, and the lack of job security.  You could perform your job exactly as you're supposed to, but if you get bad reviews by customers who are angry at company policies, you can and will be fired.  No job security.   I've seen way too many good employees fired - whose supervisors even said they handled their calls/emails exactly as they were supposed to but shrugged it off as "the numbers are what the higher-ups look at."

Doctor's notes do not excuse absences, so I have seen people fired after car wrecks, bouts with illnesses such as pneumonia, and even early childbirth.

I found another job and got out of there ASAP.

headline: PayPal Debit Card Supervisor perspective
pros: PayPal provides it's employees with a very good set of benefits and building facilities.  The social environment is comfortable and derverse.
cons:
The company's pay is sub par for the industry, and I was only provided one cost of living increase of .25 cents in over four years. 

It was well known that many people would simply come work there for the experience, then leave for other companies who pay better for the same job.  

The company is incredibly disorganized internally. Personally I felt that people in charge of long term planing and communicating these plans were utter failures. With any given change, launch of a product, or even hiring e employees the plans implemented seemed to be 6 months behind. 

In general since the split of PayPal with eBay the company has made a huge turn from putting their customers and employees first to the all mighty dollar.

headline: Technology and Prof Services POV
pros:
Great benefits, if you get on the right team it's a dream job. There is a lot of freedom to pursue projects, certifications, lots of training, and a great outlook for where the business is going. 

Someone somewhere that makes the big decisions realized there were big changes needed, and empowered Product and Technology to make them. It's still a work in progress, but it's certainly getting better as time goes on.
cons:
You have to find the right team.  I know some teams are not a great experience, sadly. 

As with any large company with a LOT of branches, there are communication issues where teams don't always share needed information. 

In some roles (such as management) work/life balance is challenging.  Additionally, the rating system is on a grading curve which absolutely sucks.

Some decisions are held up because of process, and the bug metrics seem to result in ticket closing instead of actually getting to the root of the problem.

Products are focused on particular silos rather than overall experience. 

The longer you work here, the harder it is to get promoted.  This is the most serious downside in my opinion, and is causing good and knowledgeable people to leave for other opportunities.  It seems like in order to get to the level you should be, you have to go outside the company after a few years.

headline: Candid opinion of PayPal
pros:
You would be happy if you are working at the development center in Bangalore.

1) Career growth : There is a huge opportunity to learn and perfect what you do, because you will be working in the same job, at the same designation and salary, in the same function for min 5 years. There is zero growth like a govt. setup.
2) Politics : You can graduate from here and easily join a leading political of India. It is a place for obsequiousness with boot-lic*$ng being rampant.
3) Salaries : You are paid on time but very poorly. Expect a raise only if you are vv good at politics (see point 2).
4) Learning : At PayPal, you will learn about the different emotions you have. The company pays for anger management and meditation courses, after they offend and slander you at regular intervals.
5) Work-life balance : After you join they will ensure you are a dedicated employee and have you work for more than 12-14 hours everyday and Saturday, Sunday. Contractors work for 17-18 hours.
6) Teammates : There are no teammates here.
cons: There is nothing right about the place

headline: Sales Executive
pros: Decent to work for............Good work life balance
cons: lack of promotion  lack of opportunities

headline: Overall Honest review
pros:
They have very competitive pay for call center depending on your experience its 15.00-16.00 starting then can go up from there 

The Benefits (medical dental vision) life insurance fraud protection (alot of others too many to name they even have very great benefits for both mothers and fathers who are employed with the company for planning a family you get your regular 8 weeks for maternity leave then baby bonding time within the first year you get extra 8 weeks of time off with your new baby so total of 16 weeks which is awasome they also have great adoption assistance and tuition reimbursement

Sunday and tuesdays they have FREE donuts and Fruit

 

The lavista NE location is very well kept nice gym, cafeteria, volley ball court and basketball court with a pond in the back to walk around during breaks/lunches

The desk are bigger than normal call centers i've seen!
cons:
Just as any other call center you are sitting 95% of the time and it can get tiering sometimes you get conflicting information on what is right and what is wrong.  They seem to say there is room for career growth however with out a degree i have not seen that possible and ive been there two years.  

The calls can be very dificult (depending what department you are in) however Debit card Department you get the callers who are upset about their cards not working or issues with their account and they can be highly unproffessional rude. 

Metic based per performance- some of the metrics just as any other call center AHT there are some metrics we as employees are subject to but its not within our control ex AHT is in your control call control but when we get bad survey they make it impossible for it to be appealed even if it was the correct response we gave the customer if their upset we have to take the hit on the survey which affects our TIP payout (bonus) at the end of the quarter

When i started i knew it was a call center however i did not know what position i was going to be placed you dont get to choose what you want you go through :my path" then they decide and give you a schedule  you cant change it unless there is a "shift bid" available and it does not happen often. we can not shift trade like other call centers allow you too. its very limited

headline: Good but stagnant and individuals ruin everything
pros:
- Diverse working environment.
- Casual dress code.
- Transportation and shift allowances provided.
- Fair wage considering the hours and work-life balance.
- Ability to buy PayPal stocks at an employee discount.
- Free/subsidized snacks and drinks from the vending machines.
- Occasional parties with food and gifts for any cultural celebration.
- Freebies such as hoodies, t-shirts, mugs etc.
cons:
- Upward mobility is stagnant.
- Employees being shuffled from department to department on the pretext of "upskill" with no change in salary grade and no additional wage.
- For executive-level hiring process, the company dismisses previous work experiences that are not in banking/financial services.
- Many overqualified employees for the positions they're holding.
- Despite the many D & I initiatives, the company can't stop individual employees from being racist/sexist and those who act inappropriately but not outright abusive often go unpunished. There's too much babying of bullies who are treated as if they don't intentionally want to hurt others, and too much focus on victims to alter their own behavior when faced with bullies.

headline: Red tape everywhere!
pros: The company has a lot of resources and they have invested in good reporting tools.
cons:
Too much of gimmicks of looking into customer experience but nothing for real. 
Group leaders who have been around since the time they were hired would do almost anything for personal gains.  No proper guideline for work related matters and agents can always manipulate the system as there's no proper governance on processes.
There are times when you'd be afraid to report process gaps due to the politics and the labelling which take place.
Incompetent managers who are around just to get promoted by impressing their superiors by putting up shows. 
The company is basically running on autopilot mode as they have already have strong customer base due to the lack of competitors in the market.

headline: Customer Experience Agent
pros: Will not get fired for not meeting metrics, some pretty cool co workers, maternity and bonding benefits are unheard of. They have a free gym
cons: Impossible to get a better schedule unless your in with higher ups, certain people have to jump through hoops to advance, while screw buddies will get promoted no problem, make you clock out to breastfeed, the employee surveys are not anonymous like they preach, constantly changing metrics to avoid bonding potential, cost of living raises are .37 a year. The shift bids are a joke, they change your schedule anytime and if you are not positive all the time they are extreme with outing you to anyone. They have the rudest people as help line that give you wrong information and their platform for finding information yourself on a call is always ridiculous and not updated. They change their policies everyday and your surveys cannot be disputed unless they say you don't speak English. They can call you by a different t name etc and you cannot dispute. Outsourcing is terrible they are incompetent and they make your customers so mad. Your customer will be transferred 10 times before coming to you and they are so pissed. You get the bad service because you are the last to touch the call.

cons:

Without speaking much french, I often felt isolated socially as people tend to be quite insensitive if they have one foreigner among all French person crowd.

Poor training

headline: Constant Change
pros: Good medical benefits, intelligent coworkers, the job can be interesting at times, sabbatical program
cons: The company is downsizing in most departments and going about these changes in a chaotic and unprofessional way. Managers tell certain employees confidential  information and directly tell them not to say anything  to anyone else. This creates so much gossip and mistrust. Employees who worked in my department for over 10 years were pushed out. They do not care about tenure anymore and we are treated like a number. The metrics are a joke that benefit agents who cheat the system while employees that try to do the right thing are not rewarded. Overall, I feel like  management treats us like we are in high school. The atmosphere with all the recent layoffs is tense and nobody feels like their job is safe.

headline: Different departments
pros:
Free Parking.
I need to complete 5 minimum words in this field.
cons:
Politics, Favoritism, Stats are manipulated in base who play the game. Unfair selection for promotions, often the promotion came out from the canteen or from a conversation in the balcony, so the decision is made pointing fingers based on who much you play the game. 
No respect from the Supervisors, neither from the Managers, and the worst part is not support from the HR department. 
Team Leaders often don't know the product or the goal of the department, neither the market needs or trends, eg. no strategy. No leaders, they are just to chase employees about the breaks, lunch time and to apply the carrot in front the rabbit policy.
Management is authority, once again there are not leaders, just authority and employees must to say the same than them in order to don't be blacklisted. 
Hr is the union of both groups, so they only support Supervisors and Managers, never employees.
There is no The company policy, it can be changed in base of the manager, supervisor, it means that rules are not the same for all employees within the teams. 
No communication at all, when you release a feedback you will be penalized. 
Salaries are out of the real living cost in Ireland, and salary reviews are just for friends, doesn't matter how hard you work or how high are your stats vs target, the best result will go to the friend of the manager, supervisor, even more if both have worked together in a different company before.
Targets are really challenging to reach, considering all the technical issues that come out every week.

headline: Steadily Declining
pros:
Meet some very talented peers
Lower level management is highly competent
cons: Upper management recently experienced some drastic changes, which resulted in many cloak-and-dagger actions including forced demotions in lieu of paying unemployment.  Recently there have been some severe layoffs due to (ineffective) automation practices in addition to outsourcing to highly incompetent workers. This was a great company to work for several years ago but, although it is too self-sustaining to fail, is certainly not going anywhere fast.  For a company that boasts significant growth every quarter, it's a travesty that benefits such as shift differential and bonuses were cut so dramatically for seemingly no reason.

headline: Sales perespective

headline: Nice place to start & build your experience
pros:
- Correct benefit (VHI, Stock, Pension, Bike to work...)
- Both locations in Ireland are great (Dublin & Dundalk) nice office, decent commodities, and good canteen (Sodexo, not expensive good quality)
- Good material to work (computers, software...) 
- Management chart is pretty clear, Team Leader (your direct manager) can be really good and/or average, strong emphasis on the word "leader" instead of manager in some instance
- If a business needs appears and you have good connection, you will be able to move quickly.
cons:
- Salary (Entry level is a bit low, specially because the office is not in the city center, unless you are living near the office or have shift matching with the shuttle, you will need to commute or have a car)
- Bonus (quarterly based, but really low) 
- Management, as stated your Team Leader can be a true leader or not, and this person will be your key to success
- Strong emphasis on targets, can be stressful for employees (specially in Front Office) no target? no evolution! (unless your Team Leader support you, which can be unfair compare to other teammates working harder)
- Typical US management style, you can like it or not, I am not a huge fan of the "optimistic way" even if management ask for your feedback, be careful...

Conclusion:
Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed my time in PP, but I would only recommend it in the optic to build your experience.

headline: Good if Your Work is Non-Critical
pros:
- Good work/life balance for teams that do not affect PayPal's bottom line.
- CEO is a great guy with a solid vision for the company.
- Good perks. Free soda, lots of events, technology training courses.
- If you can keep up with the high work demands, there is good upward mobility up to a certain point.
cons:
- If you work on one of the critical back-end teams, you can kiss your weekends goodbye. It's very common to see people in the office until 7, sometimes as late as 10 for a deployment hand-off to an India team.
- Mediocre culture (perks != culture). Although overall there is diversity, individual teams hire people like themselves (diversity != inclusiveness)
- Non-flexible work for engineers. They always assign more work than is feasible to complete. They expect people to work at a constant output all of the time.
- Managers may ask you to do extra on top of your work, which can be rewarding for your career, but is mostly to help the managers look better in their fight to look good.
- Because everyone is overworked, team members are too busy to train new hires.

Overall, it is a great place to work.

headline: Learning Specialist
pros: I loved the people on my from start to finish. I found coaches who were willing to develop me, and I stuck by them. I was bummed to leave PayPal for the relationships I had built and the skills I had gained from my mentors
cons:
So much of employee engagement, happiness, and consistency depended on what team you were on. As an agent who began on the phones, I and others were constantly switched from team lead to team lead. Some were better than others, and a few were down right awful. There was very little consistency and as I moved up in my career, that didn't change. 

As a facilitator I felt much more apart of my team, but many trainers were overworked, didn't know their schedules most of the time until last minute, and didn't have any effective facilitation guidelines to be held accountable for. Everyone trained in their own style.

headline: If you are on the fence, read this
pros: PayPal has a great benefits coverage for their staff, I would even go as far as saying that salary is also above average.
cons:
Too many to list down, but I'm going to try:

1. Politics - especially from those unqualified to lead. Team Leads are somehow hired based on 'years of Customer Service experience'. Non-performers from other organizations (can't even communicate effectively) are hired/promoted to be yes men to make management 'easier'
2. Employment practice. Some would think that call centers are filled with fresh graduates. I want to correct that assumption. PayPal KL is filled with folks who has >5 years working experience, didn't get anywhere, and was somehow brought into the organization, influencing the rest of the staff with bad working culture and attempted political underplay.
3. Staff treatment. My years at PayPal saw a few of the good folks leaving for greener pastures. Aside from planned promotions, PayPal KL does nothing to prepare their staff for any form of career progression, instead focusing on redundant 'soft-skill' trainings.
4. Sucking up is also an art plenty of those 'Leaders' you see got to where they are. Frequent 'outings' with the management increases visibility, and the management seems to much rather have someone with the same mindset, than have someone with actual ability.

headline: Seems like a good company but very bad indeed. Avoid
pros: Some good training. They still haven't realised that they are sending me their employee benefits hub offers despite having left quite sometime ago. Was able to use their undeserved reputation to get myself a much better job.
cons:
Bending the rules is the norm. You have a strict hierarchy and if your face doesn't fit, you have new ideas or you are interrupting the TPV then you are going  to have a hard time. Promise lots in interview delivered on none of it at all.

Whilst there saw a lot of people who came in thinking they could get some where only to be bitterly disappointed. PayPal is a glorified call centre and it is all metric driven. The targets are ridiculous and are contradictory and require you to ignore a lot unlawful activity.

Raised this with management and team leaders and found that it expected and was told not to be raising issues. Was asked to do projects and mentor staff who despite being tenured were under performing. This was ignored at end of year. Project suggested some automation was possible and this was frowned on. Later found out that they were planning automation all along and did not want the bods worrying and not doing their jobs.

Now sending a large number of people back to night shift customer service roles especially if they are Irish.
Gobby self interested nit wits likely to succeed but should remember being top of the pile doesn't matter if it's a pile of festering manure.

The money is terrible and if you are promoted internally you are on a capped increase. 26.5 k is not a lot for what you will be doing. Was promised 30k interview and later told that this figure included bonuses. Applied for one job and was not told I was being given another one until 6 weeks in. Dishonest or very sharp recruitment practices. My stupid fault for not walking earlier, but gave it a while to see if it would get better and that was mistake too.

Hours are not good and if you are new agent you will be shoved onto 1000 - 2000 shift or night shift so say good bye to your social life. Asked to get moved of my assigned shift and had to wait for several months and left before they came back to me.

Avoid unless absolutely no other choices

headline: Rants and frustrations of an an honest man
pros: None None None None None
cons: Absolute waste of time. Hopeless management who treat people like third class citizens. The class divide is too much between the staff and the management. The top brass think they are blue blooded(literally). This is all about the Chennai team (am not aware of the culture at other locations, but i don't think it will be any different). They do Agile and that's all they care about. Endless hours of lying and pleasing the Rally tool, so that management can fool off its top brass to earn good bonuses and profits. PayPal Chennai is what everything that's wrong about modern India. Brash, uncultured, and utterly pointless. Wish I could rant more, but what's going to change? Nothing probably. I would give no rating if I could, but again forced by the idiocy of the web developer to award PayPal a generous one start from me. I don't want people slating me, it's not my fault if you have low standards. I have worked previously in quality companies where people with double Phd's walk with humility that would shame you to death. Probably everything that's said about PayPal applies to every other company here. That's the only saving grace for the disaster that is PayPal Chennai.

headline: NOT a great place to work
pros:
- Colleagues
- Canteen was ok
- Gym
cons:
- PayPal wants to appear like the best place to work but the management doesn't care about the employees
- Every time you want to make a suggestion or if you have a concern they say they will consider etc. but they never come back to you
- Even in the public forum, Facebook or Glassdoor "PayPal" says "we value feedback, we will consider, we are sorry to hear about...etc." Everyone knows that these sentences are fake and that they are written on the first page of every marketing book 
- At least once a year they ask the employees to fill out a survey but in the end they don't care about the outcome, and it appears that they don't share the correct results 
- Very low payment for the work load they are expecting
- The work procedures in some departments change every day in a way that no one really knows what their scope of support is
- If a customer complains about PayPal its the employees fault because they weren't able to make the customer happy in the end
- You are not allowed to talk to your colleagues during the day. As soon as you want to say a word or if you want to ask a question a senior advisor asks you what you are doing (thats why its always quiet in the back office)
- The targets in some departments, especially in the front office, are almost not achievable - and as soon as they notice that too many advisors reach the targets they set it higher
- They offer the bonus but this amount is very low, and they take every chance for not paying it. In some occasions the advisor was too many times sick, the advisor handled one out of 100 calls wrong or just because "they can't give everyone a bonus". Yes, they need to select people who can not get the bonus.
- The manager tells you every week that you need to improve in something even though you reach all targets by 200 Percent- If all targets are met you need to work on your personality (!)
- You don't have many career opportunities because a lot of good jobs were offered to relatives or friends of managers
- The shifts are not fair. Some advisors had to work weekend shifts for years (!!) while others only had the shifts during the week. However PayPal advertises with a change every 6 months which is clearly a lie. 
- I could write so much more but to put it all in a nutshell in the end PayPal wants to create robots but they advertise with a great place to work etc. I would not recommend anyone to work here as I know a lot of people who suffer from depression etc.

headline: Disappointed
pros: PayPal moves fast so there is opportunity to work on different projects frequently; the company focus on empowering the "underbanked" Global population is admirable and inspiring; benefits are solid and most go into effect on first day of employment
cons: Elimination of support function such as learning & development mean business units have to implement their own leadership training - every quarter there seems to be a new "flavor of the month" training format rolled out, which then is abandoned after the newness wears off; executive leadership claims to want to instill work/life balance into culture, but allows practices that clearly discriminate against groups such as new parents, employees caring for sick family members, etc.; continued promotion of individuals who do not have effective leadership skills; groups work in silos, which often leads to unnecessary fire drills as a result of conflicting priorities; high level of internal conflict resulting from cliques of employees who join PaPal from other companies and then refuse to adapt to the culture (FNB of Omaha, Amex, etc).

headline: No opportunity for advancement
pros: Great benefits package, decent starting wage
cons: Paypal is a great place to work if you want to be stuck in single position for years with little wage increase. Change happens very quickly at PayPal, although not in a good way. You are constantly shoveled from team to team (within same department of course) and have a new team leader every 3-4 months, which you have to explain your career goals to every time and right when you think you're going to get somewhere BAM. New team. New boss. No actual advancement. The initial training received was completely inadequate. When you actually start your job you are incredibly overwhelmed. Also, the attendance policy changes are impossible. Flawed incentive system makes it very difficult to get a sizeable bonus or any bonus at all. The internal talent search is a joke.

headline: High hopes in the beginning...and now disappointment

On the same day the CEO announces a purchase of millions of another company, we get a 2% raise on an already low starting wage.  
Take care of your long term employees
Stop the high school clicks that team leads hang out with so they get what they want and get covered for mess ups that the rest of us would be fired or wrote up for
Dan schulman sends out too many political emails. He should worry more about paying people more so they are happy to come to work and be screamed at all day and stop trying to convince everyone to follow his beliefs. What is he trying to be...a cult leader?
Programming is terrible. There are constant bugs and system issues. Customers are mad at paypal and take it out on the agent with a survey and then its not appealable. 
Customers are allowed to talk to agents any way they want. They use foul language and instead of allowing the agent to be "empowered"  by disconnecting the call they have to take the abuse. 
TRY SUPPORTING YOUR EMPLOYEES DAN SCHULMAN. You might not have so many bad reviews from the people that help line your pocket

headline: Top Tier Pushed Out Unless in the Clique
pros: Salary, Benefits, CEO, Technology, Work Live Balance
cons:
Management is in a constant disarray and re-org should be the company motto. If you are on the higher end of the salary range expect to be rifted out for fresh thinking and new thoughts. Meaning they will hire lower paying replacements to make the numbers look good, at the same time sacrificing experience for new replacements.

Cronyism is alive and well, if your in the clique or inner circle you are destined for a raise, bonus and not affected by the new blood mantra, otherwise expect to be rifted out.

If you're in the inner circle you have nothing to worry about, if you're not part of the good old boy network prepare to be disappointed.
