headline: Used to be one of the best companies to work for and is now one of the worst
pros: Great Benefits.  Medical benefits are superior compared to other any other company I have worked with before. Great 401k match.
cons:
HR department is a complete joke.  Any issues that you have are in no way shape or form confidential and will get reported back to your supervisor or the individual you are filing a complaint against.  So be prepared to expect retaliation in the form of abuse, wage freezes, and any other way your supervisor can make your life miserable.

If you are considering becoming pregnant or already are, be prepared to be treated horribly before, during, and after your maternity leave.  Especially in the compliance department which is ran by a bunch on misogynists.

The new attendance policy is a slap in the face.  Especially considering the company strives to promote family values, this hurts individuals with family members the most.

This company uses metrics to deny pay increases.  Even when you are meeting and exceeding metrics it's still not enough.  They will find ways to alter metrics to deny tip and increases.  On average consider yourself lucky if you see metrics once every two months.

headline: Mixed emotions, but thankful for the experience

I was tasked with responsibilities that I initially thought were too far removed from my own skills and abilities to meet. This company will help you grow a thicker skin and focus on what you can achieve.
cons: The business direction of the company shifts frequently as does also the executive leadership over the past few years. The company's direction and focus seem to constantly be altered by internal and market and technological demands and can make work hard and sometimes completely wasted. Middle and some upper management suffer from constant kingdom building. Re-orgs are very common and extremly disruptive to business, morale and your own career needs and desires. Ego's, politics and macho mentality made it hard to engage with leaders, bosses and coworkers often.

headline: Frustrated
pros: Co-workers, fun environment, great onsight family activities
cons:
Terrible attendance policy alloting for only 5 call-ins during a rolling 12 month period does not allow for unforseen life happenings. Recent changes to the policy were supposedly to align with other centers throughout the world which I believe to be a outright lie. A simple search on EU labor laws found that US employees are allowed far less time off with no annual vacation days. Sick time must be accrued starting at the beginning of each year leaving no room for getting sick during winter, a time most people are apt to becoming ill. As it stands an employee cannot call-in for being legitimately sick until sometime in April of each year. Once a manager actually told their employees that while he understands things happen, but we should try avoid anything happening during our work days. This is especially insulting coming from someone not personally affected by the policy.
Process policies are changed frequently with little to no notice and offer no grace period to ensure employees understand and are implementing the changes correctly.
Advancement is based on who you know not your abilities.

There's a lot, more then I can think of.
After the excitement of "PayPal is an awesome company" wears off then everything starts showing.

Management sucks from the very top to direct supervisors.

YOURE NOT GRADED ON HOW WELL YOU DO THE JOB.
It's you're personality and NOT how well you do the job.


THE COMPANY IS DOWNSIZING!

headline: All the egos of the tech world combined with all the bureaucracy and politics of the banking world
pros: Reasonable competitive benefits but not fairly distributed and you can often find coworkers making a lot more or a lot less than you for doing the same job.

headline: Re-org has killed old culture
pros:
Reasonable pay. Most of the work is interesting.

cons:

Too many re-orgs kill team formations.

Interfacing software with other PayPal software incredibly time-consuming and difficult.

Management turnover very high.

Heavily political. Reviews seemed to be based on savy politics instead of performance. As a result
many managers are simply political hacks.

Way too many marginal apps on live.

After the re-org, all of HR was outsourced. Now it is very difficult to get a results from these remote outsourced HR people. The exit "interview" is an online multi-choice form. My PayPal career is thus a series of numbers, 1 to 5. This tells me PayPal doesn't care about its people.

headline: good experience would do it again
pros:
For Austin the stock compensation is best in class ( RSU's and ESPP).
Benefits were good, PTO, and sabbatical, decent 401k, decent medical.
Nice office space with walking path, gym, lots of windows for light.
at the end PayPal was a great place to explore new technology and take it from idea into production.
Very solid support teams ( dev ops etc...).
There were a few tough and long nights dealing with releases or produciton issues, but the process improved to where releasing code was always smooth and quick.
Very thorough pre-testing of production releases.
cons: The biggest con was being in Austin.  The original CEO was Scott Thompson who supported and championed the site.  After 3 CEO changes there is no senior management at the Austin site and for the most part everything is controlled out of San Jose.  I don't think the site will last much longer as the interest in Austin seems to be waning.

headline: IT Desktop Support in EMEA? AVOID!!!

She threw parties and solicited services from her teammates while drinking during my one on one and after telling her i was uncomfortable with her behavior i was separated from the company 3 days later.

headline: Cold and corporate, has lost its humanity
pros: Good health care benefits,  extended bonding/leave time for new parents,
cons: I worked there 13 years and saw a lot of changes over the years, mostly good but ever since they separated from eBay in 2015, it's really gone downhill fast. They have forced good agents into roles they do not want to do and anymore it's about making and saving money, they hammer productivity into our heads on a daily basis and don't get me started on the horrible micromanagement! They treat you like an elementary school kid who needs a hall pass to use the bathroom when you get up from your desk for 30 seconds to go get a drink. Plus they got rid of a lot of the cool and fun incentive and recognition programs for employees.

headline: Executive
pros: Fantastic company with great mission and vision. Dan is an awesome CEO! He is very transparent, engaging, and a great communicator. Diverse set of products. And check out our diversity statistics on people! There is a clear focus on diversity and it shows in the numbers. Everyone I work with is inspired by PayPal's vision and is driven to go above an beyond to help others succeed. Collaboration is one of the four values and it really shows in the culture. There is a great future ahead. Come join PayPal if you want to be part of something great!
cons: Since spin off from eBay 1 year ago the company is still aligning around go structure and figuring out how to operate as an independent company. This is part of the excitement as we get to create this new company's culture. There are growing pains, but these are to be expected and are fun to work through.

headline: Great place to work.

cons: Hated the strict 15-minute breaks and 30 minute lunches. Disputes and Claims felt like the door mat of the company.

headline: Not Horrible
pros: I really liked the people at PayPal. The people PayPal employees are smart and creative. Comping from an extremely competitive company, I was surprised at how helpful everyone was during my first few weeks. PayPal is always trying to do something new and exceed the norm of payment.
cons: The management at PayPal is less than par. With the the fast paced environment, there is little structure and control from management and organizations. This can work in start ups, but PayPal is not a start up. They need to mature and become better organized. Once they do this, they will excel in the payment areas. However, working the way they do now, they spend too much, have bloated organizations, no sustainable direction.

headline: Not just about brand name
pros: Good commissions within sales and good bonus for account management. free lunch, discounted health care and gym memberships. Drinks on Friday.
cons:
Not enough girls! 
Clear favouritism from management/leadership team and unless you are their 'buddy' don't even think about getting a promotion. 
If you want any career progression at all it's all up to you. They do not update you on which teams are hiring. 
They don't promote from global opps to the business unit because there seems to be fierce competition and/or no communication between departments. 
Hardly any support from leadership and the sales team have lost 2 team leaders within 6 months because of the environment. 
Lots of constant changes within the team that disrupt the peace. 
The global opps team is very obviously tight on budget that they try to make as many cuts as possible.

headline: Poor Managment
pros: The People are great, most of the immediate management or TL's are also really nice, but to think of them as actually management would be a mistake.
cons:
Management aren't trained managers, a lot of them simply came from other call centers, and focus on day to day People management but without any actual control. If you change departments , you're career goes to the back of the queue. Management make promises they cant achieve and or keep. Staff have literally been paid to stay quiet and not complain.

PTO can often be impossible to get, 

Staff were promised new roles in the company for their hard work, but this was a lie and then all management changed and there was  no one to answer for their lies.

headline: Director

headline: You are lost here
pros:
1) Compensation and great work life balance are the main reasons to work for PayPal. 

2) With a new board thanks to the work of an activist shareholder who also was also instrumental in shaking up earlier management and board there is a new ray of hope and accountability for the future.

3) Risk management is the only place where things are still happening.
cons:
1) More PMs than engineers. So if you are a PM your either cranking out ppts or making cases to get engineers.

2) Strategy is tops down (Snr. VPs and above). Everyone else is a worker bee trying to perform on an already defined roadmap.

3) You almost never directly present to leadership and they never talk to you. Like most traditional large corporations, you do the work and its presented by your manager or his/her manager.

4) Bottoms up innovation yields pats on the back and awards but is never funded to see the light of day.

5) Way more political to an extent that even leaders are afraid of making decisions

headline: good for a start, then move on!
pros: If you are interested in online banking / commerce / fraud, you will learn much in Paypal. Salaries, a much debated point, could be higher, but could be worse too. Benefits are, I think, decent. Good work / life balance. 25 days off per year isn't bad either.
cons: Hard,  and sometimes meaningless, targets. Promotions can be hard to get. Work,  in some positions,  can be very repetitive, thus boring, and very probably quite unhealthy both for the mind and the body.  Little autonomy in some roles, and are you treated like an adult, really?  Everything  feels like  in constant turmoil. In spite of these obvious pitfalls, you are forever told that Paypal is the best thing since the invention of sliced bread. Given all of this, attrition rate is high enough.  My advice: learn from Paypal and move on to a different company where you will get more money and more respect.

headline: Customer Solutions Agent
pros:
Medical Insurance (VHI)
25 days holiday + Paid 4 week sabbatical after 5 years
Free on-site gym
Free parking
Onsite Costa Coffee shop
International and friendly environment
Courier services onsite
cons:
Some team leaders tend to micro-manage and not listen to teammates needs and concerns. Due to lack of skills some of them tend to not treat everyone fairly. There are no long term team leaders and this can be really demotivating since you need to build trust every time. 
Progression program does not work unless you have the support from your Team Leader. Also there are only few upskilling and internship opportunities that you can use to specialized and even go further on your career.  
Communication between department does not work at all. There is a serious lack of communication between departments. CS agents are the last in the hierarchy to know about any features or bugs. Customers are in fact the first to know. 
No free shuttle bus from Dublin city centre and vice versa, no free snacks, the food from the canteen should be better.

headline: Back-stabbing culture
pros: nice office space, choice of 2 cafeterias, decent benefits and pay
cons: terrible culture, employees who spend time self-promoting are the ones who thrive. If you spend your time working instead of making alliances, you are screwed. There has been an exodus of capable people in the last 2-3 years.

headline: nice people, nice paycheck, waste of life energy
pros:
Most of the people are very nice.
Tends to pay higher salaries in locations other than San Jose, so they attract some very good talent at the remote offices.
Mostly stable employment until there is a regime change and someone decides to move an entire group to another city.

Very slow pace on actual deliverables so work/life balance is pretty good.
cons:
Top talent in San Jose is working at Google, Facebook or a hot startup, so PayPal gets mostly B players who hire C players.

"Speaking truth to power" is not appreciated by B and C players in management, but it can be fun if you have no career expectations.

The number 1 goal is to keep the site up, which means that innovation is not encouraged. Only broken things get fixed.

PayPal has a strong affirmative action promotion policy which effectively means that white males should look elsewhere. 

PayPal decided that they needed to get into offline payments. While they were trying to integrate into Home Depot, they lost their core business to many new players.

PayPal was a monopoly that failed to achieve its true potential, and is now in a long slow decline.

Too many meetings. There are too many managers at PayPal for the actual progress made on anything, so they fill the time with meetings.

headline: Best company to work in chennai
pros:
I have worked in HCL, NetApp and VMWare.
I like PayPal the most.
I have completed 1 year at Paypal and this is my 1st review.

PayPal provides Very good package :) - First most


My team has good Work life balance. Not sure about other teams.
Nobody cares what others do. Team follows Agile with 2 weeks sprint.

Flexible Office Timings. Nobody cares at what time you login / logoff.
Work from home option.
Good support from manager and team for higher education (I completed M.Tech part time).

Very good Transport Facility. (They have scheduled timing shuttles and also Door drops if you stay late) - This is awesome.

Free Snacks (Usual Tea/coffee vending machine, Biscuits, Plain vanilla & chocolate cakes, Tropicana, Real and Appy juices. Heritage Badam milk all flavors :) )
Recently they started healthy campaign and started providing few healthy foods for a short span. (Peanuts, Dates, Buttermilk, spouts, bananas, other healthy snacks)

Annual Events celebrated by PayPal is awesome.

Very good Gym with Trainer, 
Gym attached with Rest rooms for bathing (Includes towel, shampoo, Body wash, coconut oil, safe locker) 

Play area - Shuttle badminton - 2 courts
I play for 2 hours every day.

Bollywood Dance classes.

They also arrange guitar classes, Running club (3 months batch)
Some kind of club for people interested in Photography, Music and Singing , 


I don't have anything to complain as of now. Waiting for my appraisal cycle. Will come to know the real face of my manager soon :)
cons:
Their choice of food vendors...
Lunch is the only thing I hate at PayPal.

headline: Account Manager
pros: Amazing Benefits. Maternity leave is 16 weeks, Paternity 8 weeks paid vacation. Dental, vision, mental health, and health care benefits are better than I've ever had before. Good Pay

headline: Deceptive Payment
pros:
Growing environment for fresh grads
Freedom of work life
Opportunity to vocate your ideas
cons:
They quote a made up CTC which would be twice your base salary and you wont know how they arrived at that amount, as end of the year what you get is much less.

If you have a joining bonus component be very careful. They will take it back based on the service period condition on your offer letter. But never mention the amount they have taken back on any paper, not even From 16. Payroll team is extremely rude and harsh. They will not tell you till your last day how much money you have to pay back. And you have to pay then and there by cheque. 

Now, you keep mailing HR, they would not mention about this amount in your From 16 and you end up paying a huge tax amount (1/3 rd of the bonus). Nobody from HR, your director, manager would understand your argument and ask the payroll to correct the From 16. Complete harassment I would say.

headline: Great Company
pros: I think PayPal is a great company to work for. The benefits and the people are great. I think that the Chandler leadership team is fantastic, especially for PayPal Credit. With the exception of one or two supervisors, each leader takes great care of and interest in their employees.
cons: It is a very busy call center. There are few days when you aren't going to be back to back on calls.

headline: Great company overall, to an extent
pros: Benefits start day one, bonus opportunity in many departments, good medical, employee stock purchase plan, growth depending on your department
cons:
Micromanagement has increased a ton unnecessarily. Coming from the department I was in where we were completely off the phones and strictly just did investigations, it was extremely hard to handle being micromanaged by other managers who come from call center enviornments because they didnt understand our flexibility. Aside from that it was just all over the place with how they wanted things done, and  everyone had their own way of doing things and it was like pulling teeth to get a straight answer.  Approximately 20 of us were hired on to help the department where they were struggling, and to make things better with compliance yet we were never listened to when trying to give ideas. A lot of us who were hired on have worked in banking compliance for years and we know the best ways to get the work done but it was really hard to get our ideas across because the company is very stuck in their ways of how they do things and it's like they did not want to budge at all. Their quality system for the compliance department will cause you to probably lose your job, its highly inconsistent. Just a warning to be careful!!! As a result of that they have lost a lot of people who have quit in fear of losing their jobs. The inconsistency of the compliance department is very scary. They say to use tour best judgement when writing sar reports then fail you if they dont agree with YOUR own investigation. The slightest error can result in a fail. No matter how many passing reviews you get, if you get 3 fails (no matter how minor) consecutively you go on corrective action. No financial institution operates like this. 

Paypal is a great company. The benefits are amazing. Most people who worked in the compliance department feel the same way I do. However, outside of that department i have  heard much better.

headline: Environment isn't bad but company having a serious identity crisis
pros:
Many smart people with experience in many Silicon Valley companies
Nice facilities and company events
Generally a relaxed, informal workplace
Salary and comp plan is acceptable
cons: PayPal has potential to be a tier 1 company but I don't think it will happen. Since eBay split nothing has been accomplished. Always a constant reorg at any given time stopping engineers from making progress on projects that would take PayPal products from OK to great. Now a constant budget squeeze for hiring but plenty of money For things like moving hundreds of people's desks or fluffy marketing stuff. this plus politics at higher levels make progression nearly impossible. You might have some chance if you are a male from a certain country with personal connections to the leaders. There has been talk about diversity but Nothing is happening. The lack of progress toward product improvement has people wondering if the plan is really to grow PayPal or get it really for sale.

headline: No College Degree? Don't Work hard?No Problem: Popularity Contest at its Best

We had a college educated AWF serve our team for a year and did not get hired on because she worked too hard and did not participate the the B.S. politics. She deserved to get hired on as she put our small team on the map and added tremendous value.

headline: A great place to start a career in business or finance.
pros: Good benefits, especially tuition reimbursement right from day 1. Easy barrier to entry and decent pay for entry level CS. Unlimited overtime most of the year. Overtime incentives are usually pretty enticing with large prizes. Quarterly or semi-annual bonuses aren't amazing, but are based on a % (up to 6) of what you made in that period - so overtime pays extra there. If you perform you can move through different departments and often the hardest workers will get their choice of jobs and shifts. Variety of personalities so you are bound to make friends somewhere along the way, some really good people work here.
cons: Your experience at PayPal varies greatly depending on your direct leader. There is an extreme variance between styles and discipline. Some are much more involved in office politics than others, and there are many more followers than leaders. If you can ignore it and push through PayPal looks great on a resume and pays for you to go to school. The pay scales well if you continue to move up, but staying in the same role for years doesn't yield great results and at 5 years and 4 positions in, I'm starting to look externally, mainly because I want to make the same amount each year without having to work overtime. If you want to make 50k+ a year you can in any department if you put in enough overtime.

headline: Poisoned Chalice
pros: Pay is somewhat competitive for new employees - higher than most of the older employees.  The benefits are also great - $.25 Soda, gym, 401K and matching, Employee Discounted Stock, Med/Dental/Vision, and a game room - almost all available from day 1. PayPal is the king of online payments, so you also have a lot of job security as long as you stay on the good side you supervisor (even if you NEVER hit metrics!).
cons:
PayPal tries to put up a facade of a company that lets successful people thrive and innovate. This may be true for the non-call center position, but it's definitely fool's gold at the call centers. It's all about who you know rather than how well you do your job. If you're well liked by management, they will essentially get you the schedule and position that you're looking for. If you fall into disfavor, look forward to skipped one-on-one meetings (required weekly coaching meetings that help YOU improve with your manager), low yearly ratings, strict enforcement and harassment, no promotion and/or moving out of the department, write ups, and possibly even termination. I have seen people get fired for absolutely BS reasons. There are rare opportunities to move up, but most people try to move sideways off the phones, which gets you stuck there for 6+ months. 

There is also a culture of misinformation and deception both to employees and customers. Managers regularly withhold information or straight up lie. For a company that supposedly focuses on being transparent with customers and employees, they fall short. A fun lie is that "PayPal has never been hacked." While it is true that there has not been an attack that has successfully taken large amounts of data (as far as PayPal knows), ALL systems are hackable - it's a matter of how fast you detect, catch, and expel the invader. We also had to regularly lie about "system undergoing maintenance" when something would crash or a bug was plaguing the system. While technically true in the sense that engineers/techs would be updating the system to fix these, it implies that the bugs/outages are intentional - which is definitely intentional deception.

Also in the 3 years that I worked here, I was always one of the top performers and even received the top rating for each yearly review (Exceeds Most), yet cumulatively I received only 7.5% raises. One of those raises was from getting a slight promotion, that they ended up giving to ALL customer service agents less than 6 months later.

headline: Avoid At All Costs
pros: The gym is pretty nice. I have nothing else to put here but need to write this to meet the 20 word minimum.
cons:
Everything else is terrible. Middle Management is concerned only with building their fiefdoms. Rather than work together, managers will sabotage the work of others if they feel threatened or overshadowed. This is not a company that you want to go to if you want to work to make things better or have any ideals beyond making your manager look good in PayPal's Game of Thrones managerial culture.

Not only that, but every single business process internally is broken. The company runs everything on rushed artificial deadlines, resulting in tech-debt ridden software that is in constant need of replacement. When it does get replaced, it's replaced by yet another rushed out and tech-debt ridden solution. This is compounded by poor hiring standards resulting in sub-standard developers writing terrible code with little oversight and no code review. But who has time to review code when this feature needs to be rushed out by tomorrow?

There are so many better companies to work for out there that there's no reason to come here. Leaving was one of the best decisions I've ever made in my life. I look back on my time in horror. It's like having left an abusive relationship. I still find myself stopping, shuddering, and then releasing a huge sigh of relief that I no longer work here.

headline: software Engineer3

headline: Mixed Bag
pros: Excellent benefits and work/life balance. 10 paid holidays, lots of time off and they now offer sick time which is new. Great benefits for new parents. Depending on the location there is opportunity for growth. Progressive minded company. There is a lot of potential for growth for PayPal. Good entry level compensation.
cons: Your mileage may vary here. PayPal is generally behind when it comes to innovation in the payments space. If feels like we are always a step behind and when a product is launched it lacks key features. Constant micro management and lack of competent leadership in the middle of the organization is chasing out the talent. Compensation does not scale with experience and most people find out they are worth more on the external job market and leave. The culture and values are great, just not really embraced by mid level leadership.

headline: Not a place for motivated, intelligent people. Only Sheeple
pros: It can appear like a good place to work, but appearances can definitely be misleading.
cons: Most of the people in lower-management have little to no experience or education. PayPal loves to promote from within, this makes for many inexperienced and not actually motivated "leaders" that really seem to only care about their pay and sabatical. They do not seem to have any motivation to keep PayPal on a good track doing the right thing. Already this is evident in the lawsuits against PayPal, some with non-disclosure agreements and some like the PayPal credit settlement. If the problem isn't addressed and a better HR policy/management in place, PayPal is set to be "old-money", because the track they are on, is not a good one.

headline: Making an impact on a global scale!
pros:
During my time here, PayPal has been a place where I have been able to learn and grow and challenge myself. It has afforded me the opportunity to work across different domains and orgs, which I feel is helping me to gain a broader perspective of how to run a business. I have also had great opportunities to be mentored by awesome leaders.

Great executive leadership that is driving us in the right direction.

Pretty open to new technologies
Get to work with lots of smart people
Inclusive to everyone
Good salary / benefits - They have recently instituted some more progressive HR policies (Unlimited PTO, Volunteer time off, 3 yr RSU vesting cycle, etc.)
cons:
As with any large company, you will work with (and sometimes under) people who are not good leaders or managers, or just coasting along. Most of the time these kinds of things tend to work themselves out, but sometimes it can take longer than you think.

Some people may not like the amount of ambiguity or change that happens due to the competitive landscape we are in. (Reorgs happen more than once a year.)

International travel policy was changed to remove business class travel. The cost savings are obvious, but 8+ hour flights in economy can be brutal.

If I had the choice to do it all over again, I would absolutely work here again despite the inherent 'cons' that come with any company.

headline: Business Systems Analyst
pros: Work Culture and work life balance
cons: Compensation is less compared to other companies

headline: A place where you can really have an impact if you're a passionate go-getter
pros: I've been at PayPal just over a year now and seen it through some big changes in such a short time.  The executive team are really authentic and inspiring.  They are very open to change and new ideas from anywhere in the business. People are generally helpful and working toward the same vision for the company.  It's a really inspiring place to be right now.  You feel you are making a positive impact on the world and great opportunities for your career.
cons: Like any big company it has it's challenges of having to go through different processes and groups to get things done. But they are determined to make it easier. It's a complicated business and structure so sometimes hard to fully understand what everyone does.

headline: Opportunity
pros: Lots of exciting cutting edge opportunities
cons: Management is poor, favoritism is rampant when junior associates get bumped up / promoted ahead of senior associates due to who they know.  If you're from outside of U.S. opportunities are abundant as there are mostly foreign workers in management positions.

headline: Currently Employed
pros: Great benefits, working with awesome people and overall positive environment
cons: Seems to be an ongoing trend to produce more with less support.

headline: Working at paypal
pros: Get to work with smart colleagues
cons: Company overall strategy needs a rehaul

headline: Principal Engineer
pros: Great Place to work for.
cons: I am not sure what to write

headline: Product needs help
pros: Good pay, strong brand.  Company is slowly realizing that it has infrastructural issues on the site, and is slowly and carefully addressing a stagnant mobile wallet that's in dire need of innovation.  We have a lot of potential.  Human resource decisions have been a little reckless.
cons: I'm lucky to have a team that knows how to get things done, but we constantly struggle to grow resources in order to follow through with our plans.  The business struggles to improve the analytical infrastructure, and while I'm not day-to-day facing with product teams, I fail to see the level of innovation that you would expect from top tier tech company with over a decade of tenure.

headline: Account Executive
pros: Job environment, pay, flexibility and peers
cons: Location to my home makes the drive too long

headline: Depends on what you want out of it.
pros:
Great Benefits. They now have sick days, 8 weeks paid parental leave, charity days, and other benefits like tuition reimbursement.

Great team of people.
cons:
Very Bureaucratic: takes forever to get things changed and there is no easy way to do so. 

Promotion system is broken: Right now the system is completely broken to high rate of department transfers.

Software: there are always tons of bugs in the system and it causes lots of issues with our customers. So when they call and yell at us all we can say is there is nothing we can do.

headline: Good Company, Poor Leadership
pros: This company offers awesome benefits, and a great atmosphere, there is room for growth and it is encouraged. Weekly meetings with your Team Leader are the expectation. Company cares about employees mental and physical health.
cons: Leadership is so separated from the company that favoritism, and negative criticism of performance is regular. Team Leaders are not always sticking up for their agents, and constant leadership changes make it impossible to rely on your coaching file.

headline: Customer Service
pros: Free Coffee, and soda's are .25
cons: Lies to employees, moves shifts, doesn't promote.

headline: Senior Marketing Manager
pros: Good benefits, smart people for the most part.  Very interesting work, one of the most visited websites in the world so a ton of learning in a short period of time.
cons: slow to execute, promotions are not based upon merit but who likes you.  It's very much like a fraternity or sorority where one person can blackball you and ruin your experience.  Work life balance can be terrible but that depends on your department

headline: PayPal Review: Java Developer
pros: Sabbatical, Untracked Vacation, Better Insurance Plans
cons: Work Life balance, Work Pressure

headline: Software Engineer Level 2
pros: Work From Home. Flexible Hours. If you are lucky once in 3 years US trip for 3 months
cons:
Lots of politics and back biting, try to advance their careers at the cost of putting down others
Lots of work but no good hikes, policitically motivated and shouting at engineers only to see their mistake later.

headline: Software Engineer 1
pros: Best work life balance. Good pay, good perks. Best for settling down in Chennai
cons: Not the most technical environment.

headline: software engineer
pros: Good pay and good location
cons: Not good work life balance

headline: Bad culature
pros: Business model is solid despite competitor situations, expecting continued revenue growth
cons: Many re-orgs and leadership changes in last two years making employees hard to focus. Company strategy also changes frequently. No retention incentive for old and knowledgeable folks. Recently grown into very political and careless culture.

headline: Working at PayPal
pros: It's a leading company in a very dynamic segment. There are plenty of opportunities for employees to grow within the company and learn in different areas.
cons: Still there is some political aspects in the company that cause employees to quit or feel less valued, and I believe this is something the leaders are working on.

headline: ok
pros: great market potential, great industry and team
cons: not focused enough, not enough emphasis on career development

headline: Account manager
pros: Great innovative company with lovely likeminded people. Great culture and pay
cons: Inconsistent management practices, employees left in the dark very often and limited scope for career progression

headline: Director
pros: One of the best company to work for
cons: Career growth is limited and very random

headline: Change in Management Structure
pros:
Name recognition - leader in payments industry.
Nice HQ offices in San Jose.
Passionate people who really want to take PP to the next level
cons: Was shown the door in preparation for the eBay/PP split - 'cost restructuring'.  To PP credit, I did get a decent severance - but was only there under a year.  Unfortunately, the manager that actually hired me moved to another role within PP by my start date.  I ended up reporting to a manager that wasn't involved in my hiring - and truth be told, would not have hired me. So - unfortunately, wasn't really given a fair shake given the circumstances.

headline: Good CEO. Company extremely political. Leaders don't get along.
pros: Braintree may be a great place to work, but legacy stack. Business is going fine, due to growth of customers on legacy stacks.
cons: Lots of legacy. Hard to get anything done. Need connections, not merit, to survive. Feeling of loser inside, to competition.

headline: A great place to develop yourself
pros:
Really great company to work for if you want to develop yourself and make some decent money.

Great working culture, you will get to know people from all over the world and build your network within the company.
Canteen is subsidized and the food is decent.

Great benefits, opportunity to invest in shares (definitely do this if you have just landed a job with PayPal). There are some really great people there too who are passionate and knowledgeable about their job. 

For my first two years with the company I worked under an excellent manager who would walk through walls for his team, had in depth product and process knowledge and was a true motivator.

However on the flipside to that, the manager I had for my second 2 years was the polar opposite, sparse product knowledge, few contacts within the company, no idea of chain of escalation, did not inspire or motivate, did not respond to emails and regularly attempted micro managing people who did not require management/training in the area identified.


Overall it's a really nice place to work, the people there are what make it what it is,I have made friends at PayPal that I will have for life. The training is excellent (access to Harvard training courses), PayPal will sponsor your studies if they are industry relevant. 
The integration team does a really good job of supporting the sales floor. 
PayPal's technology is the industry standard, you will become proficient in some of the world's leading software.

PayPal are also a company that will stick by you in difficult times.
I suffered with a medical condition which resulted in me missing quite a bit of work and the company was always supportive and accommodating in granting leave.
cons:
These cons are in relation to the telesales department and are not reflective of the company as a whole.

Your experience can vary depending on your manager.
I had the best 2 years of my career to date when I started with PayPal but once I changed teams due to an organizational shift I found myself reporting into a manager who I felt was under qualified and did more to antagonize staff than motivate them.
The vast majority of managers working at PayPal are highly competent and professional but like any company in the world you can sometimes end up with a manager that makes life difficult.

I was in a sales position so naturally the role can get stressful from time to time, however this seems to be shifting in the wrong direction for PayPal's sales team as the market reaches saturation.
Sales agents who wish to make decent commission can expect to self prospect 80-90% of their leads as the lead generation team tend to recycle dead leads and non profitable companies over and over again!
Investment and proper utilization of software can solve that problem but there seems to be a lack of interest/innovation at the management level of lead gen.

headline: focus  on  targets,  no  concern  for people
pros: good  atmosphere, empowerment  culture, education reimbursement,great  place  to  learn  how  to manage  multitask  job  quickly  and  efficiently.  Great  CS training,  especially  call  contol with  human  to  human  emphasis
cons: within  last  year  company's  politics  changed dramatically, it  is  currently  employee  unfriendly,  severe  tech  issue followed  by  unrealistic  targets  cause  a lot  of  stress,  lack  of  career opportunity

headline: Program Manager
pros: Great Environment if you are in the right team :)
cons: Too much organizational changes which impacts the employees.

headline: Exciting industry, Great Company, Awesome Team!
pros:
PayPal over the years has been on a trajectory growth and in no better times than now to have visionary leader Dan Schulman lead an awesome team towards lots of untapped opportunities in the fintech space. This is definitely more significant post the spilt from eBay Inc where opportunities to partner and acquisitions of high potential companies helps PayPal 

The organization is definitely fast moving and in this organization, things move pretty fast. Keeping up to the pace and the changes can be both exciting and challenging. 

Great teamwork and sharing happening across the organization. Understanding the importance of keeping ourselves as one team, PayPal has a great work culture where sharing is very core and key to keep abreast of our fast changing environment, 

Keeping it real - management team never fails to keep it real for all our employees, not masking any bad news but for all of us to have the courage to face brutal facts and action on necessary to keep us in a good shape. 

Culture - Collaboration is key cornerstone to how we work together as a team , One Team! And we're constantly reminded of how vulnerable us as an organization can be if we don't continue to innovate and be at the forth front of offering the best to our customer with customer centricity at the core of our business.
cons: No time to lament on missed boat/opportunities, thus it can be pretty much of a culture shock for those who are not used to the pace of this organization and the constant changes to meet the needs of our customers

headline: Senior Marketing Manager
pros: People are great--one of PayPal's best assets of having great, passionate people. The new CEO's vision is also very inspiring--the challenge now is to meet it.
cons: Consensus building and escalation based culture that makes it difficult to navigate the matrix and get things done fast.

headline: Senior Marketing Manager
pros: People are great--one of PayPal's best assets of having great, passionate people. The new CEO's vision is also very inspiring--the challenge now is to meet it.
cons: Consensus building and escalation based culture that makes it difficult to navigate the matrix and get things done fast.

headline: Organization
pros: Nothing to mention in favour of this company
cons: No real team work focussing on specific domain.  Everyone tries to do everything.

headline: Company for the future - one to watch
pros: Recently joined and have found the whole experience fantastic. The interview process was efficient and slick - utilising technology to reduce multiple interview rounds.  Great atmosphere, friendly colleagues, can do attitude and very inclusive culture.  Seeks input from employees utilising all experiences, always seeking to provide a great product to the consumers and merchants.   There is a great spirit within the company and everyone is willing to help each other. Very excited about my career within PayPal - and on top of that great Richmond offices by the River.  Definitely a company to watch
cons: None that I am aware of

headline: Politics
pros: Health care, gym, 25 days holidays
cons: It's not how good you are it's about how much you lick up to management. You can go through talent ready but ultimately its your team leader who makes the decision on who gets promoted. You need to be a best friend and play the game.

headline: Great career starter
pros: Decent pay, excellent benefits, large amount of development, easy to moves to lateral roles within the company, great on site amenities.
cons: Hard to make changes, executing on decisions takes forever, very little power given to first line of leadership, incompetence is tolerated.

headline: MTS 2
pros: it's a stable company and still growing
cons: there are a lot of hard works and overtime

headline: Costumer Specialist
pros:
Great place for start a career
Great team
Good salary
cons: Call-centre can be tiring job

headline: Meh
pros: The compensation was not bad (if you don't compare it with Tier I companies like Google, FB. LinkedIn, etc.). The facility is nice (if you don't mind open space). You can find there some nice and smart people.
cons:
Depending on your luck you may or may not have a reasonable manager. I was not that lucky. 
The infrastructure is simply a joke. A lot of time spent figuring out why something that is supposed to work is not working.
The processes which you'd expect to find in the mature company are almost entirely absent. 
As a result the code quality is in a pretty sad state. The Live issues are pretty common and surrounded with a lot of drama.
The technology stack is ancient. (Although it depends on the group you will be part of). 
The work force diversity is lacking (and sometimes missing entirely).
Your experience at Paypal depends on which group you join but overall I'd say that the chances are not that good.

headline: "Great Employer.  Best of Omaha"
pros: PayPal offers the overall perfect concept of what a Fortune 500 company should entail.  Regardless being new to the workforce or an established professional the company is well rounded to take on high quality employees throughout.  Their culture and values are employee based which has help to make it Omaha's Best Place to work in both 2015 and 2016.  It's a casual, fun environment that helps to make your employment enjoyable on a daily basis.  PayPal will offer fair competitive pay in market comparison, the highest quality of work/life balance around PTO, Family, and Sick time, and management is approachable and will work to help develop each employee to meet their highest potential.  The company outlook for growth and opportunity is extremely positive based on our quarterly reports as a stand alone company since the split from Ebay in July 2015.  I give PayPal my full endorsement for all employees in the current workforce.
cons: As a current employee I haven't noticed any negative aspects of the company.  PayPal offers career advancement, has competitive pay, will work with family life PTO/Sick time, offers volunteer time/gives back to the community, and Senior Management is approachable and willing to assist in anyway possible.

headline: A place you enjoy your work
pros:
*Very engaged culture with very fun enviroment.
* Open to ideas and suggestion - while implementing most of it often
*Opportunities to move to different role - career enhancement
*Constant improvement and positives changes
cons: Work on shift but not rotation basis (upon agreement)

headline: Great Place to work
pros: Excellent working place, would give a thumb up in term of the benefits that given to the employees. You would get opportunities to grow your career as long as you're fighting hard for it. A good place to learn and grow yourself, a company that provide good benefits, diversity, and employee care.
cons: Nothing is perfect, to be picky. there are some contractors, which is talented. Anyhow due to the limited headcount they're waiting for the conversion. Don't lose touch with lower level associates, these people are the building blocks of tomorrow!

headline: Easy Job, Fair Pay
pros: As a customer service rep, the work itself was fairly easy so long as you're internet-savvy. Paid training made me comfortable in doing my job. Pretty good work/life balance, and I had nothing but a positive experience with trainers and management. Bonuses based on performance available. Great atmosphere. Casual dress. Fair compensation.
cons: Some bad customers - though few and far between.

headline: Excellent
pros:
Culture oriented.. maximum output when it comes to diversity and inclusion. 
Excellent office environment.. KL office rocks! 
We believe in people and truly stand for a one team and moving towards the right direction in being customer champion..
cons: needs more work on building back the empowering culture.

headline: Great place to work
pros: I have been with PayPal almost two years now and I still look forward to coming in to work each week.  My contributions have been valued from the start and my efforts have been rewarded. We have excellent benefits including vacation, 401k match, stock purchases, and bonuses.  Most of all I love the flexibility I have been afforded with my work schedule; it has allowed me to volunteer at my children's schools and ensure I'm able to provide for their needs as a mother. Lastly, there is a very active women's affinity network and I've had the opportunity to work with some great leaders as shadows and mentors.
cons: PP is a fast paced company in an industry that is changing; this means there is a lot of change and requires flexibility on our part as employees.  I love this and thrive in an environment such as this that never gets stale, but some may find the change difficult to adapt to.

headline: Center of Fintech Innovation
pros:
Growing and fast moving industry
Numerous opportunities for growth
Touching on people's everyday life
Smart and passionate people
Great brand recognition
Work life flexibility
cons: This is a common theme for a global/large organization, but the organization works in silos and sometimes it's difficult and time consuming to coordinate cross function.

headline: Positive Global Impact. Check.
pros: Global impact connecting buyers and sellers from 200 countries/markets to create a new world of commerce. I work in our global cross border ecommerce sector. A rising tide. Colleagues globally are responsive & helpful. The tools are there for people who want to make a difference. Company making concerted effort to unify missions and amplify the best of the culture that existing across our global offices.
cons: Cultural experience differs depending on location & function to the point where it can feel like a different company depending on where you are. Historically business decisions are very US centric but this is also changing for the better.

headline: Great Place Work
pros: Advanced from entry level to several levels up, doubled my salary in 5 years. There is an ability to find your own path. Very positive environment. Great benefits, discounted stocks, sabbatical, learn a lot.
cons: Large company, can get slow and bureaucratic.

headline: Challenging and Rewarding
pros: Tons of opportunity - I began my career here, fresh out of college, starting in an entry level position when the Credit part of the organization was still a 100 person startup.  A decade later, we have at least a thousand employees in Maryland and I now hold a management role within a global organization. There is tons of variety to keep you interested; I've held jobs at the Operations site in Hunt Valley as well as the corporate office in Timonium. I've led teams of 15+ people, and worked as an individual contributor. During my time here I've done everything from customer correspondence to risk management, and there's more coming every day! The fast pace keeps you busy and though you're working hard, you get to partner with some of the best coworkers you've ever worked with. I really enjoy working with everyone here, from my team to my peers to my leaders.
cons: There's change - a lot of change. You need to be able to adapt quickly and roll with the punches, otherwise you will not be successful here.

headline: Due Diligence
pros: The company is up to date with all of the BSA/AML/EDD Standards and train their employees very well when it comes to Risk Assessment Forms and SAR Filings. Great Health, Life Insurance, 401 K (4%) and Flex Time for work life balance.
cons: Unrealistic handle times of 1 hour when cases typically take 2-3 hours or more to review a RISK Assessment Form. It sets the employee up for failure. It is my understanding that they are working on calibrating this issue as it is a common complaint in the department. Also they often switch benchmarks mid half thusly making a bonus increasingly difficult. I still give them a 5 star rating because PayPal is often voted the best place to work in Omaha and I really don't have any other Cons to list and they can be easily remedied.

headline: Good company
pros: Innovation, technology, amazing industry, huge opportunity to change people's live.  Good brand recognition globally, leader in the market,
cons: Extremely bureaucratic, tons of processes, work in silos, lack of collaboration culture, no shared priorities, difficult to have things done, too US centric

headline: Build A Great Career Here!
pros: Great company with a compelling vision and amazing growth.  Great place to build and grow your career. Strong culture that embraces diversity and inclusion. Amazing benefits and pay.
cons: Need to continue to focus on delivering strong product offerings for our customers.

headline: Good money, no progress
pros: Good work, well paid, good parties
cons: no direct progress, poor management and leadership

headline: Customer Solutions Rep
pros: Benefits were excellent. Same Schedule and hours. Growth.
cons: Management was not on same page. A lot of turn over in management.

headline: Poor Leadership
pros: Excellent Benefits, Good subsidized food, Great Campus
cons: Leadership is clueless. Mass layoffs happened in Feb'15 and people were fired without any rhyme or reason. Some leaders are naive. There is no way to audit their behavior. Grossly incompetent people are given promotions and made Directors. Promotions are based on one's ability to tune the right people not on one's efforts. There is a reason why the company attracted Activist Investors such as Icahn.

headline: Good Place to Work
pros: Good place to work, challending enviroment
cons: Work Life Balance and middle management incompetence

headline: Good environment
pros: Environement is good for work.
cons: Don't expect for a KT from your seniors when you join the company

headline: Analyze accounts to determine their legitimacy and identify fraud trends in order to mitigate potential money losses.
pros: Competitive salaries, good work environment, high qualified management, excellent benefits, promotion prospects.... wellness in general.
cons: Certainly the only one I could think of is the fact PayPal does not have headquarters in my home city!

headline: awesome work place
pros: good package, nice packs, good work balance. free cab
cons: layoff is big problem here but company is awesome

headline: Sr. Manager - Analytics
pros: High growth company, lots of opportunities to leverage analytics to drive the business.
cons: Has become a bit bureaucratic, decisions are sometimes slow.

headline: anonymous
pros: Good Benefit, Work life balance, fun work place
cons: Take very long to make decisions. A lot of meetings, but nothing gets done at the end of the day.

headline: anonymous

cons: Take very long to make decisions. A lot of meetings, but nothing gets done at the end of the day.

headline: Lot to compete with
pros:
Good work life balance
Good work life balance
cons:
No free food .No offsites
No free food .No offsites

headline: Paypal Contractor
pros: Flexible hours, great learning, nice building, nice people, full time conversion opportunities
cons: Messy culture, lots of people leaving, cafeteria isn't so good, people don't feel appreciated, work life balance could be lacking

headline: Great People, Management Could Improve
pros: People at PayPal are great to work with.  Salary is good.  You are recognized for your contributions.
cons: Managers are very political animals.  The develop infrastructure needs to be modernized.

headline: Overview
pros: Great benefits.  Great place to work for.
cons: No cons at this time.

headline: A great place to work
pros:
- Ambiance de travail collaboratif
- opportunité de carrière
- bureaux parisien bien situé et très sympa
- international, innovant et sympa
- bonne rémunération et un mois sabbatique au bout de 5ans de boite
cons:
- pas de gros inconvénients 
- Subit les décisions du siège
- Grosse région à gérer

headline: Great atmosphere, great direct supervisors - horrible employee tools
pros:
Atmosphere - Generally, the team leaders and the next two tiers of supervisors are really good at keeping work as fun as it can be.

Benefits - paid parental leave, pto, sick leave, tuition reimbursement, etc.

Team leaders - nearly all are very friendly. It doesn't feel like 'us vs. them'

Decent wage- I've been here for 2.5 years. Started at $12.00 and am now making $15.50/hour
cons:
Technical issues. All the time. 
None of the tools that teammates use on a day to day basis seem to be guaranteed to work.

headline: Fraud Agent, Dublin
pros: Good place to start when your are without third level education/degree and want to step up in the financial services industry etc. PayPal offer jobs to un- and semi-skilled workers and offer funding for education. Many opportunities in Risk & Compliance areas at a lower level. Additional benefits include Pension, Health Insurance, Free car park and a subsidised canteen.
cons:
Siloed Organisation, Call Centre Environment. 
Hard to drive changes. 
Somewhat disappointing quality of middle management (they often can't provide the required support for career growth). Pay is below to what the direct competition would pay. Low bonus and pay increases whether you are a low or high performer. It matters more who you know than what you know.

headline: The best place from every aspect
author_position: Working for Past 6 Months Sse III
pros:
Value for innovative thought
Your work apart from sprint activities are highly appreciated 
Completely opposite to service based industry
Apart from work you have option to learn and research
Can learn important stuff like software behaviour on very large traffic etc etx
cons: U will be part of a big system..It has its cons

headline: Frustrating
pros: Good benefits including sabbatical leave
cons: Minimal opportunities for advancements and employee satisfaction no longer seems to be a concern

headline: Homogeneous team and culture of meh
pros: Good compensation and work life balance. This is why most people work here.
cons: People are hired and promoted by relationships only. Entire leadership teams are of same nationality who speak well but don't have any clue on how to manage engineering teams. Too many metrics and dashboards are fabricated. Code quality is a joke as developers and leaders are all timeline driven without nearly enough interest for investing in developer productivity, tooling, education, and testing. Branching hell adopted to control the poor build and code quality before release.

headline: Good Place work . PayPal
pros:
Good work culture . 
Handsome benefits and Restricted Stock Units
Cool work with less stress.
cons:
Health insurance benefits can be better
History of layoffs

headline: Sinking ship
pros: Great launchpad in the payments industry, good location, nice campus, tennis courts, badminton courts, soccer fields, tons of parking space, flexible timings, two huge cafeteria serving delicious food
cons: The great leaders have either left or are leaving. PayPal products are getting deprecated by the start up it acquired (Braintree). Braintree management is struggling to scale up

headline: Fantastic company
pros: Great company culture. The company will do a lot to encourage your professional development as an individual , not only in the light of staying with PayPal. There is a great family spirit there, management is very relaxed in terms of where you work from and working hours, fantastic extras such as a fridge full of food for those days when you can't go and get lunch. The offices are generally in great locations, the UK one is in Richmond, right by the river.
cons: The company has grown and has gone through a lot of changes , at times there was a bit of destabilisation with 4 reorgs in 3 years. At times, you might struggle to progress due to a headcount freeze but they are open to offering a transfer to another team in case you get bored of the job.

headline: Re: Inside Sales
pros:
Good team to work with.. Great culture of helping each other

Commission structure well designed and rewards high achievement
cons:
Lack of opportunities 
Slow processes, hard to move prospects through the sales process

headline: software developer
pros: good work-life balance, friendly atmosphere, lots of cool stuff around. reasonable compensation
cons: not every team works on challenging/interesting projects, only a few teams do. Sometimes talented people are not recognized properly by management.

headline: Customer solution Agent
pros: Paypal is a result oriented company where hard work are apprecited and rewarded
cons: Flexible to work as you can choose your shift time

headline: It's ok for now...
pros:
Benefits are decent 
Free soda and sparkling water 
Vendors onsite for breakfast and lunch so you don't have to waste part of your lunch break traveling
Awesome over the top Christmas party 
Annual Family day at Hershey park
Nice onsite Gym with trainer and different classes during the week
Co-workers and "most" management are laid back and cool 
Recognition of top performers with a luncheon 
Quarterly bonus opportunity
cons:
I've been working here for 2yrs and it's been sufficient to get me by. It's not a place I see myself staying for the long haul. I don't see much room for advancement unless you're someone's favorite. The turn over rate is ridiculous. The pay is low compared to other companies and for them to be a billion dollar company themselves. 
Having to take on more responsibility but the pay rate doesn't increase.
They change metrics on you at the drop of a dime so it's difficult for you to meet criteria to make bonus payout.
I think it's all politics

headline: Great Company
pros: Growing technology company, established name, room to grow your career.
cons: Some disorganization of leadership, politics.

headline: MBA Intern
pros: Collaborative, friendly, work-life balance, smart.
cons: Horrible HR is not connected with the company.

NICE, COMFORTABLE, NEAT
smart people
Nice pros

WORK WITH COMPUTER
Nice atmosphere
boring sometimes

headline: hard experience
pros: super nice people. steady income
cons: worst management ever. zero humanity

headline: Intern Marketing
pros:
- Great working environment
- Helpful friendly employees
- Interesting work
- Good salary for intern
- Access to all departments
cons: No cons in terms of working environment and employees. Potentially could have had more work although as an Intern responsibilities are understandably limited

headline: Good Company for Freshers and not for experienced
pros: You get pampered with things like things to eat and drink at cafeteria, Wifi buses, nice work desk, game room and many events.
cons:
No good hikes
Getting promotion might takes more than 5 years for mid and seniors. Only for freshers, promotion happens in a year and that too just 1 promotion.
Most of the team have untalented Managers except a few good ones from development. All other vertical managers like engineering, IT, QA, DW etc are worst.

headline: Check account for potential account takeover.
pros: Simple job with minimal calls. Easy to understand not many responsibilities. You can coast through the job without thinking very much about what you are doing. You get paid out in stock and good 401k benefits. You have tuition reimbursement if it aligns with the company's needs.

headline: PayPal Chandler
pros:
Short answer:  it's a call center.

Long answer:  Prior to working at PayPal, I had never worked at a call center (and I never intend to again) but this is probably one of the better call centers in the Phoenix area.  The campus is up-to-date, clean, has a nice gym and cafeteria, a parking structure, etc.  If I wanted to make a career out of customer service, I'd have probably stayed here.  I made some good friends and learned some valuable skills that led me to my next job.
cons: That being said, I wouldn't recommend this as a good place to work for someone who has strong career ambitions or anything more than a high school diploma.  The company (at least at its operations centers in Chandler, Hunt Valley, and Omaha) doesn't place any value on formal education and pays poorly compared to its competitors.  Bring up your poor pay to management and get labeled as a whiner, so you might as well not even try (by the way, they won't negotiate salary with you from the onset either.  Nice try.) You'll also work some really strange hours (think Wednesday through Saturday) for several years before you get a more "normal" shift, if you ever get one.  The red tape and bureaucracy were unbearable at PayPal, and the company was quick to lay off employees after management changes occur (which, by the way, happens all the time).  Don't be fooled by the Phoenix Business Journal's 2014 "Best Places to Work" survey, either.  Management set aside time for employees to take the survey and coaxed employees into giving positive responses to the survey.  PayPal isn't listed as a top place to work on any other reputable employment publication websites.  This is probably a good place to work for some, but it wasn't for me.  I'd probably have looked elsewhere a few years ago if I knew that I'd be writing a review like the one I just did.

headline: Unprofessional, lack of customer focus, and grossly underpaid employees.
pros: Benefits are decent (especially for new parents). Various shift options are available (although management is soon changing that to only four basic shifts).
cons: Stats are more important than the customer. Stats are more important than BSA/AML Compliance regulations (agents are expected to work cases quickly and, if a case is taking too long, agents are told to "cut it off" instead of completing a thorough investigation). Stats are more important then the employee (i.e., even if the city is shut down due to a major snow day, employees are expected to be at work and may even be "written up" if they do not show up that day due to the weather). Stats remain the same over the course of years even if the tasks change and become much more complicated. Even if an entire segment of a department is struggling with stats, management will not reconsider numbers or take into account the type of work that is being done. Instead, they will have meetings where employees are told that management "may have to fire the majority of the department" if the stats aren't met. Tenured phone agents are held to stats of people in different (easier) segments to "challenge" them, then when they are unable to meet those stats, they are denied a bonus because they "didn't meet the requirements of their peers". The department I am in (BSA/AML Compliance is grossly underpaid. I make $16/hr and just received an offer letter from a local bank for over $24/hr. When I shared this information with Paypal management, I found out later, managers had told their employees that I was "lying about the pay" offered to me. I have since accepted the offer and put in my two-weeks notice at PayPal.

headline: Good Little Robots
pros: Decent pay, good benefits, nice campus with lots of amenities.
cons:
Micro-management to the extreme. Your computer screens are recorded from the moment you login to the moment you logoff. It's your supervisor's job to review your actions/interactions weekly and ding you whenever a mistake is made; for example replying to an email sent to the team while you're clocked into a productive task. This power can and will be used against you. If your supervisor wants you gone they will monitor everything until they find something to write you up on.

The internal promotion/application system is bad. You pick 5 jobs you'd like and whenever a position opens up, they look at everyone who has that job in their #1 spot and whoever has the current highest stats will get picked without an interview. So if you transfer into a job that's not your strong suit you will be trapped in that position until you leave the company if you never out-perform your coworkers. We had three senior agent positions open in our department and all three positions went to people outside of the department with no experience in our field. So it was over a year before they were of any use to us as Senior Agents on the team.

There is so much back-stabbing they could film a reality TV show there. One of my coworkers was late for work one day and forgot to clock in. When he realized this he emailed the supervisor saying he was late and forgot to clock in and asked her to edit his timecard. He didn't know for sure so he gave an approximate time and she made the adjustment. She then looked at the timestamp of his badge swipe at the front doors and saw it was a few minutes after the time he told her. So she fired him for trying to scam the company out of a few minutes of paid time. I was fired because I sent an email, stats for our team, while clocked into a "productive task". I know of people who were fired because they clocked out to break before closing out of the case they were working on.

If you are not a perfect little robot and your supervisor doesn't like you, they will use everything in their power to get you out the door because there's plenty of other robots who want off the phones.

headline: It was a good place to work before they split from eBay
pros: Good work life balance.  Benefits are great.  Especially the 5 year sabbatical leave.  I started when the company first started up, so my pay was much better than what they pay now.  When eBay took over, it was a great place to work and not a lot of drama.
cons: If you are on the phones, you can expect to deal with upset customers all day long.  After the split from eBay, the company has started a revolving door policy with employees.  Getting rid of loyal employees that had been there for a long time and were getting paid better, so out the door.  I was at the top of my pay grade and my bosses kept after me about retirement.  They seemed very determined to get rid of me.  They use Medalia surveys for customer satisfaction metrics and it is junk science at best.  I had many surveys that should have been appealed, but upper management did nothing.  Nobody uses common sense.  They put me on an action plan and I was doing quite well, but the let me go regardless on some trivial issues.  The main goal was to get rid of me as I was making about twice the salary of an average agent.  If you are hiring on to the call center, my advice is to beware.  You get wrote up constantly and micromanaged to the point where the stress is unbearable.  The metrics they hold you to is almost unreachable.  You deal with calls all day long that cannot be resolved and you are constantly saying no to the customer and they expect way too much out of you.

headline: Politics politics and more politics
pros:
Lot of scope for learning. You will have exposure to almost anything that you are interested in. 
Frequent training sessions to learn a lot on Payments and Technology.
Some groups have really very good engineers who are both competitive and helpful at the same time.
cons:
Upward mobility is reserved for people with no technical skills but great at cronyism

Product team in the most important non payment group is a joke, but unfortunately they have ears of Directors and higher ups. Since there is no "real" interactive session with engineers, management has no clue of reality and is mis guided by the product team. Product teams ends up getting all the credit / promotions for the work done by engineering team. This is depressing and sad.

Very traditional management style. "Yes Sir / Madam" is most welcome. If there is any dis agreement or alternate view points, ideas are not fought, people who brought them up will be under the bus.

Frequent re-orgs and lack of accountability at management level is just annoying. Huge mistakes by management are simply ignored / rewarded. Engineers pay the price almost always by putting in long hours and weekends to cover up for the mistakes done by management.

headline: Best Place to Work in SG
pros:
I started working from contractor until I got converted to full-time employee. I've had experience working for several companies in SG, so I know which company treats their employee badly and which company take care their employee. Suffice to say, in my opinion, PayPal is one of the best employers in SG. There are several reviews here in glassdoor that said about office politic and all. I can only say that office politics are everywhere regardless of company we just need to know how to handle it (read a lot of career/professional website if you are clueless)

- Excellent work life balance (working from home, etc), if not one of the best in SG that promotes this.
- Great salary and benefits.
- Exposure to latest technology and fintech industry leader.
cons:
- At times, overengineering design and solution. It's better to think design and solution that are simple yet extensible rather than thinking on how to come up with a silver bullet solution. That silver bullet might be useless when facing against the change on requirements.
- It's a big and distributed company, so expect overhead in their process.
- Legacy codes are terrible (because of the way previous engineers wrote it not because of language), which causing a misconception and argument on C++ vs Java. Both languages are good if being used properly and both can be terrible if they aren't written properly.
- It can be harsh at times during restructuring period.
- Blaming culture is everywhere (esp, across departments), you must know how to cover your back. Issue or failure will always be there. Rather than point the finger at someone, it's better to deal with the issues and learn from it. After all, you are trying to achieve the same goal.

headline: NO LONGER  "Best Place to Work"
pros: Healthy benefits are good and they start right away. That's a good thing because most employees get serious anxiety from working here so half the company needs the FMLA
cons: Yes PayPal was voted "best place to work" but that was in 2014. A lot has changed as we enter 2016. The moral has changed. The vibe sucks and no one seems happy anymore. They started hiring anyone just to have a warm body in a seat. With that came ghetto people, lazy people and people who dress completely sloppy and basically in their pajamas. You can't bring your lunch because it will just get stolen from the fridges. And the food available to buy is overpriced. And no one will do anything about lunches being stolen daily. Who steals someone's entire lunch from the fridge or freezer?? And what management just looks the other way about it?? People gossip here including the upper management. Out of ALL the departments here, maybe 2 of them are worth it. All other depts "CS, disputes, fraud" they are all stressful and underpaid.

headline: Financial analyst
pros: Very exciting times to work here post-split from eBay, with more opportunities to expand business with other major e-retailers/service vendors  that we could not consider partnerships with before. Product pipeline is strong and service offering/outreach surpasses its competitors, especially for cross-border transactions.
cons:
Very very bureaucratic & slow for what they consider themselves as a "tech" company. A lot of ex-bank/traditional conglomerate executives have on-boarded over the periods, which supposedly add more managerial insight in the decision making process, but also flooded the stakeholder pool and significantly slows down the execution speed with unnecessarily long approval chains and redundant reviews.  
Also very US-centric mindset, upper management has a hard time understanding how business practices in other regions can impact the respective P&L structures, and delegation of decision-making power to regional management is sparse.

headline: PayPal Customer Service
