headline: Majority of employees are contractors
pros: Good environment to work in. Has some of the common tech company office benefits such as free drinks (soda and coffee), fruits, bagels, cereal, etc.
cons: The majority of the workers are contractors which means no benefits for them.

headline: Used to be a great company to work for.
pros: Nice Facility, Good parking situation
cons:
High Turnover, Poor Management, Unrealistic Expectations, Unprofessional mid level management, No transparency, Employees have no voice. 

PayPal works hard to promote it's work environment and culture during the quarter leading up to the time the "Best Place to Work" survey is taken. Following the survey, there are a large number of terminations. The company is not growing in physical size/Employee capacity but yet are constantly hiring. It's common practice for both Team Leaders and Group Leaders to have favorites and hold grudges. Management is always saying they're looking for motivated people and for people to take charge of projects. The reality of this situation is that they put these motivated people into Supervisor internships with a promise of a permanent spot only put them back on the floor in their previous position with no compensation for any bonuses or incentives missed. Those people who are motivated enough to start projects to help their co-workers perform their jobs better are then despised by the Team Leaders because those employee's are doing the Team Leader's jobs. They say they want to make it easy for employees to get to the positions they want to be in and to move up in the company. The reality is that they have made the process so entirely convoluted and difficult that the people with the knowledge and skills for those positions are overlooked for an unqualified candidate.

A couple of years back, PayPal wasn't such a cut throat company to work for, management seemed to have a genuine care for their employees happiness and advancement within the company. Since the split from eBay was announced things took a turn for the worse, management no longer communicated important decisions to the employees, team leaders were turned against their teams and became puppets to corporate. If they voiced their opinion about corporate's decisions they were put on warning or terminated. This trickled down to every employee and created a very tense workplace with everyone fearing for their job. It was no longer enjoyable to show up to work and instead became very stressful. Seeing entire teams and droves of people get terminated after the "Best Places to Work" survey was taken doesn't help with the feeling of dread either. Unfortunately this company is managing themselves into the ground and refuse to see that for themselves. Again, used to be an amazing place to work but really became a stressful mess after the eBay/PayPal split was announced.

headline: Executive Escalations Specialist
pros: This is a growing company with a lot of respect.  The benefits are fantastic.  I like the hours I work.
cons: The type of work does not fit my degrees.  It is very difficult to get past a certain employment level.

headline: Opportunity missed!
pros: Great campus, good benefits, lots of opportunity as a business, and some good people trying to make a difference. But .....
cons: Poor, inexperienced and disorganized senior management and leadership, continuous re-organizations, lack of corporate alignment; plenty of self interested agenda's, and a culture of 'Me' versus 'Us.' A lot of leaders faking it. In terms of process, discipline and expertise in people and process, PayPal is very poor. Business is heavily dependent on eBay customer base. Buy or sell stock? Sell!

headline: poor management
pros: Nice campus and facilities. it had build a good foundation in terms of architecture and platform.
cons: The company likes to re-org frequently. First and middle layer managements are lack of basic management skills and lack of diversity in terms of ethnic group. As a result, promotions and annual rating can be very bias and lack of fairness.

headline: Used to be..
pros:
* Swell company once. Built great products, the focus was on building products. Once is the keyword
* Really smart co-workers
* Once, you could either go full corporate or startup if you can make it here
cons:
* Not building products anymore, just cruising on earlier steam - if you count out some VPs pet projects which'll never make production
* Now focussing way too much on people. Not in a good way. Like you have to "evangelize" certain tech to survive. You gotta drink that kool-aid all the way down to make it. They are not even hiding it - look at the job descriptions. With that come all the bad things: politics, groupism..
* Now, if you are here, you either can't make it to the top-tier or you made a wrong choice in choosing a "secure" job
* Middle management is hopelessly entrenched - no matter who's at the top, they are very good at generating smoke and wind. Lower order is over-worked, messed with on a regular basis for no reason.
* Stack ranking and idiotic metrics will measure your performance.

headline: Interesting Times Ahead
pros:
There seems to be a new culture and movement brought it by our new CEO Dan and his staff. There are a lot of exciting things happening and the company will have the opportunity to show what it can do on its own now that is has separated from eBay inc.

Competitive Pay, Great Benefits
cons:
Since the split, it seems a lot of organizations have lost their direction. A lot of the talent was split among the two companies and a lot of teams are trying to figure out where they are going now that some of their leaders are gone. I think eventually it will get settled. After all this is expected after a split, but it's the team members that decide to stay instead of jumping ship that are paying the price.

In my experience, career growth opportunities have been very limited.

The food is awful and expensive!

headline: Good Training ground for Payments / Technology for employees from Financial services
pros:
Paypal is one of the few technology companies where employees from financial institutions can join at a lateral level or even a role with higher seniority than the one they held at a financial institution. 

It is a recognized name in Silicon Valley and can be a great training ground in product management, technology, payments and user experiences

While it has all the issues associated with working for a large company, one is recognized for hard work, creativity and desire to collaborate across teams.
cons:
1) Not considered to be one of the "hot" valley companies and is not in the same league as Google / Apple / Facebook

2) Future a bit unsure after split from Ebay

3) It feels like Paypal is resting on its past laurels and glory versus building a product for the future

pros: Great coworkers, decent pay, lots of opportunity to grow skill set
cons: Work life balance non existent j

headline: PayPal Dublin office
pros: It is a big company and there are new roles constantly opening. There is a good in house gym and canteen.
cons:
Biggest downsize: the poor quality of the basic and middle managers.
Mostly call center type of management with lack of skills/knowledge of their area or very narrow minded managers for an Internet company of this size. Managers that got to their positions only because they were in the company for long.

headline: Good with the bad
pros: PayPal has great hiring practices so my colleagues were some of the best and brightest folks I had the privilege of working with.
cons: In a nutshell: poor management.  Too many fiefdoms and not enough support for business initiatives.  Sales ran the company due to a co-founder still sticking around long past his due date.  Also product engineering was a complete mess.

headline: Great Company
pros:
Very good enviroment, good people, international atmosphere.
Good company to have on Cv.
cons: Salaries and benefit levels are lower than in other American big Corporates

headline: Senior Manager
pros: High growth potential since split from eBay.
cons: Bureaucracy has increased as the company grows.

headline: csr
pros: money and benefits and gym
cons: management acts like they are in HS

headline: Software Engineer Intern
pros: Free lunches, amazing company culture, flexible hours and no stigma to work overtime
cons: No downsides of working at PayPal

headline: Awesome company
pros: Worked with amazing people who were smart and motivated. You also have the opportunity to make a difference.
cons: At the time, the relationship with Ebay was distracting and really prevented people from moving the Paypal mission beyond to its fullest potential. That should be changed now.

headline: Business Support Specialist
pros: Loved customers set up their business accounts.  Loved speaking to customers from all over the world to help them with any issues they may have regarding sales and issues with sales.
cons: People took out their problems on you.  Did not accept accountability of problems.

headline: Program Manager observor
pros: profitable company, offer nice perks.
cons: Extremely political environment. Hiring for new positions were more based on hiring manager's cultural familiarity with the interviewee than the experience or education of the other candidates.

headline: Consultant
pros: PayPal employees are collaborative, and it's a great environment to work in.
cons: Cross platform integration is not optimal.

headline: Bad place to work
pros: I seriously don't have anything to say here. If you are a moron, this is the place to be.
cons: sexually harassed. So what about that

headline: Contract
pros: Great culture, great product, interesting
cons: Very little con, it is a great place

headline: Program Manager
pros: Good salary, perks, benefits, flex-time in real sense, generally care about employees.
cons: Synergy among groups is very poor, very stressful work, no clarity on R&R, multiple programs that business just wants to get done, not enough Program managers to support them. Managers believe PMs are machines that can produce magic. Extremely poor people management, nit-picky when it comes to emails, presentations etc

headline: Sr. Product Manager
cons: Matrix environment can make it hard to get work done

headline: Great Place
pros: Very family friendly.  Good benefits.  Great people.
cons: Recent reorganizations have made it challenging to find the people you need to get a task done.

headline: Merchant Risk Agent
pros:
Good Benefits - Healthcare, pension, stocks
Permanent positions
Established company
cons:
Management making changes that effect employees without consulting first
Do anything to cut money but send emails telling us how much money the company is making
Cut Bonus
Took a weeks salary from us last year
Give feedback to be told you are negative
Supervisors can tend to pick favorites and give them opportunities  while holding other people back

headline: Mostly a great Place to be at
pros:
- Its the Leader in the Payment industry , so you get to work at a good tehcnical stack and pretty good people


- A lot of good work is being done here, but getting that depends on which team you are in.

- Work Life Balance is pretty good across most of the teams

-Cab Facilities through out the city(Chennai)

- Sabbatical Program(1 month leave) after 5 years

- Competitive Pay

-The Recreational Facilities are pretty good - T.T , Foosball, Gym, BasketBall Court, Badminton Court, Yoga Classes, Dance Classes

-A lot of celebrations happen at various times.
cons: Not any big ones worth mentioning. All Usual stuff.

headline: A lot has changed in 10 years!
pros: They offer great benefits. Management does a better job at communicating with us than other companies I have worked for in the past. They are flexible with work schedules so as to provide a work/life balance, such as offering 4 10's instead of 5 8-hour days a week. The flexible work schedules and the fact that I don't have to take work home with me is what has kept me at PayPal all these years.
cons: The pay may be considered to be really good for most people, but I've worked for PayPal for going on 10 years and I started at $13 and some change per hour. I'm currently at $17.35 per hour. They could certainly pay employees better than that, for those who have been with the company as long as I have! There's not much room for growth unless you want to move into management; otherwise, you can bounce from department to department and hope to find something that works for you. It's unfortunate that they don't want to utilize the talents of their employees to the fullest. When I started working for PayPal, it was an awesome place to work, but it's become more corporate over the years. Consequently, there's not as much perks as there used to be. Despite all this, they want you to rate them the #1 Best Place to Work. Yeah right.

headline: company culture has been changed so much
pros: It has very nice campus and facilities.
cons:
Company reorg is quite often and culture has been changed so much. 
Promotion and annual rating are sometimes unfair.

headline: Great place to work.
pros:
Multinational,  diversity, work/life balance, innovation.
Great place to develop and learn, great team mates and managers. 
Chance to be prompted.
cons: Benefits, free parking, far from city centre, no free food in the employees restaurant. Usually benefots are less compare to other web companies in Dublin.

headline: Not so great anymore
pros: Great bonus potential and lots of PTO.  Great autonomy to work the hours that fit me.  Great coworkers
cons: Just raised the rate for Paypal transactions in my sales band by .07 to a full percent across the board.  That's a 35 percent rate hike folks!!

headline: Fraud Prevention
pros: Modern facilities, advancement opportunities, nice  cafeteria
cons: Treated more like a number than an individual

headline: Highly political environment, weak management, leaders
pros: work life balance, decent salary, free transportation, free meal pass
cons:
- extremely political environment,
- weak middle management and leaders, 
- filled with old timers or AWFs (contract employees) or converted AWFs who are not ready to change or adapt any new technology,
- Re-orgs every 6-9 months create a lot of churn,
- lot of new ideas and projects are taken, left in middle and never launched.

headline: Debit card Agent
pros: Nurturing environment, amazing co workers, tons of support to succeed at your job, fun environment, talent development
cons: call center, can get boring

headline: Software Engineer
pros:
It really differs from team to team, but a lot of groups have an excellent work-life balance. 
Also, the benefits are good - the gym is fantastic (and free), there are free bagels on Wednesdays, free coffee and milk, and snacks.
cons: Again, the experience differs from team to team. A lot of groups don't have a good work-life balance - on my first team, we had to show up to the office every day and stay until 6:00 or later. A lot of teams also don't care about code quality or follow good process. I've seen a fair amount of code that was extremely poorly written and a number of questionable design decisions. It just seems like most employees just come in for the paycheck - very few people actually care about coding or computers.

headline: Team Lead
pros: Great Career progress, big opportunity to move within the company.  Good training program, especially the yearly compliance training.  Good PDP program
cons: Things sometimes is not done by merit. Favouritism should be stamped out.  You can easily be a target if you make a mistake and any opportunity that present itself you are done with the company

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros: Paypal had great benefits and an awesome culture to be involved in.  After working other jobs with a similar role it was shocking to be treated so well.
cons: During the holidays it gets really busy.

headline: software engineer intern
pros: good work environment. really hope to become full time here
cons: work life balance needed to be improved

headline: Summer Intern
pros: Everyone treated you incredibly well. Managers were looking out for you and made sure you learned as much as you could. Not to mention it was good pay and everything was paid for by them
cons: nothing, i loved the experience

headline: Sr. Manager Engineering
pros: Payment industry experience, team logistics, monetary benefit
cons: Less challenging going forward as a separate company

headline: Extreme politics, arrogant middle-management and bureaucratic
pros: Most people are friendly, good work-life balance, some teams have decent work. If you love booze, you can party!
cons:
1) I can see politics and favouritism everywhere. There are only 2 kinds of people here: 'workers' and 'talkers'. People who do the hard work are literally treated like throw-away tissue-papers. But people who do all the talking are considered rockstars. I know people who do absolutely nothing, talk to the 'workers' in the team and when it comes to meetings, talk about the work that the 'workers' do and eventually they get promoted. The 'workers' have to fight really-hard for their career growth. If you are a quality engineer and know a little bit about the end-to-end of the product you are testing and if you have great communication skills, then PayPal is the place to be in. Forget about testing, you don't have to do that. The 'workers' will take the blame in case something breaks, but you can have a ball here, with people showering praises for the work that you weren't even involved in.

2) As a direct result of the favouritism shown to a selected set of people, they start to think they are God-level. So they start to become arrogant. I have seen mails and code reviews exchanged with sparks of arrogance thrown in (even if they don't know what the heck they are talking about). This creates conflict and in result, the good workers start leaving the company.

headline: Innovative and flush with cash for acquisitions
pros: Very talented people to work with and cutting edge technologies.  It is a pleasure to work for a company that focuses on making financial transactions as friction free as possible for everyone.
cons: Reorganization merry go round every 8 months.  It is challenging to know who we are going to report to next and this can cause consternation, moral spikes and attrition.

headline: Good company, interesting work
pros: Great people to work with and learned tons of interesting stuff on the job. People were friendly and very willing to help, and as long as you got your stuff done you didn't have to keep specific hours.
cons: Felt a little bit corporate (lots of meetings and so forth) but I suppose that's to be expected in a large company such as PayPal.

headline: Busy
pros: Dealing with as many as 70 different customers a day.  It has been a year since Bill Me Later became PayPal Credit, and we are still dealing with customer harassment over it.  Hopefully that should level out soon, otherwise, company is a pretty fair place to work.
cons: Still a lot of hiccups even though it is no longer a startup by any means.

headline: Get Ready to Be Burnt Out
pros: The company overall is very good. The benefits are better than most other places and there is matching 401K program as well as company stock options.
cons: I've been here for a little over 2 years and I've begun to hate my job more and more every day. Don't get me wrong some days can be phenomenal and you can feel very proud to be working here. But there are some days when you can't believe you are still here.

headline: account manager
pros: free gym, nice atmosphere according the dpt
cons: evolution limited, no free food, too much processes

headline: It's a bank
pros: most of the management who were in over their heads is gone.  Most likely more opportunity now with the split from eBay.
cons: big and cumbersome - if you're looking for opportunities to innovate this isn't it.  It's a financial services company, not a technology-focused, and all the priorities that go along with that.

headline: Intern, Platform Infrastructure team
pros: Nice work culture. A lot to learn about cloud and devops from the Platform Infrastructure team. Friendly Managers and engineers. You can reach out to the Director or VP for a suggestion or seeking advice. Events every week. Great fussball players around!
cons: Best for a guy who wants to learn about building secure, reliable and fault tolerant systems for billions of customers, but not the place for someone who wants build and break things daily.

headline: No major surprises
pros: PayPal is in a position for long term strength as a company. Payments are highly regulated, so they'll grow one way or another.
cons: Old school blandness, little innovation (probably by design), uninspiring work environment. Feels like a place to retire.

headline: Great benefits, great products
pros: Amazing place to grow your career at scale.  Start uppy feel with strong financial base.
cons: No major cons, though you need to be at the HQ to move career forward.

headline: Customer Solutions Rep
pros: Great company, good employee benefit structure. Starting pay is good. Able to think on your own. Environment is nice. Management is great.
cons: There aren't too many cons about this company other than scheduling if you have kids but they may work with you.

headline: Great !!
pros: Great company! I lived it and loved it. Best years of my life, worked very hard, company was consuming and engaging in a very good way. I'd do it all over again. Best pay, great career, stimulating to the core, dynamic and constantly challenging and rewarding at the same time. Loved San Jose campus, gym and the cafe.
cons: Not sure why but there was way too much management churn! 7 or 8 presidents came and went in 10 years. Lately there was an influx of refugees from the eBay side. They are toxic.

headline: collections
pros: good benefits, good work environment, good management style,
cons: Its hard to move up within different departments.

headline: Good Company
pros: Flexible working time and comfortable environment
cons: not agile working environment although we have tried to be since 1 year ago

headline: Business Development
pros:
Excellent company, financially solid, well positioned, great recent acquisitions that have put us on a fantastic trajectory. 

Recent IPO
Leadership/Executive Team 
People give a damn about you here, not just about how well you are performing!!! But how well you're doing personally, mentally and emotionally.
cons:
It is a large company, there are a lot of people to compete with.  

TBD - How The Street reacts to PYPL.

headline: Account Manager
pros: Very nice work atmosphere, great team.
cons: too many processes, hard to make change

headline: PayPal
pros: Great Place to work , great.
cons: none to speak of at the moment.

headline: I like it here 😊
pros:
Work with a great bunch of people
Gym
Vhi
They do try to give staff good work life balance
cons: Being measured on surveys is a pot luck way of measuring you,your bonus depends on some customer's humour on the day or tech glitches or someone not liking our policies

headline: Good and bad
pros: Great benefits. Lot of great people who work at PayPal. There can be great opportunities.
cons: They don't pay well compared to similar roles at other companies. PayPal is so big that you literally are a number. Some people absolutely love their job at PayPal and other people hate it.

headline: No design culture. Very confused, highly political place. No growth!
pros:
Honestly. There are no pros. Sorry..!

You can put some work experience in your resume and that is all. 
Salary is good if you are full-timer/director levels. 
Flexible schedule, but this gets annoying since people are too laid back sometimes (aka family errands).
cons:
Where do I even begin?
Very political place. Nothing gets done. Nothing gets shipped.
No design culture. Every designer acts like a product manager/architect; thus design direction gets diluted- design starts and ends with a really ugly, clunky MVP. 

No design emphasis. Everything is either really rushed or slow (never gets shipped).
Design has no voice in the company that we always get slapped by product business priorities (which changes every week). The leadership team is not transparent at all; you will suffer. Basically, everyone is a design lead, director or some leadership level. 

If you are looking for an opportunity here (and is considering), I highly recommend avoiding this team.

headline: Customer solutions rep
pros: Awesome management , lots of employee discounts, keep employees in mind and center of business
cons: Strict supervision , too many snitches people should learn to mind their business

headline: Account Manager
pros: very stable, almost never work overtime, work-life balance, good training, good employee benefit, lot of opportunity, good working atmosphere, awesome data base and supportive equipment.
cons: Too comfortable staying at PayPal, you'll have to drive yourself very motivated to learn more.

headline: Working at PayPal outside of San Jose
pros: PayPal,  has been a great place to work over the last 6+ years.  In my organization the pace has been fast and the challenges keep things new.  I have work with incredible talented people and learned more then expected about payments.
cons: The downside is PayPal still struggle to be a global company,   most of the senior opportunities are in San Jose,   so at some point in many team you hit a cap.

headline: Senior Teammate
pros: Great teammates and culture for a call center.
cons: Change, be prepared for it!

headline: Bill me Later
pros: Good environment , smart people
cons: Business is disconnected from PayPal in San Jose . Unprofessional culture . lack of diversity. Poor development of talent

headline: company review
pros: salary was fantastic.  loved the job but you work all the time.  constantly oncall
cons: management is horrible.  not sure how they stick around but they all travel around and are in countless meetings getting nothing done

headline: Meh
pros: recognizable brand, always in expansion mode
cons: in order to really advance, you need to go to San Jose.  and they really need to just acquire Square and dump Here.

headline: Feeling like number, only - Customer Solution position
pros: Free gym, health insurance, paid holidays, sabbatical after 5 years, full pay on maternity leave, canteen with good value for food and salary every 4 weeks, giving you at end of year one extra salary.
cons:
Well, where to start? 
Let's start with the feeling as number first, the company has all the beautiful theory and beautiful phrases knowing as share purposes, commitment and behaviour! 
They are lovely, only in theory, because in practice it is completely different, they don't really care about you and treat you with warnings, PIP and dismissal if you do not meet the crazy and unreal targets!
They wait for you to be open, honest and direct, but if you do so, you will be in trouble and will never progress on company, you see the "lick as***" being promoted and have opportunity to move to other positions on different areas, but if you work hard and do your job well, it is not enough!
They pretend being worried about why so many people is leaving the company, but they don't really read the feedback and don't care much.

headline: Being Underpaid is the main reason for all people leaving this company
pros: Benefits, stock options, great coworkers that are very down to earth. Somewhat flexible scheduling.
cons: It's turned into a corporate monster. Its all about politics and private relationships when it comes to advancement past 15$p/h. To the point where a "fake it to make it" mentality is actually suggested by people in higher positions. Ineffective management system for this changing company. Long time employees not being fairly comps stars for increased responsibilities while new hires with minimal responsibilities and liabilities are hire in at 9 to 10 ratio of current compensation. To maintain momentum in advancement thru the company you must become a corporate lackey, potentially compromising your beliefs and morals for advancement. It all feels very robotic and cold yet overall communication is terrible,  at even a team leader level(supervisor). Often leaving employees learning from customers. The most common reason for employees leaving paypal is because the responsibilities given are not fairly compensated.

headline: Overall good company
pros: Good company to work at.
cons: Opportunities based on relationship with hierarchy

headline: Solid company, exciting times
pros: Product organization has supportive culture
cons: If you can't handle change, don't come here.

headline: Pretty Good
pros:
- Work Life Balance is great in most of the teams
- you get to work with brilliant people here. You can find very talented people at senior techincal positions & hence you can learn a lot.
- Pay is great & Annual Bonuses too are!
- Lot of Employee Engagement Activities : Hackathons, Festival Celebrations, Work Anniversary Awards, Lot of Cabs, WiFi enabled buses, 
- Fun & Lifestyle : Gym, Yoga & Dance Classes, Options for Playing games : Chennai Office has TT , Foosball, Badminton, Pool, Wii etc.
cons:
- They Have Internal Infrastructural Wrappers around all core frameworks: Web Services , Message Queues, DB Access etc. 

Although they are far efficient then Open Source alternatives , but they move you away from the basics. Little tough to work on open Source stuff later if you just use these tools to get your work done & not understand them well.

- Frequent Re-Orgs cause a lot of churn.

headline: Good

headline: Great Place to Work

headline: working as a qa and dev engineer

cons: alot of older folks who has dated working models or even not up to date in technologies. some engineers plays politics more than doing actual work.

headline: Decent place to work

cons: You will be just another body at a desk churning out stats

headline: Credit risk analyst

headline: Intern

cons: Drama with the eBay split.

headline: Great experience
pros:
- Smart, passionate co-workers.
- Great office
- Impactful work
- Treated like every other member of the team
- Lots of room to grow
cons: None, it was all a great experience. Disclaimer: It was my first intern experience.

headline: company
pros: Big and stable company with lot of upside
cons: Need to understand lot about the domain

headline: A great company to work for
pros:
The company works very hard to take good care of employees.
Benefits are really good and starting pay has been increasing as of recently. 
Occasional time of phones for development activities. 
Good job security in the contact center part of the company. 
A great place to start a career for some people.
Quarterly bonuses with potential to earn up to 12% of quarterly pay. 
Typically a good amount of offered voluntary overtime to those that want it.
cons:
At times customers can be very difficult to work with. 
Due to the nature of the business, having flexibility around your schedule can be limited.
While the company is experiencing rapid growth and encourages development, there is not the same growth of new positions. Therefor advancement can take years, even for the most productive employees. 
It's not for everyone. I've worked with some agents that absolutely love the job and others that hate it, just depends on your personality.

headline: Great Place to work
pros: Great benefits and a culture to promote from within. Some managers will help you develop and reach the position you desire in the company and have a lot of development tools available for your use.
cons: Most employees start on the call center floor. It is all about the handle time, not the complete answer to avoid multiple contact.

headline: Awesome company to work for
pros: Great company, great talent, nice colleagues. Everyone from top to bottom thrives for excellence. All the strategic decisions made at the top level are constantly informed to all rungs of employees. Executive Staff and Senior Staff are very receptive. In one word, great company to work for
cons: I don't see any downside in this copany

headline: Fine place to work
pros: Some interesting technologies to work on. My managers are competent and kind. The compensation is nice.
cons: The technology stack is outdated and unpleasant to work with. These is quite a bit of time wasted dealing with corporate concerns.

headline: Compliance Specialist
pros: Flexible schedule and work environment.  Worked from home 3 days a week.
cons: Not very diversed, company culture is non social.

headline: Business Support Supervisor
pros: Treat employees well, bonus for high performance, company values and ethics are strong. I would recommend working at PayPal if looking for a short term (2-3 years) position.
cons: Some departments do not uphold values. Not much room for growth. The company values are not enforced across all departments and as such you may end up in a place where you'll be unhappy.

headline: Very Good Employer
pros:
I loved working for them and only left due to issues with a certain supervisor.
In my almost 6yrs with them I was in 3 different departments & received even training for a 4th at some point.
They do 10hrs shift which, which you don't feel so much during your shift, however it leaves you with 3 days of weekend which is great.
You have 1hr break [30min paid lunch & 15min in the morning & in the afternoon that are unpaid each]
They make sure you receive a proper training so you should make sure you learn it as you do need it later on during your work.
Salary & Benefits are good.
If you have a problem they try to help you as best as they can, within their means.
cons:
flexibility of hours sometimes depends on the supervisor you have.
I had one that allowed me to start at 5am so that i could beat the traffic as I was living quite a drive away, but my last supervisor wouldn't allow me to start at least at 6 even though this was back office, which increased my traveling times at some point to 3hrs one trip instead of 1.5hrs

headline: Hot mess
pros: Good benefits, flexible work schedule, bonus scheme. Good people as employees (not all managers are bad), somewhat progression tracking. Ability to work towards promotions
cons: Looking at wrong targets, don't follow their own shared purposes, too high expectations from the start, too unstable management, too many people who perform great are forgotten, recognition is a popularity contest, treats employees like kindergarten pupils.

headline: Camera rental/Help operate
pros: Awesome production staff and very knowledgeable.
cons: no downsides I enjoyed working very much with paypal.

headline: Little breathing room
pros: Nice people, and a pleasant working environment. Not much to say than that. Lots of potential for seeming sidewise moves.
cons: Everything measured to within an inch of its life. No real room for upwards progression. A million miles away from Dublin. Weird hours. Felt a bit wasted in there.

headline: Great Opportunity with PayPal
pros:
+ Collaborative Spirit
+ Good HR Benefits
+ Flat organization which is transparent and abundance of opportunities
cons:
- Lots of ideas and slow in execution
- Social acceptance extremely important
- Changes too rapid to bring an idea to completion

headline: Great Company!
pros: Work life balance is great, atmosphere at the officer is great, employees are really appreciated here
cons: sometimes the atmosphere is almost a bit too casual, but who can complain about that?!

headline: Technical Support Analyst at PayPal
pros: Good package, competitive salary, overall OK.
cons: Poor work/life balance, too much control over employees.

headline: Great brand to have on a resume. Culture is becoming corporate. Morale is beginning to suffer as a result.
pros: A better work-life balance than a traditional bank and most large enterprises. Lots of great talent and personalities working there.
cons: It is difficult to get anything done in a short period of time. Despite working in an agile dev process, the company is far from agile.

headline: Overall, great place and interesting work
pros:
1. Generally helpful and friendly people
2. Type of work is relevant and interesting, could see the impact of my code
3. Laid-back atmosphere, frequent team events and activities
4. Good training programs + informational session
cons: 1. Stage environment is a pain. Currently managed stage is supposed to help, but it's still evolving

headline: Software Manager
pros: Some of the folks are extremely talented and pulling the weight. Rest and MOST of them come due to connections or friend of friend.
cons: Bad management. Most of them are overrated. Manage and kiss upwards.

headline: PayPal EA
pros: It's a great place to work! There is a wonderful EA community here and the Execs treat their EAs with respect.
cons: PayPal lacks some of the common "perks" that other large Bay Area Tech companies offer.

headline: Great work-life balance
pros: Great leadership, work-life balance and location
cons: Very matrixed organisation - hard to get things done

headline: Global Integration Engineer 3
pros: One of the few companies I've worked with that has ample career advancements and rewards you for the hard work put in.
cons: I started on the ground floor in support. In a crowd that large it's hard to get initially recognized and harder if you have a sub-par supervisor.

headline: Merchant Risk Vetting
pros: 10 hour shifts with 3 days off, great benefits, ESPP stock plans, semi-annual bonuses
cons: Schedules are nearly set in stone, have to schedule school around the job, no sick time

headline: Great
pros: I'm just here so i don't get fined. I want to meet the 20 word minimum and that will do it.
cons: This job does not support creative thinking, everything is based on audits and not assisting the customer. That is not good.

headline: Working at PayPal
pros: Benefits, people who work there, opportunities
cons: No stock options anymore unless you are management.

headline: PayPal is Great
pros: Benefits, people, company, culture, good pay, interesting work. I really enjoyed my time working at PayPal. I'd like to work there again.
cons: Dim workspace, not easy to advance or switch to other departments. There isn't a ton of collaboration between separate departments.

headline: Does not follow own company values at all.
pros: Nice colleagues. Canteen is not too bad. Free gym.
cons:
Two of the company values are "Do the right thing" and "Be open, honest and direct". Sounds good, but it is apparently to be ignoring by everyone from team lead and up. Discriminating people for having a disability by giving them a hard time when they are off sick with the flu is not doing the right thing. People with disabilities can get the flu just like any other person. And sending them to a disciplinary hearing (yes that's what they call it) with the message that it's because of concerns about the other health issues and that this might cause extra sick days in the future is certainly not the right thing. Especially not if said person simply had the flu and did not take a single minute off regarding this disability. Furthermore, later on denying that this comment wasn't made is not being honest and punishment through false accusations and a bad performance review for being open and direct about seeking legal advice is unacceptable. None of the values have been followed in this case. 
Other than that it is ridiculous to expect grown ups to constantly show off how well the are at their job by making them boast about in the meetings and thro laughable competitions. We are adults, not children who need a sticker from the teacher. Just leave us alone so we can do the actual job. Some of talk about doing their job more than actually doing it, and are rewarded for it with condescending praise. Yes, great value that. Oh by the way, winning these competitions will result in little more than a pat on the back. Not really worth spending your time on, especially if you are being hounded to reach a high amount of productivity. Also, stop trying to dictate what people do in their free time by openly frowning upon them not spending it on work related activities and nights out that aren't even team related and that we have to pay for ourselves. This is "stimulated" in a very pushy manner. Some people have a life outside of work. It's supposed to be a company, not a cult, and nobody can join in every single time. Especially not if they have to pay for it. If I could give zero stars, I would.

headline: PayPal Review
pros: Most people are very helpful and friendly, work / life balance is supported nicely and internal culture is patiently intense.  Employees are committed to doing their best to meet executive and customer expectations while at the same time realizing and accepting of the limitations of human beings.
cons: EGOS!  There are many smart people who believe they are the smartest person in the world whose view should be accepted as right for everyone and who expect to be treated as if their talent is best in the world.  Additionally, poorly selected managers with no support drive quality talent out of the organization.  There is little support for new employee''s from management - they are expected to jump in, understanding from day one the matrixed operations of the company.  This has caused two results - huge ego's in the people who have been there for awhile and actually know what is going on and what teams / individuals to contact for projects and extremely helpful people who are equally confused but willing to help you figure out your issue because they are equally confused and hope to find answers themselves.

headline: A Relaxing But Sometimes Frustrating Environment
pros:
The package is very respectable given the amount of work you do. The compensation is quite good given that you're never expected to work startup hours and the benefits are solid (healthcare, 401k matching, etc) and come with a few nice perks (gym membership, free drinks). The work/life balance is good here, and the company is strong with a known brand and isn't prone to downsizing (not a lot of lay-offs). There are also a ton of free on campus events, so if you play your cards right, you can essentially eat for free.

Many of the people here have families, and this environment is very conducive to that
cons:
The company is incredibly slow and bureaucratic. Learning DOES NOT come easy here, especially with the massive amounts of poorly written legacy infrastructure bogging everybody down. Most of the time, you're learning how to deal with frustrating company-specific internal tools and processes rather than learning overall development skills that are applicable to other jobs. It's also far from a meritocracy. It's very hard to move up, and the levels are based more on your age and amount of experience rather than your actual skill. My biggest problem though is the outdated culture. The company is still struggling to adjust to a truly agile system, and a lot of the engineering base is unwilling to move from old technologies. There's a large focus on specialization here with very little emphasis on learning and growing. The company is still reeling from the old organizational structure of all of the engineers being split into QA and development, leaving it with many QA engineers who can barely write code and are unwilling to learn. There are also random company policies like internal code and hiring freezes that keep it from moving forward. The technical infrastructure is quite poor. Internal tools go down literally every day, making it very hard for developers to get work done. The code contribution process is weak overall. Version control isn't properly leveraged, a lot of "hacks" are pushed to production, code review isn't adequate a lot of the time; in short, a lot of the people here are frankly lazy and perfectly okay adding to the technical debt. There's also a lot of work that has been outsourced, which is unfortunate because outsourced code is usually completely awful and sometimes you have to stay up late to interface with the engineers overseas. Lastly, PayPal can be VERY political. There are a lot of people who would rather "play the game" instead of actually working. The word on the street is definitely true about the main San Jose campus.

In short, if you're someone who's "got the fire", PayPal is NOT the place for you. The learning opportunities are sparse, and it's hard to move up (get promoted) or sideways (join a different team and/or learn something new).

headline: Fun company, lots of potential

cons: Minor headaches with supporting legacy systems. However, given the nature of the payments industry, that's unfortunately expected.

headline: Great Career start
pros: Easy onboarding, multinational and friendly work environment, learned a lot and made valuable connections. Targets were usually realistic and achievable. Enjoyed the international travel, too! back in 2006 it was fun, exciting with a start-up mentality. Still keep in touch with many friends I made there.
cons: Large corporation politics, odd performance reviews and outdated technology. Some of the fun benefits and incentives disappeared over the years. Feedback and improvement suggestions remained unheard for the most part or took way too long to reach the right person/team or to get implemented.

headline: It might be different there now...
pros: When I worked there, I had the privilege to work with some of the most wicked smart people in the valley. Most were very human, humble and eager to teach.
cons: However, by the time I left, most of the wicked-smart/cool/fun people had bailed. Maybe it's changed since Marcus has left...?? Last time I checked though, the marketing teams were still headed up by people that were very much "on-line" focused accountants, that had little vision (or none)?, to support out of box experiential, off-line / retail marketing programs. It's a shame too. We were so close to so many great things, and it just seemed like PayPal marketing higher-ups got in the way of things. Meh.

headline: Product Leader
pros:
PayPal is one of the more innovative and forward thinking companies, so as an employee you get to work on opportunities that has broad impact on a global economy.  The company has stayed a leader in emerging and digital commerce opportunities with continued growth in its customer base - consumers & merchant partners.

As you gain experience within the company, there are ample opportunities to explore other roles with management providing flexibility to rotate into different roles.  As a brand, PayPal is well know globally and is among the top employers in the US.
cons:
The company has grown in size across the years, making it very hierarchical and making decision making challenging most times.  There is also the culture of excessive meetings, power points as a way of communication that affects pace of execution.
As you grow in the organization, needing to be politically savvy is important to continue to elevate.
There is a the constant competing in priorities to support eBay inc and grow PayPal at the same time which is challenging for the leadership at PayPal. Hopefully with the spin off of PayPal as public company now, will allow it to operate independently to better prospects.

headline: senior analyst
pros: really fun  place to work

headline: Not bad overall
pros: Some opportunities to move around internationally (if you wait and push really hard), great and diverse people, flexible hours and ability to work remotely (great for parents), open culture where you can speak your mind, competitive salary for candidates with previous relevant experience, interesting industry which is constantly changing due to heated competition
cons:
Very frustrating if you do not happen to be working in the mothership in San Jose. The company claims it has a global mindset, but most of the decisions are skewed towards the US market, even though other markets show better promise and are growing much faster. You have to deal with too many decision makers who have no idea about the products & local customer needs, and keep on changing the company strategy every week just because it's cool to do a a new powerpoint about it. This is probably due to the fact that PayPal is now hiring more and more brand new MBA graduates instead of hiring street smart people or promoting experienced managers who proved their worth. Advice: If you want to be promoted at Paypal spend more time on your powerpoints rather than solving actual problems.

Fixing simple things take ages, don't even think about starting projects from the ground up: the only innovation these days is done through acquiring other startups. You'll hear a big PR when this happens, followed by a long radio silence as the acquired product dies a slow death... oops looks like those smart MBA guys forgot to think about how we could actually integrate and realistically scale this up.

Abysmal HR: you'll hear about them twice, when you join in to hand in your contract and when you leave (thought that's probably the same everywhere??)

I have worked for paypal settlement. 
this place is full of politics. some incompetent people holds higher ladder which makes it worst place to work. employee assessment and feedback system is full of loopholes. manager uses it for their convenience. people only cares about only their rating and increments. which make this place highly political. you can grow very fast if you have sheer cunning ability. if not this place is not for you.

headline: Big Brother
pros:
Curriculum, the brand is good
not really stressful job
lot of trainings
average benefit
cons: The culture inside is really bad. Career is a question of how old are you in PP or who you know in PP. For this reason you see people not able at all in doing what they should do, with all the consequences linked with. After that, all the employees are subject of a Big Brother experimentation, cameras everywhere, people that know exactly what you did or said or typed or bought, and most important, everything can be used against you by anyone with the title to do that. I don't know if all the multinational are doing that to control their employees (if yes, I don't wonna go to work for Google), but here in PP they do, and it is bad. "Be a good sheep and never will happen to you..again". OR, at the end, it has been all my imagination, and I am ok with that. Thus, PP is good.

headline: Room to improve
pros:
We are now the 800 lb gorilla of digital payments. Hear us roar. 
Generally smart, hardworking people at PayPal. I have yet to meet anyone who would stab someone in the back to get ahead. Teammates support their colleagues all the time.  
Lots of great employee benefits, food, gym etc. It's not Google, but still pretty good.
cons:
Very long live to site cycles. Why does it take 2-3 years to update a product flow? Totally unacceptable. 
PayPal is exceptionally tight with hiring right now in certain divisions. In Product and Design, they are not adding head count and are scrutinizing every contract hire. 
Management did a poor job of providing transparency during the split from eBay. Any executive who says the split was "not about the money" is not sharing the full story. It was and is about the money. 
Laying off 2,000 employees was also about the money. It was not about "operational efficiency". It has had quite the opposite effect. 
Company priorities were not shared in a clear and effective way. Sure, we heard from Dan about his vision for PYPL going forward and that was clear enough. However it wasn't until last month that we as a product team had a clear picture of product priorities. This made planning and resource allocation like running in place. Lots of effort but going no where.

headline: Not The Best Place To Work
pros: Overall the benefits are pretty decent and there is a parking garage. If you get to work early enough you can keep your car out of the blistering sun. If you play the game right, there are opportunities for advancement.
cons:
PayPal is horribly managed. Often promotions are handed out based on politics and if management likes you, not based on merit.  This causes people to be in places they shouldn't be. The office is very political and if you don't play the game properly you're out. I have worked in several different departments and it's pretty consistent amongst them all. The Directors have no idea what they're doing and decisions are often made without taking the teammate into consideration.

PayPal likes to boast how they're they number 1 place to work. What they don't tell you is that they coerced the employees into taking the Phoenix Business Journal survey and threatened that if they didn't get number 1 they'd not complete some of the requests made by employees. That's why if you look at any other ranking site, PayPal is nowhere to be found.

The pay is also terrible and unequal as it is based on politics and not merit. Management also has no idea what employees are doing what for the team. Hard work, dedication, and passion are often overlooked and not taken into consideration with reviews. 

PayPai is a disorganized mess and is moving backwards as there is no real leadership. Their attrition rate is very high as they do not pay employees enough to deal with the upset customers and shotty software used. I do not recommend this as a place to work.

headline: Management doesn't care about developers
pros:
Big campus
Good Cafeteria
Provides good work place resources (Mac book pro, comfy chairs, and other furnitures needed) 
Flexible work schedule
Work From Home (I've seen people wfh at least once a week)
cons:
I was an entry level developer(Recent College Grad) and I faced the following issues before I Quit within a year. This could vary among different orgs, but within my org I could see people having similar opinion. 

- You are made to work on something that might not interest you. Management doesn't even ask if you're okay with it.
- You are taken out of a scrum, and put into another and you lose all the rhythm that you've been trying to achieve over the time in a team. 
- Their rule of thumb - Don't promote until he has worked 3 years or more. 
- Salary - Unsatisfactory considering the good reputation it has with the outside world. 
- Very less young people which makes it hard to blend in because of the difference in thought process (within and outside of work). I think things have been changing now, but I would say that most of them are in mid 30's
- Lack of motivation to innovate and improve to make things better and faster. 
- Lack of exposure to different technologies. You work on very old stack. 

And so on...

headline: Long timer at PayPal
author_position: Member of Technical Staff I Software Engineer
pros: PayPal treats its employees really well. Most of the folks I see around are decent individuals and  very accommodative. The culture promotes basic good behavior when interacting with others. The benefits and salary are much better than most other competitors. If you are in a good org there are opportunities to do decent amount of good amount of technical work.
cons: The competition at PayPal is a bit unhealthy. There are certain cliques where they wont let you move up despite good work. Typical the modus operandi for that is to starve you from good work/projects and not let you succeed. You need to be politically savvy to change into a group that promotes good value oriented approach while giving promotions. In general going up in the game of thrones is not just a function of your skills and value but mostly your political acumen. Those who just do their job but do not spend time or do not have the org support to market their work will not receive kudos for their work. In general it's hard to find a win win situation to add value and succeed in your individual career.

In addition, I worked my way into management and it was completely corrupt towards the end. People were getting promotions because they were hired by friends not due to actual ability. Most managers are under 30 and have no idea how to manage. They care more about hanging out and playing on their phones than actually helping teammates.

So while the reps are busy trying to figure out the new layout and assist the customer at the same time. Higher management criticized us for having a longer handle time. Higher management constantly lies to cover up their mistakes, employees are so stressed out that they need to file for FMLA leave with their doctor and not to mention the many enemies this company has. I am so happy I no longer work there. Look elsewhere job seekers.

headline: Revolving door
pros:
1). People are genuinely helpful and the culture is very laid back. 

2). Great support from the professional services organization. Hands down some of the BEST Sales Engineers in the business. Very customer centric as well as innovative. 

3). Professional services management, while protective of their limited resources, is very proactive and engaged with the sales organization while accepting of feedback that will improve processes that drive efficiencies.

4). Many many opportunities to choose and pick from as a career, although hard to separate the wheat from the chaff.
cons:
1). You better build a network that can help you move around quickly. Many of my resources, management included, came and went during my brief tenure with the company. Literally a revolving door of movement into and out of and around the company, especially notable with David Marcus' departure and Carl Ichan's severing of PayPay from the eBay family. 

2). Leveraging SalesForce, the companies CRM tool, is a nightmare of redundant and useless data and meta data stacked on top of itself. At any given point you don't know who has a hand in the cookie jar when you are working with a prospective company. 

3). No synergy between business units, with 37 other sister companies you would think PayPal would realize the value of creating a "One Face of PayPal" approach. 

4). Once considered an innovative company I believe PayPal has moved to a more risk averse mentality and cannot match the innovators like Apple Pay that are moving into the market with alternate secure and streamlined  payment options.

headline: Suffered through way too many inexperienced managers but I like my role and I like PayPal
pros: The benefits, salaries, bonuses/incentives are all very competitive with most tech companies in this area (Baltimore). I like the ESPP and 401k, I like the tuition reimbursement.
cons:
- Working remotely is entirely based on your own manager, it's not a company wide policy. 
- Unless you're working at the main offices in San Jose, the facilities and on-site amenities are not as nice. 
- There are too many layers of management. 
- There are too many inexperienced individuals that are managers. 
- There should be a promotional path for technical staff members that doesn't involve managing others - there are far too many ineffective managers in technology that shouldn't be managing others.  
- While there is a lot of job growth potential, and moving up within the company, it takes FOREVER. The process takes far too long to move into a new role.

cons: PayPal is rife with politics and there is an organizational inability to get things done. Constant re-organizations. Wavering strategy and vision leads to an inability to focus on priorities and follow through.   Unfortunately, the competition has done more to create PayPal's strategy than any internal vision of success.   Internally, PayPal doesn't live and demonstrate the company values.

pros: Secure job with good benefits. If that's all you want from a company, this is the perfect place for you.
cons: Company with no vision. So many shuffles in management, in the end no body cares. Projects get abandoned often because no body wants to be responsible, in case it fails. And this points to the real problem with PayPal; it's all about appearances. Life at PayPal in one sentence: 10% doing work and 90% talking about it!. Company religiously follows the 'Stack Ranking' system. And your rank is based on your image, not the quality of your work. Whatever talent that existed has left long ago. So, you are surrounded by people who enjoy a secure job and care nothing about the company. When you bring to attention a fault, be prepared to hear, repeatedly, the line: 'This is what we have and we have to work with it!'. If you are a hard working and passionate person, this is not the place for you.

headline: Great company to work.. very good compensation.. good work culture..
pros: excellent compensation and benefits.. very good work culture... great business model and still highly competitive in their own business... global presence...
cons: lack of great leaders... no long term vision.. very frequent organizational changes makes employees not having proper direction...bad work life balance... not a very good performance management system...

headline: Was a dysfunctional start up on steriods.
pros: Budget was fairly easy to come by.  Lots of innovation and little direction from senior management giving you the freedom to do what you wanted.
cons: Constantly changing priorities and too many people just trying to hit their goals and not doing what's best for the customers.

headline: Technology Company but started hiring non technical dumbos.

headline: Not a bad place to be

cons: Bad location, can be difficult to progress if you only speak English

headline: Not a bad place to be

headline: PayPal is a company that has way too many re-orgs.  It's counter productive.
pros:
* Overall the outlook of the company is good. 
* A lot of talented people.
* The cultural is pretty open and folks like to share with you what they do.
cons:
* Bad management in product.  Senior management focus on politics and not on growing the business.
* Culture is too consensus driven.  Decision making is very inefficient.
* Almost no career path for more senior PMs.  Management simply doesn't care about growing and grooming future leaders at all.

headline: I enjoy working for PayPal

headline: Good at salary, worst at work and job security

Salary will be good based on your negotiation skills
cons:
You will be always in stress of getting fired.
Out of date tech stack.
You will be using home grown frameworks built on top of open source frameworks, which does not add value in your resume.

headline: Great work/life balance

cons: Constant reorganizations.  At times, the pace is a speeds where thought of consistency and process is an after thought.  This leads to high frequency of duplication and many different ways to do the same thing.

headline: Work Life Balance in  work work work world
pros: Restricted Stock Program, Sabbatical, Benefits

headline: The company pays well but you work hard for that money
pros: Compensation is good, Benefits are good and after working 5 years you get 4 week sabbatical

headline: Risk Analyst

headline: Great Company to work. But Employee job security is not good.
pros: Working culture, Methodologies   and Technology.
cons:
I worked with Paypal as contractor. I have seen full-time also very tensed about their jobs though they are working more than 10 Years.
Terminated contractors without minimum courtesy. 
Monday morning locked all access for contractors. No body knows what happened. Until one of our teammate received call from 3rd party vendor ( i.e Your contract is terminated)

headline: Good

headline: A snapshot

Lack of diversity in the hiring and the teams- majority males and Indians at middle to senior leadership level; 
flexible work arrangement policy although not fully engrained in culture... people believe their promotion prospects are impacted if they choose to work from home

headline: Disgusted and shocked that people act this way, how could a company like PayPal function like this and see revenue.
pros: Higher then normal salaries because they need to bribe people to work there. You can leave when you want, nothing holds you back from leaving early, except your 27 meeting a day. You get to do some free traveling on the company dime, and you can expense anything even strippers. You might find some good dudes in the weeds, but that's about it.
cons: You will get no time off, horrible vacation policy. You have to work with a bunch of people that think they are amazing, too many egos. The food sucks its all chemically processed food that comes in plastic bags, even the vegetables. You will sit in 27 meetings a day listening to people argue about features or process because everyone knows everything and nobody can be wrong. It really is a bunch of smart people doing nothing, they love to hear their own voice, its a sad story.

headline: Disgusted and shocked that people act this way, how could a company like PayPal function like this and see revenue.
pros: Higher then normal salaries because they need to bribe people to work there. You can leave when you want, nothing holds you back from leaving early, except your 27 meeting a day. headline: No clear vision .. too many re-orgs
pros: good compensation, Great engineers , ok work-life balance
cons: I have been here for 4 years and I have seen almost 6-8 re-orgs in such a short time. I see that senior leadership has no clear vision . Their indecisive nature leads to lot of confusion among the employees when the projects are moved around the teams  very frequently for no reason.

headline: PayPal New Member agent
pros: They have good people who work there and they have decent benefits.
cons: Outrageous metrics. I worked there for 2 years and they do nothing but make your job harder. To give an example, they changed the entire layout of the customer profiles without notifying their agents. When we got customers calling in asking us about the new look we sounded stupid, we had to help customers the best we could and that took more time than usual. then they had the nerve to criticize us for having a longer handle time. That is just ONE example. They shove it down your throat about what a great company they are and how you should feel lucky to work there. Don't be fooled, they do not care about you even when they say they do. They're full of it. Nothing but bad management. I no longer work there and my stress levels aren't nearly as bad as they were when I worked there. Job seekers be warned.

headline: Good for the short term
pros: Excellent Pay and benefits. Fun environment.
cons: Lots of Hours and No Stability

headline: Good place to start your career!  However, it would be difficult to stay a life time. Company is constantly in flux.
pros: There are lots of opportunities to peruse a career here.  They will allow you to learn and new fields and willing to train/coach you.
cons: I was in the risk area and the company restructures risk about every 18 months.  This add undue stress to the position, wondering if you will have a position, etc.

headline: Strategy team
pros: A lot of talented people, most of whom are open-minded, smart, receptive to ideas. Decent perks, good work/life balance.
cons: Terrible at execution. Pockets of highly political director/ sr. director level folks who are more concerned about pushing their own agendas rather than helping the company succeed.

headline: Fun environment, results driven, good welfare

headline: Fat Cat
pros: The Senior Management at Paypal don't have a clue how to run technology or innovate.  They just keep milking their cow and feeding the fat cat.   Lower ranking jobs can be protected from the storm at the top, but there is always a maelstrom going on at the top.
cons: management is horrible on every level

headline: Variable depending on who you work for.

Not all the managers are good. There are a lot of people who are going nowhere or are coasting along (even after the recent layoffs).

Promotions and raises are not done well or fairly.

There are a number of sexist members in senior leadership. For all the Women's Initiatives, there is little the company does to actually promote women.

pros: Opportunity to work remotely when needed. My managers were very flexible and understood the importance of work-life balance. Had some really smart colleagues.
cons: Positions often need to "hit the ground running" with little direction. Additional processes are needed to improve efficiency.

headline: Lots of Changes

No longer the fun place I know. Any issues do not rely on HR. They are hardly on your side. 
Managers need to undergo training to be better managers.

headline: Some great people to work with but too much politics and too many re-orgs

Great benefits
Lots of smart decent people to work with
cons: Leadership has been poor for a long time leading to a lack of real product successes in the last few years

headline: PayPal
pros: Benefits are numerous and very nice.

headline: Great company to work for with a fun and stimulating work environment.

headline: Great company to work for!

headline: Ad Ops Specialist

office environment is great

mac computers

headline: Was once a great company but now is nothing but turf wars and inconsistent leadership and vision
pros: People for the most part are talented and passionate about what they do.  Nice amenities (gym, cafes, coffee bar, free sodas), flexibility in work hours, working from home.
cons: Years ago Paypal had great vision but now is floundering and trying to be "a bank but not a bank". It makes my heart hurt to think about what the company once was and what it has become. VPs are more concerned with managing up and getting face time with the C-level than with managing their businesses and ensuring their teams can be successful. Leadership is inconsistent--constant changes of opinion, of approaches, inconsistency between words and action.  People who are glorified sales reps are put in positions of running large businesses that are now floundering. Lack of people development; difficult to get promoted. Negative politics, turf wars and kingdom building run rampant. Have to be a a "yes man" to be successful; can't voice opposing points of view without repercussions. Values and behaviors look good on paper but few people exhibit these. Compensation is low, and often unfair--women on my team made less than the men, directs made more than their directors and VP management doesn't care. I once was a huge advocate for getting people to work here, but at this point the company is off the path to success and instead is becoming a "me too" company--following the likes of Apple, Google, Square instead of leading.

headline: I worked at PayPal for just over a year and was promoted during the time I was there.
pros: Great training, facilities are amazing, good benefits, they paid well
cons: It can be difficult to get a shift that you really want. Some of their customers were insanely difficult to handle

headline: Constant reorganization and blatant favoritism.
pros:
-Great benefits
-Work from home opportunities

PayPal has great benefits and programs to take advantage of, there's no doubt about it.
cons:
-Poor work/life balance
-Zero accountability
-Employees are held to very different standards
-Arbritary metrics for evaluating employee performance
-Blatant favoritism between managers and employees
-Decisions are an extremely long process.
-Decisions made without considering impact to employee

Decision making is severely lacking. Even the most simple decisions take an insane amount of time. 

Upper management says all the right things, but middle management never follows through and nothing changes for the better.

Promotions are difficult to get unless you're a woman, as social agenda issues run rampant through the organization. Reviews, raises, and promotions are based on arbitrary data, and favoritism tends to rule each decision. 

Women are clearly favored and given special treatment including special seminars and paid company trips.

headline: Sales
pros: When I started was a great place. Disruptive, good VP in our area, and lots of smart, smart people. Upside was very strong.
cons: Leadership has been on decline for some time. Hiring credit card employees (who PayPal beat) has not brought any innovation, and one is inclined to believe based on their actions that they most likely have never used PayPal. It is evident that the past few months are about leadership getting as much money as they can when the company splits, and things are in complete standstill until that happens. Really sad to see.

headline: CHallenging. Amazing workspace
pros: Great minds everywhere around you
cons: difficult to get promoted. Big hierarchy.

headline: Good compensation...
pros: Compensation is good, payments space is interesting.
cons: Senior management says the right things but middle management doesn't act accordingly.  Company culture is tail-chasing.

headline: Career opportunity
pros: It was really good until most of the group (all the managers) were laid off. Some others were retained.
cons: In back sight, it is obvious there was a lack or strategy and vision and disconnect with senior leadership. The group was the shining star for a while but began slipping after a management change. Now there are no opportunities for risk management in Austin.

headline: great place to work

headline: Best job I ever had

headline: Product Analytics
pros: You will work with a lot of great people.

headline: Management Changed
pros: There were three different VP's during my time  there and the last two years they cut our pay twice from a 40k base plus commission to 25k for new hires plus commission.  Pay decreased even though salws werea significant percentage higher.
cons: They have purchased companies and replace old management with the owner or management of the newestcompany they acquire. Note this was in the sales division. Constant changes in wages and commission structure made it hard to plan for your own financial future.

Yearly Pulse Review is really good and it is very effective, you can sue your manager.

Even if you do a simple task, show it off to all managers and say that you did a amazing thing so that you will get recognized.

You have to show yourself to management or a higher visibility is required for hike and promotion
Be careful that not all are trustworthy, some will do back-stabbing too.

headline: Product focussed organisation

Good people to work with.
Loads of potential in the product
Clients can see the value in the solution
Global network

Salaries aren't competitive in the senior sales or relationship management areas of the business in the UK.  
Internal data quality and reporting solutions are left wanting, resulting in a lot of re-work and poor decision making.

headline: overall a great place to work

headline: Great group of very intelligent hardworking people. Very poor leadership.
pros: Smart people. Cool technology. Hot name in the industry.
cons: The leadership team had to make a lot of difficult decisions lately and, in my opinion, did so very poorly. People were left confused and worried for a very long time.

headline: Good place to learn, but hard to deal with the politics

- Opportunity to make an impact
- Decent work life balance
cons:

headline: PayPal
pros: Secure payments. Grand vision. People are helpful. Good work life balance. There is plenty of work to be done and plenty of learning opportunities. You will not be bored.
cons: Difficulty getting things done in the org structure. New leadership will make org changes to streamline work processes.

headline: So much potential, but leadership needs to make the tough decisions
pros: A large and growing user base, lots of revenue, employees who are subject matter experts in payments, e-commerce, and risk.
cons: Classic large company issues. Leadership needs to make the tough decisions and streamline the business. Too many employees = fiefdoms and confusion over who owns what. Slow decision-making allows nimble start ups to get first to market.

headline: Confusing and unorganized.
pros:
If you are an employee without a product, there is a large amount of freedom. (However, most people are not.)
The pay is reasonably good, and there is a very large acceptance of gigs on the side. This is a good place to put in the minimum workload, get a salary, and build your own startup. There is a fair number of frustrated employees who do exactly that, making PayPal an excellent place to put together a startup team.
cons:
PayPal has a tradition of documenting code poorly, and of performing reorgs every 3 years. This combination makes it almost impossible to change any code: you probably cannot find anybody who knows what the code does. If you find that person -- or if you are a person who knows what the code does -- then the process of getting approval to make a change is tedious, and again, frustrated by occasional reorgs. 

People working in Austin or Scottsdale are often more frustrated than those in San Jose.

headline: Hope it get's better and, all things considered, it was probably a mistake staying as long as I did.
author_position: Member of Technical Staff I Software Engineer
pros: A big name to have on your resume.  Pretty cushy job that actually drug my technical skills down.  Got paid well.  Amazing parties.
cons:
Fractured technical leadership.  Management is a mess.  Massive technical debt and encumbering weight of a system that was has been continually bolted onto with duck tape solutions.  The system is almost impossible to actually test and verify.  The vast majority of the technical staff had no idea how the entire system worked.   Proprietary SOAP protocol for services.  Around 2000 internal services that are almost untraceably dependent on each other and often have duplicated/triplicated functionality.  Little actual will or ability to reign in the system bloat.  Basically a lot of senior people that had many others running in circles just so they could justify their positions.

At one point we were told that if we weren't making every possible purchase with PayPal we shouldn't work there.  So there was quite a bit of pressure to drink the Kool-Aid.  Internal and incestuous politics with ebay.  Very poor on-boarding of new acquisitions and newer ideas.  From what I could tell it was a mostly a brain drain and then toss mentality of newer more agile tech and companies.

headline: marketing manager
pros: good culture, friendly, especially in maryland location
cons: hard to get things done, lots of change in sr management/reorgs, no clear priorities

headline: GOPS

headline: Amazing place for co-ops
pros: No matter which team you land up, you will find them amazing. It's not a place where they expect you to code straight 8 hours. You go to office, have a tea, join scrum, code, lunch, pingpong then code and come back.
cons: did not had much chance to interact with the people of HQ.

headline: Great.
pros: Good work culture, extremely chilled with good work life balance.
cons: Promotions are at the whims of the manager, which can be a bit of a pain.

headline: BEST JOB

Im a security contractor, and love the people, PayPal is very fair and treats its employees well. 
It is a professional company, and fun.
