pros: Low stress place where no one works hard.  People in my group QRS work 30 hours a week.  Come in late and leave early is no problem.  Management doesnt care.
cons: No excitement or team feeling. Everything from managers is fake. Some managers are mean and talk down. No woman leaders in 120 people group.  Company is getting rid of people now instead of managing budgets all along.  Contractors are kicked out with no notice even though contracts were extended a few weeks ago,  Contractors are people and have families and bills.  Nasty to kick them out with no notice not even one day.

headline: good compay but salary is not Very good. Good culture and young teams.

cons: Not many promoting options to employees who work for many years. It is like a big call center. Most jobs need to be on shift.

headline: Great potential

headline: Paypal is an excellent place to work. Lots of perks and benefits start Day1.

headline: Fantastic opportunity lies ahead

headline: Product management

headline: High expectations - Good compensation

headline: What a ride
pros: The company ordinarily compensates their employees well (including granting a 4 week sabbatical after 5 years of service), and the vast majority of people I worked with were awesome! There are periodic social events (though there are fewer outside of the San Jose, California location), free drinks (soft drinks, coffee, tea, etc.), sponsorship of community events (like World Usability Day), and community involvement is encouraged. There's also a significant degree of diversity in the lower echelons and more than a few career opportunities (if you're in San Jose).
cons: Work/life balance can get seriously out of whack - there were weeks I worked 80 hours to get a project done and the only reward for going above and beyond was a "thanks" from my direct supervisor. You also have to constantly watch everything you say and do - even the things you think are innocent, like telling people other companies are hiring - there are people who will calmly throw you under the bus if it benefits them (but this is true everywhere). Diversity isn't nearly as pronounced at higher levels and career opportunities outside of San Jose are pretty minimal. Also, there is a significant loss of knowledge capital after people have taken their sabbatical.

headline: Great place, but it was a dead end.

Everybody I knew was very dedicated and working extremely hard, but the arbitrary rules for performance evaluation demanded that only a small percentage could be recognized/rewarded for excellence.  

Too many re-orgs, too much politics.
Most people were nice, but they were over-shadowed by a handful of abrasive types with big egos.
Your experience may be good or bad, depending on which org you're in.

headline: Good facility, culture
cons: None to specify as per as concern with me

headline: Telesales. Sophomore leadership which is clueless at best, self-serving and thoughtless at its finest.
pros: Location. Some of the AEs really do care about the merchant experience, and are not solely focused on their hefty commissions. Some of team leaders are really great and know what they are doing. The cafeteria food used to be awesome.
cons:
1)The compensation plans need to be reviewed and revised. Again and again. The market shifts, and companies and need to shift too. What worked 6 years ago to drive performance, won't necessarily work today. The  plans do not necessarily reward the right behavior and the people who work really hard to hit their quota when they've fallen behind still get the short end of the stick, despite their best efforts. The model is archaic at best and was managed by someone who really should not have ever been involved in the process. Their involvement was due to a terribly misplaced sense of trust...and the output was garbage and did not motivate or incentivize people to do their best. The feedback about this fell on deaf ears (see issue 3).  P-Club? That entire program is a joke, and seems like a free vacation for the leadership team when it's the front line people "making it rain" and bringing in the "revenuuuuuuuuuuuuuue!".

2)Work and life balance. Account executives are afraid to take time off, because it puts them behind and potentially on a performance improvement plan which can take many, many months to claw yourself out of, if you're lucky. So, though you've earned it, you can't take time off.

3)Feedback. It goes into a black hole. There once was a little survey that was put in place to collect real time feedback. The leadership team would review and respond to comments and it was starting to make a difference. 2 or 3 months later, with a massive change in the leadership team, that stopped and is rumored to come back sometime soon- almost a year later. So much for taking feedback seriously and implementing solutions with some degree of velocity. Thanks, Pulse survey!

4)Differing and sometimes unfair leadership practices. Some front line leaders (due their lack of professional development and lack of support from above) are afraid to take action on some people, for any number of reasons (the person is too nice, the person is too loud and scary, the person has something on me so I can't run the risk to my career, etc.). So- in some cases- noisy, toxic, too nice, or troublesome people stay around for far too long, even though they are not performing to standard thereby creating an environment of mistrust of the leadership team and their "tenets". Some of these people have since left but there are a lot of them still here. All things are not created equal- and that includes the use of the performance improvement plan. Leaders are allowed to be way too subjective in their application of it. Again, where is the trust?

5)Too often, when it does happen, the wrong people get promoted from within. AEs to trainers, trainers to managers, managers to directors. And the right people don't. Leaders (at all levels) are allowed the play favorites. It is demotivating to people, but they stick around for the paycheck. And the individuals with self-worth leave.

6)The culture is positively toxic here, abhorrent even, driven from the top down and perpetuated by lack of address. Sadly, this was not always the case. It was never perfect but was getting better. Most of the current "executive" (and I really do use the term loosely) leadership of the sales organization came from a couple of big banks, and had all worked together at some point in time and were all brought in to bring the band back together (see issue 4). Other leaders were brought in because they knew someone, or were promoted because they were buddies with someone on the leadership team. Other people were promoted because it was easier than going through the hiring process and would minimize some noise during a  massive shake-up. Boy's club? Check. (There have been very few female managers.... and look at the telesales leadership team today. How many women team leads, site leads, operations managers, directors, senior directors are there? So much for diversity). Inexperienced  "leaders"? Check. Of the leaders that are still here, it's a clown-show....not one that inspires you to do your best. One particularly elitist leader, will regularly, loudly and proudly tell you about their prestigious school and their "service" and will show disdain at pretty much anything other than ivy league. You'll hear the same loud, show-off stories at every event  if you're in the club and get the invite. It's been said more than once that they only associate with people that can help further their career. So, "bottom feeders", forget about inclusion. Apparently there is an "I" in team.  It doesn't make us look up to him, or inspire us to follow his path. 

You would think with a company this size with such potential exposure, after several prior complaints about leadership inefficacy that someone would take notice, take affirmative action, protect the people bringing in the dollars that fund those paychecks but in fact, those leaders instead get promoted and get the benefit of a coach (this is a massive investment that should be invested in the front line)  and people that speak up or so called whistle-blowers are the ones that take the arrow from the exec quiver on those issues (see issues 4, 5 & 6). Which brings me to my next concern to call out for people looking to join the sales team, or PayPal for that matter. Human Resources, has zero human to it (see issues 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6). At all. Please do not expect them to help you or even take you seriously. They are there to protect the most senior of leaders. That's it. They are the next most dysfunctional attendee to this party. The HR senior leader refuses to engage on escalated issues therefore rendering complete paralysis to the team managers. Issues go for months and months without response or action and when things hit critical mass, the individuals escalating beyond for any type of intervention and support get the boot. And do not think to escalate to any senior execs either. Your issue will get pushed back down to the person you've raised concerns about and you will be at the mercy of their wrath....which, of course, is to get the boot and keep their reputation tidy.

In short, to anyone doing their due diligence right now (be glad you did) please do your homework before you leave another environment to come here or even look to start your career here. Ask around your network, get the scoop not from the recruiter trying to sell you on utopia...but the real deal.  If you aspire to receive recognition, support, career growth and a healthy environment- this isn't it. You likely won't be developed (the leaders who are supposed to be developing you aren't even developed). You probably won't see the benefit of promotion from within (but your leader's BFF might!). You may not even be supported by your leader, or your leader's leader and definitely not your leaders' leader's leader or beyond. There are better places to cut your teeth on than here. You can do better.

headline: Collections specialist, with paypal over a year.
pros: Good environment, great facilities, full health care, gym onsite. Good people in general to work with.
cons: Unskilled management, almost brainwashed in believing in the "paypal way" favouritism, criticism of paypal policies or management is almost a mortal sin. Likes to project itself as an equal opportunities employer which is sadly not the case if you have opinions of your own and don't follow the PayPal "cult"

headline: Interview Process/Recruiting
pros: Pay isn't all that bad.
cons: Once you sign on with Paypal there is no work/life balance. Odd hours and schedules that are basically for nomads.

headline: It's been a roller coaster of a ride!!!
pros: The benefits are pretty awesome!
cons: In mature people and bosses. If you get the right boss and manager it pretty ok.

headline: Toxic and very political work environment. It is about who you know, not what you know.
pros: Benefits, benefits, benefits, benefits, benefits.
cons: It's very unfortunate that good people are not given opportunities and that seniority means absolutley nothing. It is also unfortunate that we are not allowed to voice our opinions truly without repercussion. Management says they have an open door policy and that they want to hear what we have to say but as soon as you disagree, you are targeted as a negative person and then things get...uncomfortable.

headline: Challenging, Face paced environment
pros: There's a lot of opportunity to branch out and learn. It's a 'never-get-bored" environment where there's always something to get involved in -- even it it's outside your job scope. If you decide to explore other careers, there are options to do so.
cons: Life work balance isn't that easy.

headline: If you're not Indian, do not take a job at PayPal.
pros:
- I learned a lot about web application programming.
- The pay and benefits are pretty good.
cons:
1) PayPal's workforce is more than 70% Indian. Of course, this is not problem in itself.

At PayPal, however, the Indians heavily favor their own. They get away with this because they control the place. 

As a result, if you're not Indian, you have no chance at a good rating or a promotion. If you *are* Indian, you have a cushy job for life.

2) PayPal stack ranks its entire workforce every 6 months. The result is intense competition among "teammates," with lots of backstabbing, politics, and court intrigue.

headline: Limitations Agent
pros: Great Benefit, great place, multicultural workplace, 25 days holidays per year
cons: working at weekends, negative support, bad reputation, no career opportunity

headline: Product Manager
pros: Lots of challenges, Work-life balance, possibilty of growth.
cons: Far from my home, spend a lot of time commuting.

headline: Great company
pros: Very nice facility with a positive environment. Great benefits including free health care and gym on site to name a few. Company is always growing and has a promising future. Work/life balance is very flexible.
cons: Difficult and slow trying to move up as lateral career moves are the predominant option.

headline: PayPal
pros: Great management who really want to take care of their employees.
cons: I was collection agent for Paypal, which was a very crappy job.

headline: Adding good apples to a bad barrel
pros: It is a great brand name.  No one is in charge, so you can set any direction you like.  Well, until your legacy employees complain.  Great Indian food, if you like that.
cons: These people are out of control and uneducated  They filled an entire building directly from India and they wonder wtf why are these under qualified people making decisions that 8th graders from the USA would not make.   Look at customer complaints of frozen accounts inside a black hole.

headline: Good experience
pros: There are a lot of opportunities to learn a lot because there is not a whole lot that is documented very well
cons: despite the learning opportunities the career path is not very clear

headline: Great company to see innovation, but not execution
pros: great people to learn from, great innovation drive
cons: execution challenges, TTM, not the best leadership

headline: The management is missing the big picture here.
pros: The facility and location are nice. If you work hard and market yourself well there are opportunities for development and growth in the company.
cons: If you have any opinion other then what your leader or leadership has you are ignored and avoided. Once you have established yourself and earned a promotion to supervisor or team leader you are expected to put in 50-60 hours a week, working from home when not in the office offering little to no work-life balance. When you are promoted they give you as little as raise as possible and their rating system is designed to stack rank you against people of different job functions making sure that the majority of their employees receive little to no raise annually but are give acceptable marks.

headline: Nice Company to work for
pros: Excellent Benefits and a good pay
cons: Not a technological destination yet. Too much of coordinatiion with different geographic locations

headline: Good job
pros: Good people and culture depending on what department you end up in. Wonderful benefits. Overall I recommend the company but just be careful a lot of cliques in management. Sabbaticals.
cons: Communication between upper management and below is an issue. More about who you know to get promoted.  They should pay more as tenure means nothing here, which is not how it used to be.

headline: Internal hiring process makes Stalin look reasonable.
pros: If you're looking to get hired easily and put a big company on your resume, look no further. They will pay for your school and even some professional certifications, no tenure required.
cons:
Don't expect much of any opportunity to handle larger responsibilities on a relatively short-term basis. In most places being able to showcase your talent will open doors for you and improve your CV when you look at advancing your career, but with PayPal you'll just get discouraged when you're slapped in the face with the fact that you need to spend another year or two on the incremental raise treadmill before you're given consideration. If you're looking for a quick resume booster, it's great. If you're looking to build a career, look elsewhere.

Pay is substandard for most fields not handling calls. If you have 5 years to give and aren't concerned about the low pay, it's great - you can have PayPal reimburse a good chunk of your schooling and maybe a professional certification or two, then get your sabbatical (4 weeks paid leave, granted every 5 years of service) and jump ship. By the time you've been here for 5 years you've got enough experience to easily make 50% higher salary elsewhere. The lack of competitive pay is something brought up regularly in internal surveys but management insists the comprehensive picture is better, as though they expect anyone to believe a month of paid leave makes up for salary $20k/year below competitors.

headline: Relax... Too relax
pros: No micro-management but favouritism and local lobbies are deeply anchored which could block your way up.
cons: They want to Yankee you up! And robotise you. Processes sometimes can't be applied to certain markets due to culture differences but it doesn't seem to bother them despite many and many complaints and feedback. Salaries are under standards, good job to build up a cv though.

headline: Solid business model, but definitely not a place for passionate engineers.
pros: Solid business model. PP will surely dominate the online payment space for some more years to come.
cons: Very mediocre legacy employee base. Hardly any innovation and encouragement to drive out-of-the box thinking. The moment Apple/FB/Amazon will generate enough heat, as a company PP will find it really difficult to survive.

headline: Account Executive
pros: great benefits, insurance and health. Great Christmas partty
cons: high turn over, dis-organize, goal is unclear, training is under develop and some managers are micromanagers.

headline: Part-Time Position
pros: It was a beautiful brand new working space.  The training that the company provided was excellent.  Expectations were set, and the communication to the team was excellent.
cons: The only true problem I had was with the commute.

headline: ok ok
pros: salary,programs,team lunches,cab facility,work life balance
cons: no good work,no growth,you can't be here for long time

headline: Good one.
pros: Lots of technical learning, industrial relationships and more importantly you can follow what you like the most.
cons: Too lenient, but lots of opportunities, some partiality. A little opaque, but it actually doesn't matter.

headline: Good one.
pros: Lots of technical learning, industrial relationships and more importantly you can follow what you like the most.
cons: Too lenient, but lots of opportunities, some partiality. A little opaque, but it actually doesn't matter.

headline: Pretty good
pros: Good perks, very well behaved people, good work people.
cons: Location and lack of full time employees

headline: Only form middle management up otherwise just a summer job
pros: Company is growing and in Europe you might have opportunities across different countries, salary is ok and based on performance you can have a an increase every year, stock option plan is great.
cons: Slow  and bureaucratic, internal promotion are a scam, and totally detached from skills and performance and if you have to start from the lowest level is micromanaging all over.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Secure job with good benefits
cons: You need to work hard and show your interest to move up

headline: Great company, incapable upper management and executive
pros: Good compensation, great benefits.  PayPal is currently the industry leader in online payment and it still has tons of growing opportunities despite the recent emergence of Apple Pay
cons: Incapable upper management in technology department, along with crazy working attitude and unreasonable business requests by finance executives.  Wrong concepts and tools are being implemented, and the technology department blindly follow the finance executive decision.

headline: Innovative payments company
pros: Fast paced, growing, high performing
cons: Management is very unstructured and difficult to communicate with.

headline: One of the best companies I've worked for so far...
pros: The company is always growing, so there will always be job security. There are multiple opportunities for growth and career advancement.
cons: Sometimes it is difficult to balance your work life and personal life with the way the scheduling/shifts can be.

headline: Great place to work and innovate!
pros: Mobile first! if you are looking for focusing your career in Mobile Payments. This is the place to be.
cons: Not agile, very slow to make things happen. Needs a start-up dose to move fast.

headline: Good work life balance
pros:
Work life balance is good.
Culture is very informal.
cons: There is some level of bureaucracy as with any big company.

headline: Manager
pros: Work life balance is okay. benefits are good; definitely an exciting industry to work in.
cons: too much politics and backstabbing; no concept of career development; you move up by selling the story; too many young directors who have no concept of people development.

headline: Fun but only for short term.
pros: Good pay, international, good facilities
cons: Rigid working environment, weekend work, location was far off the city

headline: An unrewarding experience..
pros:
- easy to get hired on all levels expect management
- they don't expect much in terms of experience, knowledge or work effort
cons:
- salary below standard
- management is a prime example of failing upwards

Unlike what is published officially most work (case and risk reviews) is actually done in China nowadays, which means that at least the European offices don't really have to do much other than being present. Most departments touch significantly below 1% of the problems that arise in their specific market. On the other hand over 99% of all workflow gets outsourced to companies in Tunisia, the Philippines and China. At the same time the Managing Directors tour all around Europe and receive prizes for creating underpaid jobs..

This company is actually a Luxembourg registered bank, at the same time it is unbelievable how much sensitive customer information is lost through their outsourcing activities. I was using the service before, but since working there would never trust them with my personal information again.

If you are looking for a easy and unchallenging job and can life with the fact that its quiet badly paid this might be a good company for you. Its actually the perfect company for students, better than working as a waiter anyway. However be prepared for some travel time, in Europe most offices they rent are in the middle of nowhere..

headline: Fast maturing company with cohesive leadership (even while new president is being recruited) and excited rank and file
pros:
Great people oriented corporate culture across eBay...top management at eBay really cares about career development, diversity, open and honest culture
Work life balance generally good, with flexible work from home culture (ok to phone in especially given the sprawling global employes presence across most teams...though that means APAC and EMEA hours in the workday)
Investors see paypal as a "hot" company with a lot of runway potential ahead, albeit in a highly competitive field
cons:
Still building processes of a smoothly oiled mature company, though has been an incredibly fast learning org over the past few years
Performance assessment process has gotten broadly mixed reviews, so is being revamped

headline: Good values. Lack of focus. Emphasis lately on hand waving over execution.
pros: The values that Ebay Inc strives for are worthy of emulation by any company or individual. It's a place with heart ; which is quite amazing given the size of the company. Huge business in online payments and security differentiation. Simplified product structure recently makes for greater sakes focus.
cons: Too many senior level people that are fluffy both in management and technical tracks. Lots of hand waving by these folks who don't understand payments business or payments tech and think that PayPal is a web startup or that it is a new programming language that will change the payments ecosystem. Too many very senior programmer type people  who don't understand payments and are rewarded for implementing basic dev environment tooling and custom infra that is slowing down engineering productivity.

headline: Limited Growth & Lack of innovation
pros: Good salary, benefits and decent work/life balance
cons: Reorgs happen frequently and results show in lack of innovation by staff. Office culture is clique driven and offers no growth if you're not part if the clique.   High staff turnover at all levels, reduces productivity and focus of staff.

headline: exciting, innovative, flexible
author_position: Member of Technical Staff I Software Engineer
pros: Paypal tries to solve a lot of problems in most financial spaces. Recently they have also started investing a lot on setting up data warehouses and minting intelligence from them
cons: Although a lot of opportunities are provided to the employees to innovate, very few takes shape and gets to the market

headline: Used to be a great company - Right now its like there is no Management
pros:
Great people
Reasonable work life balance
Great infrastructure , great for people to gain technical skills and expertise
cons:
Mid level management is worse . Somehow top level management cant see this
There is no motivation what so ever for employers  . There is absolutely no collaboration across the teams.There is no common goal.too many changes introduced blame game that makes it hard for engineers to thrive 
Managers keeps getting promotions and   they dont believe that they are successful because of team work .

headline: Amazing company
pros:
- great product, driving mobile revolution 
- super culture: helpful, nice, innovative
- work and life balance at its best
- amazing location: Richmond, by Thames
- strong package
- part of eBay Inc. family
cons:
- nothing major I can think of
- more external speakers presentations

headline: Different modes of work environments
pros: Office culture is fun with a lot of emphasis on work-life balance. Technology wise one of the leading companies in the industry. Product is unique and has interesting problems.
cons: You can work in any mode you want. Population is defensive in work adoption & execution. A lot of inertia over the past 5-6 years and so many competitors have left the company playing catch-up game instead of being market giants that they once were.

headline: great
pros: Good comp with a great work life balance
cons: There is nothing bad I have to say

headline: Lack of leadership in Marketing and constant re-orgs
pros: Great products, I use them everyday.  There is so much potential for Marketing to do great things if they could only have consistent leadership and get the organization to row in the same direction.
cons: Constant re-orgs.  Hi turnover of employees.  Leaders are not aligned.  Every year you get to solve the same problems over again with a different group of people.

headline: Very Nice Environment
pros: Freedom, as long as you do your job company culture is very flexible.
cons: Reactive to Market Business, not Proactive.

headline: Positive experience
pros: It's a great working culture. People are sincere and nice. Pay and benefits are reasonable.
cons: Work-life balance can be ruined at times. Politics abound. Your success depends a lot on your manager. Work can become easily boring.

headline: Good pay, good w-l balance
pros: Payments, many companies seek payments experience. New management changed the culture of paypal from buerocratic to technology company. Good work life balance. Good cafeteria with multi cuisine options like indian dosa, naan and curry, chinese, sushi, mexican, american etc.
cons: Developer productivity sucks. The development environments and application frameworks are customized to paypal, slow in adapting to latest technology trends, lot of legacy code and services. The landscape is changing but its still slow.

headline: Good from far, far from good...
pros: Big company perks- benefits, fair comp, budget, resources, etc.
cons: Lack of culture, direction, innovation and passion...Contract/consultant culture rampant across the organization- cruising/coasting is the norm...

headline: Flexible, good work/life balance.
pros: I had great flexibility with my job and schedule. Managers were fair and reasonable. There are plenty of resources to work with. Good pay, bonuses and benefits.
cons: The company is so big that you end up feeling just like another statistic. People come and leave the door so quickly.

headline: Great company... Great people
pros: Enjoying market lead position, good people and value, flexible hours, good lateral growth opportunities
cons: Difficult to get things done... No  new disruptive ideas... Difficult to get promoted... Company is getting in to large corporate mentality... Too many people

headline: Sr. Quality Assurance Engineer
pros: Competitive salary.  Great position in payments market.
cons: Company focused.  Not about the people.  Don't give time to learn new technologies.  Little work-life balance.

headline: Great company, great potential, massive scale, but unclear priorities drive challenging execution
pros:
definign the future of payments, with a global scale
great people
genuinely trying hard to re-connect with more innovative and startup-ish culture
cons:
no clear priorities make execution a giant challenge
poor culture of crossfunctional collaboration. If you can be self-sustaining, then you can suceed, if you need other teams to support, then very hard. makign crossfunctional decisions is really hard.
while CEO David Marcus has left and not (yet) be replaced, the organization's challenges are multiplied.

headline: Awesome Culture, Rapid work !!
pros: Awesome Work. Awesome Team. Excellent Benefits. !!
cons: None. I can't find any !1

headline: Challenging place to be a marketer
pros: Company is on the cutting edge of many innovations in the payments space, and combined with the brand recognition of eBay and PayPal, should be a more dominant player.
cons: Marketing functions are in a near constant state of re-organization, with little leadership and no professional development.

headline: Data Scientist
pros: Great place for expanding your skillset as there are several diverse groups you can work with
cons: Too many organizitional changes could sometime lead to lack of execution clarity for employees

headline: Good learning experience
pros: Great learning experience in the payment space
cons: Political, takes too long to make decisions, cumbersome structural issues

headline: Great place to work, good training program
pros: Everyone was nice.  The perks were good. Plenty of room for growth.  My favorite part was the customer support training program.  I left the company early for other reasons.
cons: I can't think of many bad things about working in this position.  You do not have any free-time to mess around on the computer, but after a while I found that to be a good thing.

headline: Mediocre at best...
pros: Compensation and travel benefits, bonus, options
cons: Management, lack of focus and follow-through, lack of direction

headline: Best Company I've ever worked for
pros:
Training is great, small classes with instructors who listen and understand concerns.
The system isn't perfect but is always improving, which is all that matters for a company.
Great benefits and things to do while on break, follow the rules and it's like being on vacation at work.
cons:
Some departments need better management to keep people sane.

When I was working there we were judged on how the customer rated us.
Who is going to give you a good rating if you work in the "limitations" department and the only customers you get are already irate about their account being locked (most of the time we weren't even able to remove the lock because other departments were way behind schedule). So we had Irate customers with no means of helping them because another department wasn't able to handle their work load. We were judged on the customer reviews that were out of our control.

A customer is given a survey about how you handled their call, it does not matter how polite and sincere you are, people are going to give you a bad rating when you are unable to resolve the issue with the result they wanted (due to PayPal's system). You can coat bad news with anything you want, they are still going to be angry their account is locked and give bad ratings.

PayPal created this no win situation by not paying attention to what happens when another department is reliant on another department.

headline: Overall a great place
pros: Great co- workers, interesting role, great perks
cons: Tons of office politics, hard to be promoted.

headline: Good company, good heart, low tech
pros: Good work/life balance.  Fair company with good values. Amazing potential.
cons: A lot of Technology By Handwaving at senior levels.

headline: Great place to work - as long as you can "fit in"
pros: The entry level pay is great and the benefits are great. They also feign interest in helping you move up in the organization AND business world.
cons: Because it is a "clique-like", it is hard to approach upper management with concerns without fearing some kind of retaliation or being aaron lingle'd until you are pushed to the edge and quit.

headline: Worst company I have ever worked for
pros: Only if you are desperate and don't have other choice.
cons: Wage, Benefits, Company status, Career Path, CSR is a really tiring job, stressful and frustrating. You are a number, not a person in this company. Management does not care about employee satisfaction. PayPal moves agents from department to department without considering the feelings of their employees. Leadership is strongly lacking, the management is clueless with clearly played favourites. People skills are a tick box exercise and people who can talk-the-talk are preferred over actual achievements. Terrible work-life balance unless your a favourite. The politics is all over the place and the company does not care about the customers either.

headline: Poor Leadership - Dublin Team
pros: Good Team-mates and most people work hard and understand the importance of a strong work ethic. If you've the right boss then compensation and benefits are good. With the right boss you can go far very quickly.
cons: Leadership is strongly lacking from Dublin team, with clearly played favourites. People skills are a tick box exercise and people who can talk-the-talk are preferred over actual achievements. Terrible work-life balance unless your a favourite.

headline: Decent enough
pros:
- schedule flexibility when you work in back-office
- time given to work on additional projects
- job recognition culture
- good work-life balance
cons: - career advancement is very slow, promotion generally means moving horizontally from one department to the other

headline: Great work environment if you don't mind being on the phone.
pros: Very professional and friendly environment. Great benefits as well. The opportunity for advancement is very present. The employer actually encourages you to move up and seek different positions within the company. Very supportive.
cons: If you don't like talking to people on the phone. The first year of phone work can be hard.

headline: A great company and workplace, but with lots of room for improvement
pros:
1. Good benefits. As far as software engineer positions are concerned, it beats most of the Singapore-based company (foreign banks excluded) I know of.
2. The company makes a genuine efforts to upgrade the technical skills of the employees.
3. The team dynamics are wonderful, and there are many great technical talents.
4. Work-life balance is great, although mileage varies wildly from group to group.
cons:
1. There tend to be organizational restructure once every one year or so, essentially the same employees and managers being reshuffled into different groups/organizations. It can be a real distraction overall.
2. The code base is largely ancient and with varying quality. Although there has been company-wide efforts for migration and cleanup, there is still a long way to go.
3. The quality of the middle managers (senior managers, director levels) varies a lot. Some are really soul-less, who simply take the order from above without much consideration of nuturing the people, or really care about what customer need.
4. Domain solos. This is observed between different technology groups. There are cases in which domain ownership (or lack of) takes precedence over sound architectural considerations

headline: Software Engineer
pros: flexible working time, friendly environment, work life balance
cons: application of new technology is not fast.

headline: Great Vision ... low in technical innovation
pros:
- Vision is inspirational
-  Financial leadership
cons:
- Low say/do ratio in PayPal leaders
- Bias toward male employees especially in technical groups
- Poor dev environment

headline: Great company
pros: Very nice people in there
cons: There are no cons to working there

headline: Highly politically minded executives thinking of how to secure their jobs
pros: VERY solid business model that generates a constant flow of profits
cons: No consideration of career development/path, VERY weak HR, and VERY poor record of management experience among senior executives.

headline: Friendly employees & good benefits
pros: Very good environment and exciting company to work for
cons: Frontline managers lacking in experience and leadership qualities

headline: Great
pros: Learning, development, benefits, perks and compensation
cons: People can be annoying and very political...

headline: You are a number, not a person in this company!
pros:
- Nice colleagues
- Opportunities to move up the ladder/to other departments
cons:
- Poor location [far away from the city centre, Dublin has poor public transport]
- Management does not care about employee satisfaction. After 5 months in Fraud I was advised that they were moving me to customer service because of understaffing in this department. They did not care I was very strongly against this decision. PayPal moves agents from department to department without considering the feelings of their employees. You are a number in this company, not a person

headline: Good benefits; Good career opportunities.
pros: Benefits in the company are outstanding! good team building activities, bonus, Health insurance, etc
cons: Difficult to make changes. Difficult not to get into a rutine.,

headline: It was a teaching school that educate you as a "PayPal Mafia" member

- Do global projects in a growing company
cons:
- HR and salary strategies are really bad
- pressure to do your job better
- No clear career path

headline: Making Money Work Better for People
pros: Opportunity to impact society.  Dedicated people.
cons: Can be more effective with focus.

headline: One of the best places to work for
pros: Work culture at PayPal is great. PayPal gives you enough flexibility to ensure a happy work-life balance. You get to work on cool technologies. Leadership is effective and inspiring.
cons: Corporate culture steps in way to efficiency. Processes and dependency consume more time than development.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great benefits and salary plus great commited people
cons: work life balance could be better

headline: Great as long as you stay in line with the flock and aren't a whistle blower
pros: Fun environment, great cafeteria, loves nepotism, most managers care about you, give good bonuses if you work hard, acknowledge good work (doesn't mean your compensation or role will change but you'll get a pin and a pat on the back)
cons: DIdn't agree with certain policies, felt there were less there honorable practices that were trained. Poor training during tax season. Kept employees under educated on purpose so you wouldn't see flaws in the system.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Offers great medical benefits, tuition reimbursement, pay for performance bonuses, paid time off,  you get a 1 month sabbatical (30 days time off paid!) for every 5 years you work there, lake to walk around, outdoor volleyball court, grills available for BBQ's, arcades in both buildings, full servicing cafes, 24 hour gym, flexible work schedules and I'm sure I'm forgetting more!
cons: The biggest con for me (will not affect any new hires) being grandfathered into a certain shift negates me from applying for other rolls and moving up in the company. Many employees are grandfathered into a three 12 hour day shift which is great for having children however they took this shift away (which also included a pay increase) and if we were to change positions we loose the additional pay and will be required to work at least 4 days a week. This does not work for my life balance.

headline: Company review
pros: Wage, Benefits, Company status, Career Path, Huge company
cons: CSR is a really tirening job, Weather

headline: Never again!
pros: Good co-workers, no other pros,
cons:
Management is focused on their own career.
Ireland is not a place to live, 41%  tax for the employees, 12% or less for the companies

headline: Join if you want to learn from those who enjoy mediocrity
pros: The company is trying to turn around - there are some great new talent around and Exec seem genuinely interested in fixing problems.  The company is in a hot space. With their footprint in ebay they can't help but make money -- however there is little real impactful innovation.  Pays well and get's green cards for everyone -- which is why so many are there for so long.
cons: Many of the senior leaders below the exec are useless and the processes in the company too rigid to turn these people over. There is a serious lack of any type of ambition or dedication to quality.  Most have not updated their skills in years, and blockers to the change that the company is trying to drive.  Overall the company has very little clue about what constitutes a great 'product'.  Most of the old guard are dead weight and so you are always working against the grain.

headline: Fun, innovative company
pros: There is lots of opportunity for career development.  As a university graduate, I didn't have much to offer in experience but PayPal was willing to take me on and I've got the chance to do jobs that I would have never got if I applied for them externally.  It's a really relaxed environment which I love.  I hate the idea of having to wear suits and ties to work.  I can wear the same clothes that I wear at the weekend but still be completely professional.  On the whole, people are quite nice and open and you always know that you have a lot of support there for any issue you may have in the company, both professionally and personally.  Lots of extra corporate benefits like bonuses, free gym, free healthcare and pension contribution!
cons: Some of the red tape in the company can be a little annoying but this may be similar in many other large multinational corporations.  I think that the salaries aren't quite as high as they could be.

headline: Work life balance
pros: work life balance is good
cons: I can't think of any

headline: Paypal has everything to offer, its my first call center job and have had nothing but a blast.
author_position: Bill Me Later Customer Solutions Agent
pros: The atmosphere is awesome, everyone is generally younger and just enjoy having a good time. Everyone will say Hello passing to each other, also you can see on everyones face that they truly like their job. Promotions are awesome there is always an opportunity to grow. Also the quartly bonus is great!
cons: Customers can be a pain, sitting for long periods at a time (if you have adhd like myself), getting addicted to caffeine.

headline: Merchant Business Support
pros: Innovative and cutting edge company.  PayPal offers great work amenities such a gym, cafe, casusal dress code, and great benefits package
cons: Management is untrained and sophmore in their experience level at best.  Prone to many changes and surprise product releases which begets many fixes, bug patches, etc.  Change is good, too much change breeds instability.  This causes a very unstreamlined work environment due to bad and ever-changing non-maturing business practices and processes

headline: Fast paced culture, smart people, well positioned in its space.
pros: Many smart people who are very driven to get things done. Still a very startup culture.
cons: Sometimes feels like there is lack of focus, too many priorities. Very matrixed environment makes it harder to execute.

headline: Best Corporate Employer

headline: Pretty good for a call center.

Have excellent on site amenities.
cons:
Working weekends, overnights and holidays. 

It's a call center.

headline: New hires beware
pros: So-called "Work and life balance"
cons: When they layoff, the new hires are likely to become victims - happened to me in 2008.  Looking in retrospective it is unclear what the motives are to open these positions in the first place, when the decision makes clearly knew what was coming.  Beware when you get an offer from them!

headline: Good company to work for overall but a struggle for top performers who expect faster paced change and job acceleration
pros:
- nice culture
- good benefits
- ample vacation time (London based employee)
- strong family values
- open door to management
- opportunity to distinguish yourself and make an impact if you're willing to work hard, drive change and produce creative solutions to problems
cons:
- not great at promoting top performers (they seem to subject everyone to the same 2 year promotion process regardless of how good they are). 
- legacy of A* performers leaving because change is too slow / frustrating. in turn C players tend to stick around and get promoted by default.
- siloed environment - not a lot of true cross functional collaboration
- marketing is only just becoming more consumer oriented. professionals tend to be uncreative and unhelpful and supporting anything outside of their core agenda. 
- product has to do SJ's bidding. very little regional control or resource to support new ideas that might move the needle.
- slow to get anything done

headline: Quality of Life

cons: Limited career advancement in certain areas.

headline: Please Read and Beware before and after accepting Offer
pros: None None None None None
cons: Rescinded my offer 13 days after I accepted it. I had 2 other equivalent paying offers (Software Developer) which I had already declined to work for. I would like to suggest people to accept this but don't trust them until you join them in fact don't trust until you work for a month for them. You can be removed whenever. Please don't be at the mercy of their will. Keep your options live until the last moment with this company for your safety.

Leadership not in touch with employees
Employees are way under compensated

headline: A Revolving Door
pros:
Opportunity to interact with very talented and smart people such as ivy league graduates
A job if you need to live in the bay area and have no other options
Good cafeteria with diverse cuisines offered
cons:
Big company politics and policies without the security and stability of one - reorgs happen every 6 months and you may need a new role every so often just to hold on to your job
Executive incentive structure encourages exploitation of the rank and file employees - the company artificially keeps attrition rates low by hiring individuals on visas that restrict their mobility to change employers
Not your typical American company - this is a sweatshop that discourages ideas and innovation
Not a trusting work environment - very unforgiving and harsh to newcomers if they fail to adjust quickly
Constantly hiring - because they constantly fire employees who for no fault of their own are unhappy. Likes to save on severance costs by artificially creating reasons to fire employees.
Management is a firm believer in getting "fresh new blood" all the time to do their bidding. What is worse is all the employees working in the firm are blinded and believe the management's opinion without questions. No one has the guts to be a whistle-blower. And if someone does - they get thrown out for asking too many questions. 
To survive in this company - blindly follow orders and do everything to please your bosses.
Company has been firing employees for meeting it's growth targets - the company is growing phenomenally but because the investors demand even more, the management has accepted the recourse of reducing operating costs.

headline: Not a good place anymore
pros: Good location, nice campus and facility.
cons:
Too many meetings - almost 50% of the day time is spent in various meetings. 
Different vertical teams are hard to communicate and the communication can be quite inefficient. 
Politics are floating around everywhere. Lots of re-orgs. The space for career growth is not much.

cons: GE mentality has taken over VP and Sr. Director level.  Politics and positioning are everything.  Calibration curve is used inappropriately on high performing teams forcing sub-standard ratings to be assigned even though everyone is excellent.

Promote from within which is great, providing the person was promoted for the right reasons.  Decisions made years ago seem to come back to bite them.  Leaders with little or no experience in the department they are managing.

headline: Great company.
pros: Hands down best benefits - cheap healthcare coverage and a 4 week sabbatical every 5 years of employment.  The company has an enormous amount of potential and its future is bright.  They do make efforts to empower employees and show that they are appreciated.
cons: Sometimes the efforts to show appreciation fall short or don't seem genuine.  Pay is low for what is required in certain departments.  The biggest pain point for me was the internal hiring process.  It is very confusing and difficult when attempting to advance within.  I earned three promotions but eventually hit a wall because I do not have a degree yet.  There are several employees who are more qualified for a certain position that do not have degrees that don't even receive an opportunity to interview.  It became extremely frustrating.

headline: Awesome Product and passionate President but lacking true investment in the culture or people
pros:
David Marcus is a great leader. Incredibly passionate!   
PayPal is a great brand to get behind. Employees really seem invested in impacting the organization and the payments industry.  
People here are very sharp! 
Very good outlook for the company. PayPal will do great things in the payments space!
cons:
Comp is average, lacking compared to competitors in Silicon Valley. 
There is a lot of focus on creating incredible product and services but not enough investment in making it a great place to work for employees.  No perks compared to other companies (no free food, snacks, dry cleaning etc). Employee on-boarding is laughable.  Recruiting is sub par.  
The systems/tools are horrendous! Way too many tools.  Makes ppl unproductive 
There is a lot of "talk" about getting stuff done but there are a lot of obstacles preventing it
Stale talent is kept around way too long.  HR leadership is not as impactful as it should be.

headline: OK
pros: Benefits, good people in teams only.
cons: Horrible management, lack of humanity.

headline: Great Experience, good working culture.
pros:
Open minded people, good salary. Work life balance is good. At the end of day it depends on manager. :) Flexible working hours. 
Leadership team is good with clear direction in mind and how to reach there.
cons:
Management is too much self driven, and not looks the bigger picture. Too many managers and real people executing seems to be less. Less collaboration.
Less empowering the employees growth, and too much self centered in many cases.
Not much open to people views.

headline: Great place to work.
pros: The atmosphere is by far the best part of working at PayPal.  The people are really nice and the work place is very modern and comfortable.  Great benefits and incentive to be an efficient worker.
cons: The work itself.  While it is rewarding to turn an irate customer into a happy camper, doing this for eight hours can be mentally taxing.  It makes everyone's goal in the building to work their way up to a position where they're off the phone, making it pretty competitive.

headline: Not the job presented in interviews, a big disappointment overall
pros: Competitive pay, excellent benefits, decent campus and company cafeteria, flexible hours, and marquee brand.
cons:
Hierarchical culture, insular silos, and disconnects between management rhetoric and actions. Frequent re-orgs; some with layoffs. Limited opportunities for professional growth and advancement. Training and conferences are treated as perks for a select few instead of as a necessary investment in employees. Some buildings are crowded; personal workspace and parking are limited. 

PayPal uses a highly politicized “stacked ranking” system for biannual performance ratings, forcing a fixed percentage of staff into Performance Improvement Plans (PIPs) regardless of their actual performance. New employees are generally not considered eligible for “meets expectations” ratings at their initial six month review. 

Because it is used to allocate the annual bonus pool for technical staff, the ranking system creates perverse workplace incentives. (Think: “Game of Thrones”.) Senior managers make the final ranking decisions in a closed meeting. Visibility and perception are heavily weighted. Some allege favoritism. It is not uncommon for the rating assigned by your immediate manager to be reduced by at least one level.

There are many disgruntled employees at PayPal. The cynicism and negativity can be overwhelming at times.

headline: Leadership needs to hold itself accountable for results and values
pros: Good pay and benefits.  Exciting products.  Part of eBay, Inc., which lends credibility to the Paypal leadership team.  Workload is manageable in many roles because the company is overstaffed in many spaces.
cons: The leadership team needs to hold itself accountable for results and modeling the eBay Shared Behaviors.  For a company that is as mature as it is and part of eBay, Inc. it is surprising that it is so immature on many levels - lack of clear goal planning structure, weak communications cadences, under utilization of staff and frequent reorgs to solve issues that can be solved without creating employee churn and productivity loss.  Some of the leaders display unprofessional and poor leadership attributes and rather than holding them to the same standard that employees are held to their behavior is condoned because of who they know.

headline: Short title of review

headline: Constant uphill battle with Product organization
pros:
There are decent folks in User Experience Design (UED) that try their best to do what's right for the user. Most senior executives are on the same page with us grunts and they advocate for organizational change (it's slow, but it IS happening). Things like "Customer Driven Innovation Program" are teaching managers how to actually think like a customers, which they've never done on their own before.

The benefits (health, free stuff, etc.) are great, and our cafeteria in San Jose was awesome (but in the other branches, not so much). I didn't get a chance to do the Employee Stock Purchase Program but I hear its super good too.
cons:
The Product Owners are a thick layer of "dead wood" middle management, as one person described it. Often, there are POs that have crazy amounts of control over just ONE webpage sometimes, so it's impossible to change anything on the site because they need to protect their jobs and the jobs of their direct reports. (And yes, they still wonder why we have so many different login screens and Web flow visual designs...couldn't be because the POs refuse to talk to each other, could it? No, ofcourse not.). They also push out features without ever knowing/researching true user needs, or even understanding their own technology. Frustrating!

The big "transformation" programs are a smokescreen. Many teams aren't doing proper Agile (bad story estimation, splitting/merging stories arbitrarily, cooking performance numbers, fudging or ignoring progress surveys), and some POs aren't even Agile trained even though it is required now. I've heard rumors of POs sending their employees to take trainings for them but I can say 100% if thats true or not. It wouldnt surprise me though.

headline: The only reason to work here is for the healthcare
pros: Healthcare, stock opportunities, 401k plan, build skillet for resume purposes
cons: Negative toxic place to work. Unless you are Management or higher don't bother.  Internal hiring process is pathetic.  Management constantly shifting due to misrepresented talent.  If you just want to be another replaceable piece of the robot, then this place is perfect for you!  They  will switch you out tomorrow without blinking an eye, regardless of your talent or time put into the company. Greedy.  Saddens me to write this. 6 years ago PayPal flowed through my blood.  Now they have become just another greedy organization.  Ps. no I was not fired. Even if the company makes billions of dollars in revenue, don't expect any Christmas bonus. You took too long providing their customers, who made their company all that money, excellent customer service and you are punished in return for taking the extra minute by receiving zero bonus. Isn't that ironic?   I had the opportunity to work in 3 different departments and found it is a common trend throughout.

headline: Too many politics! Too much upper management! Horrible review and promotion process!
pros: Good pay. Lots of good people.
cons:
The review process is not objective, there is no way you can defend your performance because it is not based on objective, measurable,pass/fail criteria. 

In other places I've worked at, you set measurable objective goals at the beginning of the period. At the end of the period you can say with confidence you met or not met your goals or perhaps exceeded your goals, and you are evaluated accordingly. It makes sense!

At PayPal you get "compared" to other employees in your organization. And when you ask your manager to explain why you got the rating you got, it is never an objective, measurable, pass/fail goals.

It is a well known "secret" that managers are forced to evaluate their team based on a bell curve, so even if you have a lot of superstars on your team, the manager is going to have to single one or a couple out to be given a "sub par" evaluation.

Some of the people that do not deliver anything, or that have their projects get promoted. While others that do deliver a working project, on time, get fired... go figure.

headline: PayPal is an excellent company to work for!
pros:
Interesting technical challenges and engaging work environment
You get well rewarded for your efforts and contributions
good work life balance
cons:
Always some level of politics in every project and initiative 
To get a solution out the door, there's a lot of groups that need to be either engaged or kept informed to ensure success. I guess this is just life in a big tech company!

headline: Keep it Human, falling short.
pros: Great salary, Great employee's, Great benefits, Great Employee parties. Wonderful training, PayPal is breaking ground as to how to ensure a good employee turn around from training to production. !:1's and Team Huddles, weekly, are such a benefit to the employee's, and an open door policy with all management staff is someone tot talk about.
cons:
I was fired for an incident that happened outside of work, that involved a work product.. The PayPal Debit card. Long story short, My brother was killed by the phoenix police department. I had a hard time dealing with this, and I was meet with 3 days of paid time off, if I had the paid time off to match the time off. Then began the struggle. I had to go through FMLA and battle with the 3rd party disability leave company that eBay uses to handle their disability claims. I won that battle, and when I came back, "ready" as much as their disability company would allow me to be(read as intensive counseling, and soul searching.) I cam back, and resumed employment.

Shortly after(maybe a week or two), I went out with a friend who wanted to talk about my loss. I ended up spending entirely too much(220$ on my bar tab exclusively). When I went to use my PayPal Debit card(which was recommended by my employer as a way to get familiar with company products), It was declined. I did the same thing that any other red blooded american would do, and I called the number on the back of my card. Now I was frustrated, but in relatively good spirits, all thins considered. After the bad representative I spoke with basically stated, there is nothing she will do to help me, I said, I cant believe you would not try to help me, because I help customers like this every day. That's when the call took a turn for the worse, instead of trying to resolve my problem, the rep I spoke with went about capturing as much non-payment related info as they could about my employement there, and filed a claim with their manager.

Two weeks later, I was terminated saying that, "My candor outside of work was not congruent with the image PayPal wanted to present to its clients"

For the record, I have no ill will towards the rep that resulted in my inproper termination.

I say Improper because the Department of Economic Security agreed, and payed me unemployement.

headline: A good company to work for IF you can secure the right position.
pros: Benefits are probably the best of any company that I've ever heard of and I'm not just speaking of health benefits and stock options. PayPal offers everything from tuition reimbursement to a free membership with Care.com.
cons: If you want a position outside of customer service, you must be prepared to work your behind off and deal with the politics of a large corporate world. And trust me, unless you're a college kid working towards a degree, you WANT to be out of customer service. In the position that I was in, I was one of five in the entire company supporting three rather large departments. I loved my job, but there was SO much drama and cattiness. People have been in these positions so long, it was like High School all over again.

Common answer is, even though your a rock star you just got promoted so even though you should be XX rank, you are going to have to wait another year (focal) to get promoted. Future promises like these don't happen because chances are the person who was your boss wont be in 3-6 months after the next re-org. They tend to happen every 3-6 months for the last 10 years.

headline: A downright toxic work environment
pros:
Flexible schedules
Working with some of the best talent in the industry
cons:
Top down management style (explained below)

What the new senior management has been doing as part of a drive to redesign the company is to eliminate certain units, redesign some and grow a chosen few. The method of implementation however has not been to layoff employees, but it has been to create a very hostile work environment in specific groups and departments to encourage attrition. And in some cases where individuals do not leave in a few months - as a last resort, some employees get specifically targeted at each level where in a situation would be created for them that pushes them to leave. They would find themselves in a situation where a new construct requires a different skill set. Or their existing jobs may suddenly require them to work in a different location owing to a new drive in which every member of a single functional unit is to be sitting in the same office. Hence they would either end up in a situation in which they may be fired by finding some excuses for poor performance, or they get fed up and leave on their own if they act first.

What is also unfortunate is in such a environment, nepotism, racism and favoritism tends be very rampant as everyone tries to save their own skin

headline: High turnover, Unqualified management .
pros: Learning about the ecommerce and merchant services industries. They also have a gym and cafe located inside the building.
cons:
I went through four different managers and several commission plan changes in two years of being there. No one knew what was going on or how we were getting paid. Reps would always be complaining about leads and researching your sale to see if you were cheating somehow by getting referrals. Reps are always reporting other reps to HR . 
Management would be more focused on your talk time and would threaten to fire you if you didn't hit your numbers. Very stressful work environment .

headline: If I were given a dollar for every time I wished Paypal should sink, I would earn more than my salary.
pros:
1) Good salary
2) Good perks
3) Free time (Not for my team, for the rest of Paypal)
cons:
1) Many products have such implementation that you can't even think that a perfectly sane mind would design such thing. So if you are sane enough (have common sense), you would not understand it unless you are explicitly told so.

2) People have devised acronyms for almost anything. So don't be alarmed if you find someone saying, "XYZ should have been designed as ABC unlike BOS. It would have increased SPT." Too many acronyms in one sentence, eh? But you should read an internal email. People will behave like this is some general knowledge you should know.

3) For India primary location is Chennai: although an office was started recently in Bangalore , most of the work is still done in Chennai. For a guy from northern part of India, I find it very difficult to live here.

4) Lack of techies: I had expected that there would be an abundance of geeky people here as it's a tech company. But I was hugely disappointed. Being a techie myself I don't find anyone interested enough to discuss something technical.

5) Lack of concern for employees: I have to be on on-call support every alternate weekend. For those weekends I can't plan any trip. I have to even carry my laptop even when I want to go to movies. This was fine if this happened once in a while. But every alternate weekend, WTF. So I started to stop caring for my work and live my life peacefully (read, being irresponsible). Please note here that this situation could not have come if they have hired enough number of people for the job!

6) Mostly unmotivated workforce: The average age of the company must be over 30. With numbers so skewed towards middle aged people, you can't expect much enthusiasm. People come and go like government offices.

7)Too many meetings: Really? Did you need a meeting to decide how many meetings should there be per week? Can't it be discussed as one of the topics in one of those meetings? Who likes all these lengthy and boring meetings anyway? Well.. you get the idea.

I can go on and on, but stopping here to keep it short (oops! it's already long).

Focused prioritization on investment required.   Product managers not able to run their business, but are project managers.  Offshore development model highly ineffective.

headline: It's a place to grow with a wide range of possibilities
pros: The culture, for the most part, is positive, and the greater percentage of people are hard-working and nice. eBay treats it's employees pretty well, and they regularly have creative events and parties to build on the fun vibe of the employees. There are a ton of opportunities to learn, and you're generally encouraged to dive in, move laterally, and find your way.
cons: It has a long history of passive aggressive behavior, serial re-orgs, and new leaders clearing out people for a variety of agendas (bring in their own people, streamlining the workforce, etc.). The good reputation of the company is being undermined by rash RIFs, forced resignations, etc.

headline: The overall experience in terms of learning and exposure has been great

headline: Good company to work for

headline: Nice Company to work for.
pros: Big company, lot of opputunities to grow in your carreer, exciting products ever increasing growth. Interesting place to be in at this time. Very good payscales. Overall I would recommend to my friends. Many good programs for personal development, and training programs.
cons: Work life balance would be bit screwed, worth the Pay, Some groups Middle Mgmt is political, play games, dishonest and tries to Manage up. Sometimes it is annoying. Good part is you can always find a opening internally and move on.

headline: Work at PayPal if you have good political skills and don't care about work life balance.
pros: Good salary & benefits. Soccer field.
cons: Horrible performance review process, very political.

headline: Too much work !
pros: Their benefits are okay !
cons: I have worked 2,5 years in PayPal in two different department. Both were customer assisting positions , CS is really hard and too much work and too many targets, you are constantly under pressure by your stats even your one to one with your manager is such a torture that is a great opportunity where your manager can pressure you even more. That is how things work in PayPal.

headline: Not a collaborative and fair work culture
pros: Growth prospects of company are good - if one is lucky to join the right group chances of moving to senior roles can be descent (promoted once in 2 years).
cons: Not a level playing field - seasoned employees won't share knowledge and information is very poorly documented for the benefit of new comers. Company's forced rating mechanism ensures poor co-operation amongst team members as each tries to ensure his or her position within the company. Very high employee attrition rate, and very frequent re-orgs (at least twice a year) that lead to inefficiency and churn. Quality of data is very poor and no two sources ever match. Performance measurement is very subjective and growth in the company depends on how politically connected one is within the organization.

headline: Tough to get things done and feel like you are making an impact, but good work-life balance
pros: Work-life balance is good, v interesting space, good growth prospects
cons: Lots of processes make it difficult to GSD, lots of politics, frequent reorgs

headline: It has improved to a certain degree
pros: The pay is ok... had to take a severe pay cut to move to Chandler from Omaha. Given that I have been with the company for going on 8 years now, one would think my pay would have stayed the same, but there is nothing like that offered for employee loyalty. Great insurance. Job stability.
cons: I have worked at PayPal for going on 8 years and have not been able to move up the ladder. It is very difficult to move within the company because 20-50 people will apply for 1 position. And, unless you know someone already doing that job who is willing to refer you, your chances of getting the job are slim...it's more about "who" you know than "what" you know. The jobs are so monotonous that they're simply not challenging enough, so unless you're close to retiring and just need a job to get you by until then, this may not be the place for you. The technology is outdated and management keeps saying they are going to improve on it, but have yet to follow through on the promise...they have been promising that since I started my first day on the job. It's a very micromanaged workplace. Never used to be that way. I used to love coming into work every day. Then they cracked down on the stats and introduced a stupid "development plan" that doesn't seem to get you anywhere in the company; I have never understood the purpose of the development plan. They say management looks at it, but I have never know them to. If you work extra hard, it only yields a pat on the back. They are more strict on dress code in Chandler than they are in Omaha, which doesn't make much sense given Omaha is the corp. headquarters. So, they are focused on appearance/attire, but allow employees to act immature and be noisy which carries over to the customers on the phone; this would NOT be tolerated in Omaha --that only gives the customers a bad perception of PayPal. There is nothing for employee loyalty or retention.

headline: Overall some really talented, committed dedicated engineers solving complex relevant problems - but poor infrastructure
pros:
will get to work on very interesting, complex problems if you are so inclined
some really talented committed people at various levels
cons: poor infrastructure and not so great processes - so need to invest some time initially (and on-and-off) to learn how to navigate these quickly

cons: Since we are a global company, sometimes it feels like they put quantity or quality.  Too many positions in the administrative side that more or less do the same thing or cover the same area/services for the company. They could eliminate many positions by doing do a major restructure and combine some positions into one.

headline: a great company to work for

headline: No empowerment to make decisions
pros:
-Salary comparable with competitors if hired externally
-Bonus potential up to 15%
-Stock options
-Private healthcare
-Teams were hard working, motivated, ethical and worked hard to promote a cohesive, fun and friendly team environment
-Team leaders competent and 'human'
cons:
-Lack of empowerment even at manager level; directors had the final day and it was a 'top down' 80s industrial style management at VP/Director level
-Expected to do job without adequate tools or resources 
-Values preached but not always practiced. Managers tried to make things right and fair but hands were tied when it came to executing on decisions (eg grades and salaries for people)
-Lack of overall vision and communication. Often two different project teams were duplicating efforts by working on the same project or working on projects with completely contradicting goals. 
-Facility- complaints raised about ineffective HVAC (building either freezing or roasting), smoking area on balconies near fuel zones do not even meet health and safety code
-Reward people who grow up at the company; external hires make up to 25% more than leaders who are grown from within

headline: great company

headline: Improve Upper Management and Business Practice
pros:
Many people are willing to do their best and accommodating. 
It is a beauty to see everyone marches in unison once the company-wide initiative and expectations are clearly communicated.
PayPal encourages entrepreneurial culture, provides executive sponsorship for worthwhile ideas/prototypes, tries to attract technologists and attempts to compensate well.
Executives express their appreciations to little guys in various ways including company wide meetings and corporate communications.
There are SPOT awards to individuals and sometimes teams for going beyond their call of duty.
PayPal celebrates a lot at both company and individual team levels.
PayPal encourages employees to have a work-life balance and provides tools and resources. 
Some people make work place fun by hosting social events both alcoholic and non-alcoholic. 
There are communities withing PayPal with many helping hands.
cons:
Too much lip service and too few quality managers.
Too many architects, directors and VPs.
Many projects get started but do not really come to fruition or even road tested.
Process heavy and agile practices/expectations misunderstood at many levels.
Many leaders do not necessarily understand domains that they own beside how they can take advantage of it to move up/out to the next level.
Some key leaders think that PayPal is quite bloated. Even then, whatever the work force that was trimmed in 2012 for PayPal to be lean and fast, the growth in Bangalore and Chennai seems to replace far beyond those numbers.
Nepotism and selected consuls seem to exist. Some leaders force fit key roles with people from their previous companies regardless of qualifications.
Some San Jose teams seem to be constantly catching up due to difficulties in getting requisitions approved while Bangalore and Chennai seem have problem filling up their requisitions, which no one really questions. Most San Jose folks treat the work-life balance as academics.

headline: Micromanagement without other plusses

2. Managers with no scruples and no technical/people skills
3. No stock plans to make it better

cons: lack of opportunities to be upwardly mobile. when a job posting comes out, you are competing against at least 10-15 people (sometimes as many as 30-40 people) because many tenured people are desperate to move up. final decisions on candidates seem to be based on who you know, not education or experience. many quality people have left the company because they just can't get ahead.

headline: There's some good, some bad, and some very bad.

cons: Imagine how much the company can accomplish if it actually makes the whole company nimble, innovative, and productive. Too much politics, too many useless and "talk only" middle managers. Some managers are tacticians and good implementers, but are also brutal and warlord-like, stifle creativity and plays cronyism; hire and promote "their own kind".

Unwritten law: Never critisize your TL or manager.  Once someone is in this position it is hardly possible to get rid of them even if they ae unqulified for their position.
In the job no room for creativity. It is working in a routine and scheme only.
