headline: A good company with high potential, however org is complex with overlaps, lots of stress and ambiguity
pros: competitive pay. stocks are doing good (can be better). smart people to work with. good culture of innovation
cons: reorg is norm. collaboration is a joke here when you have to work with several teams who may be doing something similar and everyone try to find their sponsors. work life balance is bad - working on night and weekend is norm here (you may be able to find teams where you don't need to, but usually such teams won't stay long in such fast pace company).

headline: If you love to be forced to take rest because of technical hurdles of using archaic technology, you should work here
pros:
Money is good, and Paypal deals in money.
Huge customer base, so be assured that company will be profitable for long time.
Who doesn't love free snacks and free ride in AC buses.
Flexible working hours with an option to work from home sometimes.
Not much work to do.
cons:
Even though its a product company, work culture is same as service companies. People just want to finish bare minimum or if possible twist the project requirement and push testing guys to just pass the code as the way it is.
No proper knowledge transfer programs for new hires and no proper documentation for new hires. While there are some good articles, they are scattered on so many different websites that while searching for something you will feel like you are on a treasure hunt, and believe me you will feel same kind of joy when you find something worthy!!
While the whole world have moved to modern technologies which are easier to handle and more intuitive to work with it still uses cgi implementation using C++. In my opinion not more than 1% of people in Paypal Chennai know how the whole system works, right from the frontend to the backend, I don't know about the other offices.
There is so much mixup of different technologies, so much of real work done on patches and by porting software, that you might get a feel that if ever someone sends Paypal code as an entry to some collage making competition, no other team will have a slightest chance of winning.
You have to work with a crowd of people where you won't find inspired by anyone. This is especially a bad scenario for you if you are in early stage of your career and you want to have a mentor.
Moving from one team to another is very difficult, unless of course if you have something to blackmail, like another job offer.
At last the most important thing, it will entrap you with all the joys I mentioned in Pros, make you a worthless person who doesn't know anything about the latest technologies, who does not fulfill any of the criteria of a good software engineer. So you are bound to live with Paypal and die with it, unless of course if it throws you out.

headline: No place for technology folks here!

headline: PayPal has a good work environment and they take care of their employees.
pros: Progressive benefits, lots of P.T.O., good health, dentist, and life insurance available. There is opportunity for lateral changes periodically, if you want to try a new position. There is also opportunity to progress upward. The work environment overall is good. They also offer school tuition reimbursement.The management was nice and did everything that they could to set you up for success. They allow you to plan for your progression and set goals to get where you want to be in the company.
cons: Most positions at PayPal require receiving and/or calling customers. Call center jobs are stressful in general. Depending on your department the benefits are based on surveys from customers, which are inconsistent and hard to control. For example you could please 9/10 customers but only 2/10 get a survey and one of those could be the unpleased customer. They are also based on call handle time which means that you are always in a hurry to close the call.

headline: Company has a great potential but is poorly managed
pros: Stock is great and you get to work on new technology
cons: Very Political and has no employee loyalty

headline: Lots of politics, Great compenastion
pros:
+ Base Salary is great
+ Bonus and stock structure are great
+ Work/Life balance is great
+ Very strong revenue stream
cons:
- Politics. This company you move up on who you know, not what you do
- They want to take it back to a start up. The way they are doing it is horrible. 
- They go through management/upper management like no other company i have seen

headline: Best place to work in the big eBay family
pros: The main [difference] is the focus that PayPal puts on the employees and how every decision that is made, we’re made part of it. The boss is not just someone who is above you in the hierarchy. The treatment and the respect towards employees is the most important difference.”
cons: Compared with other big companies in Irleland PayPal and eBay could offer more or similar beneficials than the others big one, like free food and softdrinks, free child-care or creche and/or at least a more focused support of parents

headline: Disputes and Claims Specialist
pros: Great pay and benefits, laid back work environment. 8 weeks of training.
cons: A lot of change, career advancements was very competitive and call metrics were pretty aggressive.

headline: Your average bureaucratic corporate environment
pros: Green building, onsite gym, shuttle transportation, customer driven goals = gold mine for business development and product development, green company, bicycle friendly. Good experience for new grads, consultants and summer interns
cons: Lots of turnover in management and re-organization of groups. No real career development.  Chances of getting a good manager is like gambling. management is authoritative, hierarchical and elitist

headline: It is wonderful.
pros: Nice work environment, nice office infrastructure and diverse culture. It is everything a graduate can expect as a first job after graduation in technology.
cons: No cons really. Maybe because the main office in India is in Chennai and many people, especially those from north, will not prefer it is a working place because of the culture and weather.

headline: Overall Nice place to work
pros: Great place to work. Everyone is very dedicated to their work
cons: very quiet place, not much fun loving people

headline: Great place to be
pros: great technology comoany with very motivated team.
cons: Things can take a long time to change.

headline: Disorganized,
pros: competitive pay, but  inefficient, ineffective, slow, wasteful
cons: too many layers of middle management

headline: Credit Risk Analyst
pros: encourage innovation, collaborative team environment, work life balance.
cons:
data management is not so organized;
various system access approval not in centralized site

headline: Good if you want a job, terrible if you want a career
pros: 15 days PTO in year 1, medical insurance starts on day 1,  Sabbatical after 5 years, activities and events to keep young people engaged (prom themed Christmas party. They gave out yearbooks as gifts.)
cons: There is no room to do anything in your career. Everything is hourly and the average age has got to be just out of high school. They force you to have a development plan, but it is all for show as there is no where to go. This is a great place if you have a high school education or got a college degree in theater, but if you are a business professional, know that the job you take is the job you will have until you decide to leave.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
One of the best annual salary package
Lots of free goodies like Bus/Cab service for pickup/drop
cons:
Inconsistent goals.
3-4 years behind in terms of picking up technologies, To build a small feature they introduce a lot of plans and consumes a lot of time.
Too many Directors & VPs in the company hierarchy.

headline: endless parade of "leaders"
pros:
> most managers try to make sure you maintain a good work/life balance
> lot of flexility as far as working from home/remotely
cons:
If you are a UE/UX designer (UI, visual design, content, user research) this is NOT the place for you. Despite some job postings and/or reviews to the contrary, if you're looking to do some really interesting work and grow as a designer do NOT work for PayPal.
> an endless parade of "leaders" has driven this company in general, and the UED team in particular, right into the ditch. They've tried to reboot this team so many times b/c the senior leadership is totally incompetent.
> your work will not be recognized, rewarded, or celebrated. 
> you will be moved on to projects and into verticals regardless of any interest you have expressed or career goals you have. 
> IF your manager actually bothers to set goals with/for you, how you do on those goals will generally be ignored when evaluations occur. 
> evaluations are generally a popularity contest and are based more on how hard your manager fights for you then the work you actually did or how you did against your goals. 
> an absurd amount of money will be spent on pointless schwag and company celebrations rather than on salaries, team offsites/team building, or things that most people generally consider "useful." You will also find yourself wondering why you would possibly need another cheap plastic water bottle rather than some actual decent advertising that could bring in more revenue or positive attention. 
> right about the time you finally get an org chart and start to get a good sense of how the team is structured, sr management will conduct a 're-org' and change it. you can expect this to happen on an annual basis, if not more frequently.
> as part of the recurring re-orgs you will be moved to yet another manager, again with little to no concern for any relationship you have established.

headline: Good company, you'll need to work hard to rise
pros: Overall a good culture, like any company depends on your team and manager.  Reputation among technologist improving and David Marcus is executing well.
cons: Large organization means things can move pretty slowly and affecting change will require good politics to pull in champions for your ideas

headline: A management driven company
pros: Good work environment and facilities. Work life balance
cons: Continuous changes in management and each management thinks differently. You end up following those changes.

headline: Great place to work many international opportunities
pros: Mobility and size with many various departments and opportunities to switch professions. I like to work here but they generally pay less Han other companies for similar roles. However the benefits are very good.
cons: Size and internal competition. When you go for a job internally there are many people going for it at the same time. The company is also quite far outside the city.  And not easy to get to from many places in Dublin.

headline: Software Quality Engineer
pros: Flexible hours, challenging work environment, rapid growth of the business, good pay
cons: Engineering environments, lots of legacy code to deal and  frequent changes in process, tools

headline: Poor if you are a technologist in North America. Good if you are on the Product side.
pros: Outstanding coworkers and very  good compensation.
cons:
I have been in Software for 15 years and have never met another company where they tell you NOT to learn new technologies. Their whole goal is instead have you devote your time to getting people in India to up to speed and to do the work for you. As a result of this, the opportunities and career path are very limited. Forget training.  I did not experience this for the first few years when I joined - at that time it was a thriving environment, but this is what the company has become - and it shows as internal quality has gone down and we are not up on the newest/best technologies.

Additionally, if you get a good manager, things can be ok, if not, your career will die. There seems to be no decent way of regulating this from the top.

Lastly, promotions and career growth are non-existent if you are on the technology side. It is significantly better if you are on the business one.

headline: Smart people in a big fast growing company.
pros: Fantastic benefits and incredibly smart people. Some of the smartest people I have worked with in my career were at PayPal. Starting to become more of a marketing company and less of an engineering company which I think will only help growth.
cons: Like any larger company it seems to be too heavily matrixed and there needs to be more communication between regions to take the company to the next level.

headline: Lots of opportunity from a great yet imperfect company.
pros:
-Friendly and supportive culture--not a dog eat dog environment
-Great benefits and excellent eBay inc. stock program
-High performers are recognized and rewarded
-Current (though not past) management recognizes company challenges and has put bold plans in place to improve.
cons: The company's core technology and development processes stunt innovation at the company.  This makes product development progress incredibly slow and often unsatisfying to all who contribute.  This has driven away many talented product managers and developers.  eBay also has a penchant for constant reorganization.  Every time a new senior leader comes in, a reorganization will be put in place.  This flux causes churn and impedes both the company's and employees' goals.

headline: Benefits good, casual workplace, few opportunities for advancement
pros:
- Good benefits
- Onsite gym
- Subsidized cafe on site with local ingredients
- Partner benefits for same sex couples
cons:
- few opportunities for advancement
- few opportunities in professional, salaried positions
- disconnect between leadership goals and management implementation of goals
- disconnect between President's message and local leadership
- clear favoritism, with some employees who excel being held back without explanation

headline: Great Place to be for guys/girls who know how to walk over and leave the human side aside.
pros: Salary is one of the best in the industry.
cons: Organisational direction is never clear or consistent.

headline: Paypal has lost its way, while management dithers
pros:
people who know what they should be doing
bagels on wednesdays
nice gym
cons:
people who play along to get along, rather than doing what they should be doing (which requires having the guts to push against management)
management who lies through their teeth and has no shame about it

headline: Good work culture, Good Compensation, A bit lacking in terms of adoption of new technologies but working hard to improve
pros:
1) Good Compensation. >50% increment over my previous job.
2) Good perks ( Buffet lunches & Breakfast, $1000 flexible benefits, excellent healthcare that covers specialist visits and child birth)
3) Lots of team outings, meals and parties paid for by the company.
4) Lots of smart people who are diligent with their job.
5) Company is doing very well and this is a morale booster
6) Highly disciplined workforce who care about their job and are willing to work the extra mile should the situation arises.
7) Willing to spend money to invest in new technologies and training for staff
cons:
1) Work hours can be very long during critical periods.
2) Some of the technologies and tools are out of date. Management recognises this and has been investing a lot of money in trying to improve this area.
3) Big company politics and bureaucracy.
4) Very process-driven company

cons: they treat you like child

pros: Friendly working environment, flat hierarchy, flexible working hour
cons: not learning much because it's already well organized. career opportunities may be limit depends on department

headline: software engineer 3
pros: competitive pay, work life balance, facilities such as gym etc
cons: slow in project execution, recent layoffs,

headline: good atmosphere to work here
pros: all are pros - good atmosphere to work here
cons: sometimes layoffs are pain -

headline: Working environment was really good
pros: Pleasant atmosphere, friendly people, good environment
cons: No transparency between employees and employer

headline: Stop the churn - of the people and of the company resources! Please get some focus!
pros:
- "Start-up" kind of culture
- Casual work attire
- Ability to atleast "talk" innovation
- Not as bureaucratic as one would expect
cons:
- Most senior leaders are from traditional bureaucratic environments, so they do bring the same culture with them, albeit wearing jeans 
- PayPal WILL take advantage of its employees, low pay and long hours is a given
- Review process is flawed if non-existent, no basis for promotions or lack there of, leads to a direction-less career (HR deptt can be easily outsourced)

headline: PayPal is a good place to work at
pros:
Growth Company - Great market potential
Focus from Senior leadership in being a technology driven and customer centric company
cons: Culture at PayPal needs to evolve to greater technical excellence, higher productivity & customer centricity.

headline: Constant org changes, poor work / life balance
pros:
Strong business that continues to drive growth and profits
Global reach, with a strong presence in many international markets
Smart co-workers
Nice campus, with great cafeterias
Driving some pockets of innovation
cons:
Unwieldy technology base hampers new product development
Constant re-orgs (I had 4 managers over 2 years)
Constantly focusing on the next shiny new thing, sucking resources from other initiatives
Cutthroat environment - not many team players
24/7 culture means poor work / life balance

headline: First Year was Great, then....
pros: Somewhat flexible scheduling, good insurance
cons: They lull you in with a false sense of security and empowerment. Thats THE WORD there, empowerment. But when you take steps to use that empowerment, they fault you. I was there for a year (in CS) and then transferred to one of the back office departments. I was in that department for a few months, and the supervisor didnt like me so she made up about 15 different things to get me written up. She had no proof but I had no recourse. Went to HR, who did nothing. Because I was a simple agent and the other party was a supervisor, I had no ground to stand on. Nevermind that the year I spent in CS, I exceeded all company expectations and the supervisor stepped down to an agent position. Do not work for this company unless you like to be disrespected and back stabbed on a daily basis. Several of my friends who encouraged me to work there stated they loved it. I'm sure they used to be an awesome company, but  I think they are trying to keep up with competitors and keep their bank accounts in the 7 digits. They've forgotten about their employees and the environment that made people want to work there in the first place.

headline: Fast-paced, large global org with lots of opportunities to move around or take on projects.
pros: Highly profitable company that's changing the payments industry. Very smart, warm people. Lots of opportunity to move from business unit to business unit. Ability to take on things you're interested in.
cons: Can have pretty heavy workload.

headline: Great experience, mediocre system, and poor development environment
pros: Great company which is doing extremely well in the marketplace. In some groups, the code you touch affects the livelihood of millions of people. A great place to learn about payments and payments processing. Some really top notch engineers.
cons: More than a few mediocre engineers just coasting. The code base is kind of a mess, although many efforts are being made to fix things. The development environment, building and testing, was a real mess when I was there, although I hear that things have gotten a bit better.

headline: Not a  Great place to work and build Career
pros: Good exposure to payments domain
cons:
The closeness to upper management matters more than work
Promotions and oppurtunities are based on who you know and  how your boss is placed in the group rather than work
Multiple reorgs with no result
Lay offs not based on work but on several other factors in nae of streamlining the organization

headline: Internal fighting, politics galore
pros: Pay is decent and company's prospects are positive
cons: The most recent re-org at PayPal has been a nightmare. David Marcus said that he was going to simplify things to "GSD" but it turns out that he isn't able to stop the infighting on his executive team so that all the teams under them are confused. You have one senior VP saying that POS is the most important thing to the business and the other senior VP saying that he's going to get it cancelled and therefore, no one knows what to do or how to execute. My entire team is hardly working because we don't actually know what to do!

headline: Internal fighting, politics galore
pros: Pay is decent and company's prospects are positive
cons: The most recent re-org at PayPal has been a nightmare. David Marcus said that he was going to simplify things to "GSD" but it turns out that he isn't able to stop the infighting on his executive team so that all the teams under them are confused. headline: Its a mess
pros:
Good work life balance
Nice facilities 
Some very smart people (but a lot of mediocre ppl as well)
cons:
It seems like there is a reorg always going on...
Not an engineering company, neither a product company, its a business company... 
Engineers should not come here to enhance their skills... 
Too many mid level dev managers and project managers who dont understand anything at all and are not involved in anything, I am unsure what their job is...

headline: Excellent opportunities to learn and innovate
pros: Innovation.  The company encourages it and if you have an idea, you can work it.  This is a rare opportunity to be part of something great and make a difference at an individual level.  The work-life balance is great.  There are wonderful, smart and driven people to collaborate with.  It brings out the best in me as I'm surrounded by top talent.
cons: The company is at an inflection point.  It's experiencing tremendous growth, but knows its competitors, who are small and nimble, are gaining ground.  It knows it needs to change, but it's not quite sure how to change its own culture.  We have a goal, but the roadmap on how to achieve the goal is unclear.  Roles and responsibilities are unclear.  Multiple teams solving the same problem in different ways without communicating.  It's not crazy here, just feels like the first 30 seconds of Iron Chef.  We're going to produce something amazing, if we can just find the salt.

headline: Overworked and Underpaid
pros:
-Benefits
- lots of leeway for mediocre work. 
-Immense opportunities
-
cons:
-Pay is LOW and the company does take advantage of its workers.
-The review system is very flawed (with consistent technical/data errors) and when questioned, you are accused of not upholding company values to "Trust Eachother". 
-Anybody with corporate management experience will be hired, regardless of their credibility, character and true experience.
-Many conflicts within operations and system. When conflicts/issues are brought to light, they are not addressed. 
-Expects workers to operate as super human machines.
-Constantly realigning goals and visions as well as assigning new responsibilities but not increasing pay.

headline: Layoff
pros: Until 6 months ago one of the best companies to work for in America. Now, not so much.
cons: Before layoff, my performance appraisal was lowered to a "meets some" over the objections of HR and 2-levels of management. This happened to about 25% of my department and some managers had to reqrite reviews to a lower level.

headline: Increasingly political design org, had been great place to work at
pros:
- Historically had a great work/life balance
- Contributors and some managers always fantastic to work with
cons: - Has become increasingly political, with poorly-qualified individuals making resourcing decisions seemingly based on favoritism, not to mention the recent layoffs

headline: Biggest Start-up in the world
pros: Lots of opportunities to make a difference how people communicate through commerce
cons: Need to break through established corporate habits that are risk-avert

headline: High-tech nightmare
pros: Compensation and benefits to an extent. Convenient location and facility, onsite gym, green field for sports.
cons:
Highly secretive and hypocritical culture with a dash of a far-eastern aptitude. Grinds good professionals down to either stressed out, overworked marionettes or political survivors. Attracts and harbors quite a bit of paycheck chasers and tech phonies.

Processes frequently change and at the same time are as slow as the telegraph in the fiber optic era. It's hard to catch up and stay up to speed, esp for new hires. And of course politics. It has flooded everywhere.

The ebay mothership advertises good values which unfortunately serve as a facade only. Usually values are walked over demonstratively after finding a convenient excuse.

headline: Forgiveness not permission
pros: This is not the same PayPal of 10 years ago. It's hungry, razor sharply focused and attacking a much bigger market than the massive one it already dominates.
cons: PayPal had a lull in the early '00s, and it's spent the last couple years working out of that. Some of those habits are tough to eradicate.

headline: challenging work environment but rewarding experience
pros: Tenured talent pool with positive mentoring in a unique business model/environment.  Start-up menatlity with capital to back
cons: Product not agile.  Decisions slow to implement once they are made.  Significant brain drain to become a more mature business.  Loss of customer focus.

headline: problem analyst
pros: good salaries and benefits; trying to get away from the 'this is how it works at paypal' mentality.
cons: the old timer paypal employees are stuck in the 'this is how it works at paypal' mentality

headline: Great company
pros: Great place to work. PayPal is a company with great values and fantastic people. Employees are valued of what they are and where they are the best in.
cons: Office is in the suburb of Berlin

headline: Nice place to settle
pros: Very nice Work culture and salary is also good
cons: Work will not be a challenging one.. you have learn new things on your own...

headline: It is good.
pros: Many opportunities. The salary is good. Overall good environment. Work life balance is good. What paypal is and the direction set by the management is very clear. Lots of freebies.
cons: - Too many managers. Too many PMOs. It is becoming managers company and not engineers company. The core values are lost.  Although engineers know leadership teams goals, not sure managers follow.

headline: Generally good to work at PayPal.
pros: Working Environment and Pay is good.
cons: Don't join a big company if you want to build a startup

headline: PayPal - as a Workplace, It is the best in my career till now. Love being a part of it.
pros:
Independent to work.
No micromanagement
 PayPal - as a Workplace, It is the best in my career till now. Love being a part of it.
cons:
No Cons to mention like that.
PayPal - as a Workplace, It is the best in my career till now. Love being a part of it.

headline: Horrible place for engineers
pros: Salary was competitive at the time, stock price is currently good.
cons: Horrible, dysfunctional internal politics. Management that is staggeringly tone def. Willingness to announce 900 million in acquisitions and 12% layoffs in the same memo shows total disregard for employees. Virtually no investment in the technology platform that runs the company. Project managers are allowed to force engineering compromises, then move on to the next project before the bills comes due.

headline: Interesting business, skittish culture for an Internet e-commerce leader
pros: Some very smart and creative people, dedicated to their work and to each other.
cons: Way too much politics; slippery non-performers with good manners rose through the ranks to form an impenetrable layer of middle management sludge. Great people left or were laid off.

headline: I had a great run
pros: love working here, colleagues are friendly, managers have the "independent" attitude. Work life balance is great
cons: It's always the same old same old stuff here. Company realize there's a problem (cluster in the management and processes), goes through reorg with a whole new set of philosophy, but nothing is done on the low to mid level management, and then employees and managers complain about clustered process, then goes through another re-org

headline: Changing for a better, but the baggage may be too much.  Glad I've moved on
pros:
High talent level within many teams

Pay competitive, financially stable company, good benefits, ESP option after 6 months, RSUs granted after 1 year, Sabbatical after 5 years, annual bonus

Medical/Dental/Vision, On-site cafeteria and gym, public transportation reimbursed. 

After years of denial, top brass finally admitting customer image is a problem and working on it
cons:
Re-orgs and process changes every few months that have more to do with self-promotion of agendas than helping the company or employees succeed.  

Highly siloed with poor communication between teams.  Projects take 3X longer than they should.  Implementing Agile or similar methodology would help immensely, but never considered.

Onboarding/training is non-existent.  It's up to you to figure things out. The ramp-up to being a productive employee takes several months and you're placed in to situations where you must make decisions without understanding how something works.

Very little opportunities for career growth.  "Bell Curve" performance system encourages mediocrity from workers.  HR is never seen after orientation, and a handful of bad apples show disrespect towards others but are never told to knock if off

Certain groups (Tools, Change Management) are led by inexperienced managers and stacked with employees who couldn't get a job working at an Apple store

Current upper management is prime example of Peter Principle at work.  Way too many former Chase and BofA execs who are now at a technology company and in over their head.

headline: hypocritical rat race company
pros: nice facility, nice location, decent salary
cons: the worst company I have been working for: hypocritical philosophy, bad management, broken processes, consistent forcement to work overtime

headline: Get a job at the CIA, they will trust you more
pros: The only pros I have are the good benefits
cons: Nothing more than a high tech sweat shop.  They will watch you like a hawk and when your numbers look bad you are gone.  The fun environment is just for show and they will hire anybody who can type and navigate the internet.   There is no dress code at all and many look like they just got out of bed.  If you are a mature and profesional adult then just stay away.

headline: PayPal
pros: Exciting - I love working in a global environment and the new technology.   You really get the sense your work matters.
cons: Global company - many work ours are outside the traditional work schedule.

headline: Can be Good, Can be Bad, Depending on Where You Are.
pros:
Culture in Technology and Marketing organizations are great. 
eBay, Inc. has wonderful values and behaviors by which employees are expected to live by. 
Great learning and education opportunities.
Career opportunities are prolific within eBay, Inc.
Salaries are getting more competitive, benefits are really good.
cons:
Front-end development and back-end development is mixed together.
Can take a long time to develop products, too many cooks in the kitchen.
eBay values and behaviors are no where in sight within PayPal UED, where there is a culture of fear and morale is at an all-time low.

headline: So far so good. The people are nice.  Office hours are flexible. And there is a drive to innovate!
pros:
Decent salary.
Open Culture.
Plenty of competitions and everything to build your techie skills.
cons:
The current location is Chennai in India. Not a great place to live in for people from outside Tamil Nadu. Different salary for people in the same positions.

Place of employment is actually Chenai but Glassdoor isn't giving that as an option.

headline: Great when it was small

cons: Corporate greed has gotten the best of it. Better when it was small, now you just report about your job to upper management instead of actually doing it.

headline: Good company to work for

headline: PayPal
pros:
1. Being a manager is a added advantage while engineers of PD are treated as lower order of the value chain in the system!
2. Almighty decisions are usually taken by the managers. Engineers are mute spectators and executors of their will and wish.
3. Great salary packages, at the time of joining.
cons:
1. Career growth is so unpredictable or not clearly tracked by the managers.
2. Salary packages tend to be stay around - with no so lovely hikes. 
3. No good onsites, technology learning, trainings are not supportive or meek. (they could do more).
4. Random nepotistic approach to hiring! Very rarely referrals from tech staff is heeded.

headline: a company that follows Yahoo, DELL and HP
pros: good position on a hot market. the company will get split to another IPO company sooner or later.  at current market, RSU is worth 30k+ per year if you have been working more than four years.
cons: internal management are poor.  Some people has to do most of the work while others does nothing.  talents are leaving for Google, Facebook and LinkedIn.

headline: So much opportunity, so little execution
pros: PayPal has a unique opportunity to become the world's favorite way to pay and be paid. It can enter into any financial service, it can offer all sorts of payment products and enhancements, like offers, discounts, loyalty, big data. Past management has dragged their feet, but new leaders promise a start-up and experimental approach that bodes well.
cons: PayPal has terrible hiring and people management practices, which results in lousy managers hiring huge numbers of lousy people. There exist massive departments filled with friends of friends, most of whom do little work. Years of poor management means that these departments grow regularly every year. There is very little path to promotion from within, because leadership does not seek to groom talent, but hires director-and-up positions from outside.

headline: Good company, Bad Position
pros:
If your career track is Quality Assurance or Customer Service than it has many great points:
-Tuition Reimbursement
They pay up to 5,000 a year for work related courses

-Organized workplace
The most organized place that I have ever worked.

- Healthcare

-Corporate Environment (a lot of parties to boost morale)
They spend a lot of money on making sure the workplace is fun.  It does help boost stressful days.  They will rent different entertainment equipment and throw themed parties. This could be expected almost every month.

-Free Drinks
They have soda machines with free drinks.  Great.

- Great promotions
If you meet your time and quality, you can move up quick.  Really quick.
cons:
The position was a call center position.  
You should already know that dealing with call centers, there are going to be angry customers almost daily. That isn't the problem , the problem is management's idea of how well you handled the call.

-Unfair Quality Assurance scoring when dealing with unruly customers
There are times when you could literally be cursed at and called names by customers.  Customers will call in screaming profanities at the top of their lungs in some cases.  Most companies allow you to disconnect the call after a fair warning.  However, Paypal's QA will always tell you that you could have done more and give you a low score. It's very unreasonable since QA scoring affects potential promotions and pay.

-Call times should be aligned with specific calls
You are judged by the amount of time you spend on the call.  It is true that you take many calls a day, however the calls do not always offset. The system should factor in more leniency for calls types that may be be longer.  You may get a lot of the same calls in a day and those call types are almost impossible to make within a certain time.  Two long calls could mean the difference of a promotion or even your job.

-Managers are EXTREMELY lazy and dismissive.
Some customers will ask for managers, even after you tell them everything that you possibly can.  Situations such as these are to be expected.  However, there are times when managers will be very unhelpful.  Some will help, some will tell you to go back and reiterate what you've already said to the customer, some will duck, some will tell you to go to another manager and some will have attitudes that you've bothered them. It's a waste of time for you and the customer.  

-Quality and Time Policy
Simply put, you are subject to "corrective action" if you don't meet both.  This is wrong for all of the reasons mentioned above.

-Lateness Policy is very unreasonable
They do not tolerate lateness, which is fine.  Being late could mean 1 minute, which is also fine. You are considered late if you are not logged in to your computer within 1 minute after your official start time.  The problem here is, if you are late... you get marked.  If you get two marks within 6 months, you are put on a sort of first and final.  That means if you log into your computer 1 minute late more than twice from the long span of say..Jan to July, you could potentially lose your job.

Its unreasonable especially during winter when there is snow and ice. (This policy could have changed since my departure)

headline: It was truly an amazing experience working as an intern at PayPal

cons: The only con would be that it took a little longer than normal to get the setup ready for an intern to work.

headline: Survival in PayPal is a factor of how you manage upward not how you manage downward.
pros:
Great salary.  It becomes a problem to the extent that you will find it difficult to get your next job.
Good benefits.  But a lot of those benefits were great only in the initial years.
Good stock compensation (that was all in the past - no more relevant)
One of the best places for Payments domain knowledge.
Know how not to build software (there is so much learning that you have once you work here)
There were very few competitors that gave Paypal a big first mover advantage.
A great place to grow skills.
cons:
You may never get proper positive recognition for your work.
You won't get relevant feedback for your actions.  Everything is deemed confidential that noone is supposed to utter a word on who said what about you in any of the appraisal meetings.
If you work in Chennai, your promotions almost always never happens.  This is a personal experience.
If you work in Chennai, your performance is compared with folks in San Jose.  Good in theory but bad in practice since the whole the senior management sitting in San Jose mostly decides all the appraisals. Don't expect a lot of participation from Chennai in senior management.
The management in Chennai has very little authority when it comes to your career options or survival in the company.  Or perhaps, they have no stakes in the matter (there is no transparency at work).
There are so many managers within the PayPal organization, that don't represent a great model of management.  
eBay behaviours are mere statements and i have not seen them followed in spirit by most managers in my hierarchy.
There are so many senior folks that travel frequently from San Jose to Chennai.  The motivator for young engineers is onsite travel which gets affected  because of those travels.  
In PayPal, you decide the appraisal rating and then write the review for an employee based on the rating arrived at.  Really weird.  The funny thing is that the management insists on finishing the reviews from the lower level folks but never get it done for themselves.  Not a nice model when it is not practised at every level.
Some managers in San Jose just don't have the maturity to deal with people under them.  They are just not experienced to be global managers.  There have been a variety of contextual situations in support of this.
If you work in Chennai, expect to be given instructions from San Jose on what needs to be done.

headline: You need to be careful when you work there
pros: Good benefits. Great facilities. The company culture encourages you to network and make connections. Most people are willing to have a meeting to discuss an idea or explain what their group does.
cons: When I first joined the company, someone mentioned the "30 day" discussion. What I learned was that for no concrete reason, your manager can tell you that you have 30 (or more) days to find another position otherwise you will be packaged.  I work with a number of people who are strong performers that were given notice when they were in a previous group. If you do not "fit" with your group you will be squeezed out.

headline: Started great, has gotten horrible.
pros: good benefits, casual dress, free coffee, onsite exercise facility, good cafeteria, 5 year sabbatical, Close to home, Close to the Interstate.
cons:
Promotion is nearly impossible. I have never seen anyone promoted in my 5 years. HR is invisible, perhaps they do not exist. If you have a bad supervisor your life is hell and there is nothing you can do about it because management does not listen. 

Management is completely incompetent. They make vague guesses as to company direction and do not listen at all to the people who actually do the work.  This last year has been a disaster. We have been forced to make thousands of pointless phone calls to customers though the actual people doing the work agreed unanimously it did more harm than good, finally after losing millions to fraudsters and completely alienating the staff, they have gone back to the original policy.

Pay Pal has a very real class system, and fraud agents, along with customer solutions are the untouchables.  Your supervisor is your slave driver in a very real way. If he or she is bad, too bad for you because his manager is going to do nothing.

The pay is okay but it never gets any better. For someone with a college degree, it is a very bad decision to work here. Personally I have a BS and have applied several times for internal openings and have heard nothing, not even a "Thanks for applying" from HR.

It is actually worse than what I have described. Do yourself a favor and do not work at PayPal Omaha.

headline: They value outside talent more than existing talent - even if you're an exceeds performer
pros:
- good pay and benefits
- nice desks (ergonomic) and office space
cons:
- politics, politics, politics
- Even when you get hired as an internal candidate for a job at a higher grade level, you don't get moved up. It's always a lateral transfer unless you're one of the "favorites" who actually gets a shot at the very, very few promotion spots that open up annually.
- They prefer to hire from the outside, so get the title you want coming in because getting it through promotion is unlikely despite your performance.
- I thought that being part of a fast-growing company would mean opportunities for advancement. How wrong I was!! It's the opposite of most places I've worked where advancement was much easier.
